After the investigation board recommended that NASA develop on-orbit repair capability, O'Keefe carried a cheap foam paintbrush in his pocket that he said might be used to spread the patching putty -- both to show the agency's commitment to the goal, and its unconventional thinking.
NASA internal memorandums tell of the degree of uncertainty within the development effort.
The first order of business, redesigning the part of the shuttle that the largest chunks of foam have fallen off of, was hailed as a success, but it was being changed before the Columbia disaster.
Other changes have been made in the fuel tank to prevent formation of ice along and to reduce foam shedding.
The next steps have not gone as smoothly, internal documents show.

A copy of a July 15 presentation by a team working through the tile issues described numerous problems with the filler, which is made of two compounds taken to space and blended by a "goo gun" before application.
Any deviation from the smooth surface of the orbiter, even by fractions of an inch, could have a significant effect on the aerodynamics of the shuttle upon entry into the atmosphere.

It would not be possible to tell if the compounds were improperly mixed or if the material was hardening properly, but accidentally applying only one of the compounds "results in a contaminated repair site, from which no recovery has been demonstrated nor planned for."
The presentation says the equipment being developed and tested is only a partial solution, at best:

Other concerns are underscored in red in the presentation, including those that suggest that some of the repair and re-entry options will be incorporated into the return-to-flight plan before they can be tested -- or without the capability of being fully tested.
A slide depicting a range of tile damage states that in some cases, "likely a 'gap' will exist between on-orbit inspection capability/plan and damage possibility that could be catastrophic."
Other documents show uncertainty in other aspects of the effort to return to flight.
They suggest that NASA still does not really know how much foam the shuttle's enormous external fuel tank will shed.

NASA officials said last month that they had changed the process of applying foam so that pieces no larger than 0.01 pounds would fall off the tank, well below the 0.023-pound chunks that can cause critical damage, according to new research by the agency.
Another presentation discusses when to call for external inspection, repairs and deciding whether it is safe to return to earth.
The problem -- or, as the presentation puts it, "why we got nervous" -- was the sheer number of gouges found on the shuttle in more than 100 flights.
There have been some 15,000 "tile-damage events" in the life of the shuttle program, and each shuttle flight includes an average of 24 nicks or gouges of 2 inches or less.
On average, a gouge of 10 inches has occurred in nearly one flight in five.

Figuring out when to call for inspection and when to call for repair is crucial, or every spaceflight will be turned over to repairing nicks in the craft with untested tools, and using up time and money that is needed for other things.
NASA officials say they recognize these problems.

But they said shuttle astronauts would have an extra margin of safety from the "safe haven" plan, which would allow a damaged shuttle to dock at the International Space Station until a rescue mission could be mounted.
That plan, however, has large risks of its own.
Getting to the station's orbit would be anything but certain in a damaged craft.

NASA internal documents suggest that the station lacks adequate support systems and supplies to assure that its own occupants and a shuttle crew could stay alive for more than a few months at best and a few weeks at worst -- not enough time, under many possible situations outlined in the documents, to carry off a rescue plan.
Meanwhile, the space station, which has been occupied since 2000, is itself troubled, with its crew scaled back from three people to two after the loss of Columbia.
Crucial systems like the oxygen generator have malfunctioned repeatedly, and supplies are dwindling without the freight-hauling capacity of the shuttles to resupply the station.
Beutel, the NASA spokesman, said safety on all fronts would continue to be improved in the test bed of space.

Once we get back to flying, it's not over with R and D.
Just because we're back to flying, it doesn't mean we're not going to improve for the rest of the shuttle missions.
But people who have the most direct interest in a safe shuttle say they are ready to fly.
THREE KEY SAFETY ISSUES REMAIN UNRESOLVED, BUT NASA WILL STILL CONSIDER JULY LAUNCH DATE FOR DISCOVERY

Though NASA has made strides in lowering the risks from space shuttle flights, the agency has failed to fully meet three key safety recommendations set forth by the Columbia accident board for resuming launches, an oversight panel said Monday.

The ruling from the Return to Flight Task Group comes with just a few weeks remaining in NASA's timetable for launching the shuttle Discovery with seven astronauts on the first mission since Columbia's fatal breakup more than two years ago.

The task group found shortcomings in NASA's efforts to eliminate losses of foam and ice from the shuttle's towering external fuel tank; adequately strengthen areas of the spacecraft vulnerable to critical damage from debris impacts; and equip the astronauts with a reliable repair kit.
The ruling of the task force will be a factor, but not necessarily an obstacle, when the space agency decides if it will stick with its plans to launch Discovery between July 13 and 31.

I think you need to look at what the agency has done, not necessarily a score card, said Richard Covey, the former astronaut who co-chaired the 26-member task force of aerospace, risk-assessment and management experts.
I don't think a score card is the way to look at it.
More than a 100 shuttle program officials will gather at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Wednesday and Thursday to formally review the Columbia recovery effort and set an official launch date.

NASA administrator Michael Griffin, who will participate in the two-day flight readiness review, has said he will carefully weigh the task force's deliberations when he joins his management team in making the final decision.
Today, Griffin will appear before the House Science Committee to discuss Discovery's readiness and other issues facing the nation's human spaceflight program.
The Columbia Accident Investigation Board issued its recommendations after a wide-ranging inquiry into the causes of the Feb. 1, 2003, Columbia tragedy.

Struck under the left wing at liftoff by a 1.67-pound chunk of break-away fuel-tank insulation, the stricken shuttle was ripped apart as hot gases entered the breach during the high-velocity descent to Earth.
With only blurred, recorded views of the strike to work with, mission managers erroneously concluded that the foam chunk was not massive enough to cause critical damage.
The Columbia crew was informed of the blow but told not to be concerned.
As a result of the reforms initiated by the investigation, future shuttle launchings will be tracked by dozens of ground and airborne cameras.
The spacecraft's heat shield will be inspected thoroughly after liftoff.
If there is critical damage, the crew of a crippled shuttle will take refuge on the international space station until a rescue mission can be launched.
The task group characterized the recommendations that NASA has been unable to fully satisfy as the most difficult established by the investigation board.
The space agency has focused most of its recovery effort on the elimination of fuel-tank debris.

In late April, Griffin delayed plans to launch the shuttle in mid-May in order to initiate a new round of efforts to cut the threat posed by ice that forms on the chilled fuel tank from moisture in the Florida air.

Space agency experts said Friday that those efforts have significantly cut -- but not eliminated -- the possibility that flying ice might strike the edge of a shuttle wing or slice into a seal around the landing-gear doors on the underside of the spacecraft.
More analysis is under way, and the space agency is devising new criteria for the inspection team that will scan the shuttle for ice just before liftoff.
If inspectors find large deposits of ice in a new worry zone, the countdown would likely grind to a halt.
Late last year, the space agency acknowledged difficulties in devising repair tools and techniques that could withstand temperature extremes and the vacuum of space.
The crews of the next two shuttle missions will carry experimental repair kits.
What's left for NASA is to put all of these things together ..and assess what they believe to be the residual risk before they fly."
NASA SET TO RETURN DISCOVERY TO SPACE ON JULY 13
NASA will return the space shuttle Discovery to space next month, after almost two and a half years on the ground since the loss of the shuttle Columbia, officials said Thursday.
This is a very major milestone on our path to return to flight, William Readdy, the associate administrator for space operations, said.
We said immediately after the accident that we would find out what happened, we would fix it and we would return to flying again.

If all goes as planned, the shuttle carrying Cmdr.Eileen Collins and her crew -- Jim Kelly, the pilot; Steve Robinson; Wendy Lawrence; and Charlie Camarda, all of the United States; Andy Thomas of Australia; and Soichi Noguchi of Japan -- is to lift off at 3:51 p.m. for a 12-day mission.
It is to carry 15 tons of supplies and equipment to the International Space Station.
During their time aloft, the crew members will test new procedures for inspecting the shuttle's fragile skin for damage and for repairing damage.
Three spacewalks are also planned, one involving the replacement of an ailing station gyroscope.
The decision to fly comes after more than two years of study and struggle since the loss of the Columbia and its crew of seven on Feb. 1, 2003.

The Columbia Accident Investigation Board, or CAIB, found that an errant piece of insulating foam had punched a hole in the shuttle's left wing during the launching, and the hole led to disastrous overheating during re-entry.
Since then, NASA has worked to reduce the sources of ice and foam debris.

But on Monday, a NASA panel led by two former astronauts concluded that NASA had not fully met the three most challenging of the accident board's recommendations, including the development of tile and panel repair kits and measures to eliminate all shedding of debris from the external fuel tank.
However, the report said, "the inability to fully comply with all of the CAIB recommendations should not imply that the space shuttle is unsafe."
Instead, the final report described the risks of space flight in the terms that NASA itself uses: "It is impossible to drive the risk to zero."
That theme was sounded repeatedly at Thursday's news conference.

As the years and the generations unroll, we will learn how to make it routine -- as we have done with airline travel after a hundred years.
So we have a ways to go.
The only flight that will ever be cleaner is the next one."
If someone wants more, they are going to have to find smarter humans.

When asked how he would celebrate the launching, Readdy said: "This isn't about weighing anchor -- this is about when Discovery is back in the harbor here at the Kennedy Space Center after a successful mission.
At that point there will be plenty of celebrating."
At the same time, the coming flight is one of a dwindling number for the aging shuttle.
President Bush has called for its retirement by 2010, and Griffin has said that the 28 trips initially planned to complete the space station will be cut back to as few as 15.
Now, he added, "They're going to try to manage the risk as best they can."
DEBRIS STIRS CONCERNS ON SHUTTLE SAFETY
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.

- Pieces of Discovery appeared to dislodge Tuesday during the first space shuttle launch since Columbia blew up 2F years ago, and scientists began studying photos to determine whether any of the debris will have an impact on a historic flight NASA hopes will rescue the US manned space program.

Early photos showed an inch-and-a-half piece of tile, or its covering, may have peeled off near the door covering the shuttle's nose landing gear, but NASA managers said late Tuesday afternoon that it was too early to tell whether the debris had compromised the shuttle's safety.
Debris falls off during every shuttle launch, although the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has worked to minimize it on Discovery.
The falling debris was more apparent this time because more than 100 cameras were trained on Discovery during liftoff and the early part of the flight.
Another piece of debris also appeared to fall off the external tank, according to video footage, but did not strike anything.
The shuttle also apparently struck a bird less than three seconds into the flight.
Insulating foam that fell off Columbia during liftoff pierced its heat shield and skin, later allowing hot gases into the shuttle during reentry.
All seven astronauts died in the ensuing explosion.
It's very early ...I don't have any conclusions, John Shannon, flight operations and integration manager, said in Houston late Tuesday afternoon.
We are seeing areas of the vehicle ...we have never seen before.

While engineers said changes to the shuttle design since the Columbia tragedy have minimized the chance that foam, ice, or other debris will fall off and damage the shuttle, NASA was unable to completely eliminate that possibility.
Engineers will now spend several days analyzing video and photographs from the cameras that were on the ground, in the air, and mounted on Discovery.
Astronauts also took pictures from the shuttle and will employ a robotic arm to inspect the outside of the craft.
It was unclear what will happen if NASA scientists discover the shuttle is damaged from falling debris.
In one scenario that has never been tested, NASA would have the shuttle crew wait in the cramped International Space Station for a rescue attempt by the shuttle Atlantis.

But the crew is also equipped with repair kits that include caulking guns and putty knives that they were going to test to determine whether heat-shield emergency repairs could be made in case of a puncture.
But NASA officials have previously indicated they do not want to attempt a real repair with the test kits, so it is unclear whether the kits might be used.

During the launch, the air rumbled and a wave of cheers went up at Kennedy Space Center as Discovery and its seven astronauts sliced through two puffy clouds and blue skies before disappearing for a 13-day mission to test new safety gear and deliver supplies to the space station.
More than 150,000 watched the fiery launch from nearby roadways and rooftops, marking the start of what NASA hopes to be a new era of confidence in space flight and more daring solar system travel.
Today, Mother Nature smiled on us and I think the Columbia crew smiled on us too, said NASA associate administrator William Readdy.
There was no hint of the fuel sensor problem that forced NASA to scrub a mission attempt nearly two weeks ago just a few hours before launch.
NASA has worked to minimize the risk to Discovery of falling ice and foam during launch, according to an independent advisory group.
But the space agency failed to fully reduce that risk - or make the shuttle's skin durable enough to resist such an impact.
Collins is joined by pilot Jim Kelly and mission specialists Steve Robinson, Andy Thomas, Wendy Lawrence, Charles Camarda, and Japanese astronaut Soichi Noguchi.
Laura Bush watched the launch at Cape Canaveral with Florida Governor Jeb Bush and about 2,500 other NASA guests.
NASA needs the shuttle to fly again to bring as many as 28 loads of cargo to meet the obligations it has to the space station.
The agency plans to retire the aging fleet in 2010.
Bush has called for a new space era, to put an astronaut back on the moon by 2020, and then launch a mission to Mars.
NASA is developing a new vehicle to get astronauts there, but agency officials said it would be irresponsible not to fix and then finish the shuttle program's mission.

NASA has made hundreds of modifications to make the shuttle safer, including the camera system, to ensure the agency does "not proceed out of ignorance," said John Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University and a member of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board.
There have been debris hits on every mission, he said.
If you saw something fall off it doesn't necessarily mean it hit the thermal protection system.
Along Florida's Space Coast - and across the country - adults and children wished the astronauts a safe journey.
Viewers of NASA's broadcast at the McAuliffe Challenger Center at Framingham State College, named for teacher-astronaut Christa McAuliffe, who died on the Challenger, gasped as the shuttle went off.
Each time the announcer ticked off the shuttle's speed - 2,000 miles per hour, 3,033 miles per hour, 17,000 miles per hour - the crowd muttered in awe.
Globe correspondent Adam Jadhav contributed to this report.
SHUTTLE PROGRAM A STUDY IN CHANGE AND STABILITY
Since the 1980s, the story of NASA's human spaceflight program has been like the space shuttle itself: a study in stasis and change.
The shuttles reflect decades-old design and show their age.

But those who maintain the shuttle, manage it and chart its trajectory and its future know that it embodies transition as well, with regular upgrades like the modern "glass cockpit" digital display that replaced antiquated dials.
Many of the people of the space agency have remained while much around them has changed.
And more changes are expected once the Discovery mission is done.
Weather permitting, Discovery was scheduled to land as early as 4:47 a.m. on Monday at Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

But the changes made at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration between the Columbia mission and that of the Discovery have never been more evident than they were late last week, when the mission management team held its final discussion on whether to conduct a spacewalk to fix or remove a damaged insulating blanket near the commander's window on the Discovery.
An engineer spoke up to discuss the limitations of what the team knew.

While he did not voice deep concerns, he addressed differences between the degree of certainty that NASA requires for safety decisions before the shuttle can fly and those that take place during a mission.
Almost the entire management structure has been changed out, N.Wayne Hale Jr., the shuttle program's deputy manager, said to reporters last month.
But "the engineers that have the data, that have the real smarts that make the program work, are still in place."
Rocha is not the only familiar face on the Discovery mission.
The flight director for launching and re-entry is LeRoy Cain, who led the entry team on Feb. 1, 2003, when the shuttle Columbia broke up over Texas.

The world observed his grief-stricken face and businesslike manner, and heard his curt "lock the doors" command that signaled it was time to give up hope for the crew and to flip open the notebooks laying out procedures for shuttle disasters.
Cain said 2005 is not 2003.
We've learned a great deal about the vehicle, he said.
Since then, the NASA administrator at the time of the accident, Sean O'Keefe, has taken a job as chancellor of Louisiana State University.

William F.Readdy, a former astronaut who heads spaceflight operations, has said he will leave the agency after the Discovery flight, and more departures are likely as O'Keefe's successor, Michael D.Griffin, builds his own team.
At the Johnson Space Center, managers who ran the Columbia mission have departed or been reassigned.

Ronald D.Dittemore, the program manager at the time of the accident and a familiar face in the initial briefings that February, has left to become president of ATK Thiokol Propulsion, a shuttle contractor.

Linda Ham, who led the mission management team for the Columbia and quashed requests for outside help in getting images of the shuttle in flight, has been assigned to a less prominent role in the engineering directorate at the space center.
(Her husband, Kenneth T.Ham, is involved with the Discovery mission; an astronaut, he serves as Capcom, or capsule communicator during liftoff and landing.)
Dittemore and Linda Ham declined requests for interviews.

Ralph Roe Jr., who led the shuttle program office of vehicle engineering during the Columbia mission and whose part in turning down the imagery requests was described in the Columbia accident investigation report, was appointed to lead a new office at NASA's Langley Research Center devoted to providing independent safety analysis to the agency, a direct response to the accident.
(BEGIN OPTIONAL TRIM.)
Few on the current management team have spoken more often about the aftereffects of the Columbia accident than Hale, the deputy manager.
In 2003 he was manager for launch integration at Kennedy Space Center and was among the first to pass along Rocha's request for images of the shuttle.
His role was described in the final report of the Columbia Accident Investigation Board, known as CAIB.

The Columbia team had a small group of contractors use software for assessing damage that was inadequate to the task; it had been designed to measure foam debris hundreds of times smaller than the 1.67-pound hunk that blasted through the Columbia's wing.
We're operating from a position base of knowledge, he said, "rather than some sort of guesstimate."
This has led to longer discussions of damage and no small amount of hand-wringing.
But Hale and the other mission managers said that this was the inevitable result of having so much information, and that they would much rather have the data than not.
(END OPTIONAL TRIM.)

It should come as no surprise, McCurdy said, that NASA has retained people who shared responsibility for some of the Columbia mistakes, because changing personnel is not as important as fixing the underlying cultural problems.
You can bring a new person in, he said, "and they will operate in the same way if the system hasn't changed."
The tendency to keep people in the agency goes back to the earliest days of the American space program and conserves hard-won expertise.
McCurdy said that Wernher von Braun, one of the pioneers of the program, "had a history of leaving people who made errors in place, because he figured they'd never make the same error again.
But he also said, 'You make the same error twice, you're gone.'

The House majority leader, Rep.Dick Armey, warned on Thursday that an unprovoked attack against Iraq would violate international law and undermine world support for President Bush's goal of ousting Saddam Hussein.

``If we try to act against Saddam Hussein, as obnoxious as he is, without proper provocation, we will not have the support of other nation states who might do so,'' Armey told reporters in Des Moines during a campaign swing for a House candidate.
``It would not be consistent with what we have been as a nation or what we should be as a nation.''

President Bush has repeatedly stated that the administration's goal is to overthrow Saddam, in large part because of the threat Iraq's suspected programs to acquire chemical, biological and nuclear weapons pose to its neighbors as well as to American and allied forces in the region.
Armey did not directly address the issue of what the United States should do if it was determined that Iraq was continuing to build weapons of mass destruction.

Bush has carefully sidestepped the question of how and when the administration would accomplish its goal of ousting Saddam even as senior military commanders have presented options to the president and his top aides that range from invading Iraq with as many as 250,000 troops, to one involving 80,000 to 100,000 troops swooping in on Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, and other military centers in hopes of quickly collapsing the government.
Bush pledged this week that he would consult with Congress before ordering any invasion, but he stopped short of promising to ask for a vote authorizing an attack.
Leaders of Iraqi groups that oppose Saddam will meet here on Friday with senior State and Defense Department officials to discuss the policy to remove the Iraqi leader.

In Baghdad, Saddam organized a large military parade on Thursday to celebrate the anniversary of the end of the 1980-88 Iraq-Iran war, and then delivered a television speech in which he warned ``the forces of evil'' not to attack Iraq.
Saddam has refused to deal with U.N. weapons inspectors since they left nearly four years ago, and Iraq remains under U.N. sanctions imposed at the time it invaded Kuwait in 1990.

At the end of the 1991 Persian Gulf war, the lifting of those sanctions was linked to Iraq ending its programs of biological, chemical and nuclear weapons and the development of missiles to deliver them.

THE TOLL CASUALTIES WOULD TAKE ON WAR SUPPORT IS DIFFICULT TO
With Iraq war plans moving forward, an important unknown remains on the home front: The willingness of the American people to accept large numbers of dead or wounded soldiers.
Experts in Washington differ on whether high casualties would strengthen public resolve or turn opinion against the war.
Muddying the picture: The few casualties Americans have suffered in the nation's recent military excursions.
In the 1991 Persian Gulf War, in Kosovo and in Afghanistan, U.S. armed forces emerged remarkably unscathed, thanks to a combination of strength, training and technology.

As of mid-January, about 60 American fighters have been killed in what the military terms ``the global war on terror'' _ including a CIA operative caught in an Afghan prison uprising, a Marine downed in a drive-by shooting in Kuwait and a Green Beret hit in a Philippine restaurant bombing.
Only 18 of the deaths were classified as killed in action in Afghanistan.
The remainder died in aircraft crashes, accidents or incidents ranging from a drowning in Cuba to a lost helicopter crew in the Philippines.
Americans have reacted strongly when larger-than-expected casualties have been inflicted on U.S. forces.
In Vietnam in the 1960s, in Beirut, Lebanon, in the 1980s and in Somalia in the 1990s, public support for _ and official commitment to _ military operations began to fade when casualties mounted.

A Washington Post-ABC News poll last month showed that although more than 60 percent of respondents supported using force against Iraq, support dipped to 30 percent should the operation involve serious casualties.
Such bellicosity could prove as empty as Hussein's threat to ensure ``the mother of all battles'' in 1991.
But an invasion of Iraq would be vastly different than the Gulf War, which resulted in fewer than 150 combat-related deaths, experts warned.
The Persian Gulf War largely was fought in the open desert.

If the U.S. were to attack Iraq now, it is likely, as Hussein has threatened, that the elite Iraqi Republican Guard and Hussein loyalists would try to hold Baghdad, forcing street warfare on turf familiar to them.
The fear is that such fights could be akin to the Battle of Mogadishu, when 18 soldiers died and public support for the Somalia mission evaporated.
Then there is the increased threat of a cornered Hussein, who could turn to a cache of chemical and biological weapons.
American war planners understand such dangers, said Sen.Pat Roberts, a Kansas Republican and incoming chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee.
``A great deal of planning has gone into what we can expect and to avoid Somalia-times-1,000,'' Roberts said.
``We do not want to become engaged in urban warfare or put our troops into a contaminated area.
There's a lot of groundwork being laid to avoid those kinds of situations.''
Ultimately, public support will depend on how well the case is made that the war is in American interests.

``Research suggests the American public will support interventions even if they produce casualties, if there is a convincing justification for U.S. involvement,'' said David Auerswald, a professor at the National War College in Washington.
``Public support seems to drop off if elected officials have not made a convincing case, or if there's a significant debate between elected officials on whether this is worthwhile.''
World Wars I and II, and even the early days of the Korean War, were examples of casualty-heavy engagements that drew public support, Auerswald said.
On the other hand, the public doubt about Vietnam, Beirut and Somalia came after heavy casualties were coupled with decreasing public understanding of the point of the mission, he said.
``If you are expecting a significant number of casualties and you want to maintain public support, you have to make sure you have a good rationale,'' Auerswald said.
That could be a challenge for the Bush administration.
To prepare the American people for casualties might risk softening support, as polls show.
To ignore that casualties may occur could cause outsized expectations for a quick, easy war.

In a private meeting earlier this month between Senate Republicans and White House Chief of Staff Andrew Card, Sen.Kit Bond of Missouri urged the administration to more clearly _ and more frequently _ explain the links between Iraq and the al-Qaida terrorist network.
``I think the American people will stand behind President Bush even if the going gets tough,'' said Michael O'Hanlon, a defense policy expert at the Brookings Institution.
Even if Hussein uses his terror weapons and inflicts huge casualties, that could enhance support for the war, O'Hanlon said.
``If he uses them on our soldiers, people would see it as more likely that he would be willing to give them to al-Qaida in a terrorist attack,'' O'Hanlon said.
In 1990, during the buildup to the Persian Gulf War, similar concerns about the scope of potential American wounded abounded.
The war ended within weeks, with few casualties.
``No matter how strong you are, war is chaos.
You never know what's going to happen.''

U.S. MILITARY NEARS A GRIM MILESTONE IN IRAQ
It's a grim milestone that no one wants to see come about, but the United States is nearing 2,000 military deaths in Iraq.

With public opinion polls showing that a majority of Americans favor a partial or total withdrawal from Iraq 32 months after President Bush launched an invasion to oust Saddam Hussein, experts and advocates disagree on whether the looming benchmark will further erode public or congressional support for the war that the president promises to continue until a successful conclusion.
As of Friday, the official Defense Department tally of Americans killed in Iraq stood at 1,983, while the unofficial Web site Iraq Coalition Casualty Count put the total at 1,992.

BUSH CAMPAIGNS TO SELL WAR IN IRAQ

President Bush has launched a marketing blitz to overcome public concerns, Democratic criticism and Republican worries about the war in Iraq and the broader U.S. campaign against Islamic terroism that has lasted longer than World War II.

FIRST SUSPECTED CASE OF MYSTERY ILLNESS IDENTIFIED IN VALLEY(a)
(For use by N.Y. Times News Service clients)(a)
By KERRY FEHR-SNYDER(a)c.2003 The Arizona Republic(a)
(PHOENIX) - The state's first suspected case of SARS, a mysterious pneumonia that is sweeping the globe, has been identified in the Valley.
Maricopa County health officials said the patient is a man who had traveled recently through Hong Kong.
He was hospitalized with symptoms of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, and is expected to be released soon from a hospital and to be isolated at home for up to 10 days.
Health officials declined to release the man's name or any other identifying information.
They also would not identify the hospital where he is being treated.

Jonathan Weisbuch, Maricopa County director of public health, said, ``The general public does not appear to be at risk for infection,'' but he warned residents to seek medical attention if they exhibit any SARS symptoms.
The highly contagious disease is characterized by a dry, unproductive cough with a fever of 100.4 or higher and is believed to affect individuals who have recently traveled to China or Vietnam.
As of Monday, 17 countries have reported 2,601 cases of SARS, with 100 deaths.
Cases of the disease are still on the rise.
In the United States, 115 cases in 29 states had been reported to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as of Friday.
By Monday, the number had grown to 141 cases, according to the World Health Organization.
No deaths have been reported in the United States, although SARS patients have died in Canada, China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.

For the past several weeks, state and county health officials have investigated 17 suspected cases of SARS, said Dr. Larry Sands, Maricopa County medical director for the division of epidemiology and biodefense preparedness and response.

None except the case reported to CDC officials Monday turned out to be the syndrome; those were cases of other types of respiratory ailm perform sophisticated laboratory testing, including using electron microscopes and genetic screens of the virus, Sands said.
He added that he does not know the timetable for when the tests will be completed.
SARS cases surround Arizona geographically, with California reporting the largest number for a single state.
But Dr. Robert Baron, co-director of the emergency department at Good Samaritan Regional Medical Center in Phoenix, urged residents to take the news in stride.
``We can't think that every time someone gets a fever right now they have SARS,'' Baron said.

Instead, individuals must have a travel history to China or other affected areas or they must have had close contact with someone who has been in the affected areas to meet the case definition set by the World Health Organization and the CDC.
Dr. John Shufeldt, an emergency department physician at St.Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in Phoenix, said he recently had a patient who met the SARS case definition.
But a chest X-ray and other tests revealed the patient did not have SARS.
``You just know by the severity of the symptoms and how quickly they advance,'' he said.
But he also said that if more suspected SARS cases appear in the Valley, the disease could strain hospitals and physicians.
``If it hits outbreak status, everyone will think they have SARS,'' he said.
``It's going to be tough to diagnose.''
IN HONG KONG, INFECTED MAN'S ITINERARY RAISES TRAVEL FEARS

In a striking example of how far and fast a virus can be carried in an era of international jet travel, health officials announced here on Thursday night that a man infected with a new respiratory disease had flown from Hong Kong to Munich, Germany; Barcelona, Spain; Frankfurt, Germany; London; Munich again; Frankfurt again and then back to Hong Kong before entering a hospital.
The Hong Kong Department of Health appealed Thursday night for passengers and air crews from all seven flights to contact medical professionals.
A Health Department spokeswoman said that it was not yet known whether the man, who is 48, had infected anyone else on the flights with SARS, the severe acute respiratory syndrome.
All of the flights were on Lufthansa.

The airline said in a statement Thursday night that it had disinfected all of the airplanes and was contacting the air crews and passengers, and contended that the likelihood of anyone becoming infected during the flights was ``very remote.''

But according to the health department here, at least 13 people have fallen sick with SARS so far after they shared a flight from Hong Kong to Beijing last month with an elderly man who had become infected with the disease while visiting his brother in a hospital here.
Thursday night's appeal for the Lufthansa air crews and passengers to come forward follows nearly a dozen such appeals by health officials and airlines operating flights in and out of Hong Kong.
Travelers have continued to board planes while feeling unwell despite strenuous warnings from the World Health Organization and national health agencies that they not do so.

In the case announced Thursday night, the man flew on Lufthansa flight 731 on March 30 from Hong Kong to Munich, and traveled on the following day on flight 4316 to Barcelona, ac!ording to an itinerary released here by the Health Department.
The man then developed symptoms while in Barcelona.
He then traveled on flight 4303 to Frankfurt on April 2 and on to London the same day on flight 4520.
He went to Munich the next day on flight 4671, then headed for Frankfurt on April 4 on flight 265.
He connected with flight 738 the same day back to Hong Kong, arriving on April 5.
The man checked into a hospital here on April 8 and was confirmed on Thursday to have SARS.
Doctors do not yet know how infectious, if at all, people are in the early stages of SARS.
Increasingly, doctors are suspicious that some people may be able transmit the disease before the symptoms begin.

Dr.Yeoh Eng-kiong, Hong Kong's secretary for health, welfare and food, warned Thursday night that doctors here had become infected from people who had not yet shown the full symptomsO identified by the WHO.
Yeoh suggested that even someone with diarrhea alone could be infectious.
The sick man's nationality was a mystery Thursday night.
The Health Department statement did not identify it at all, while the airlcompany had only been told by the Health Department here that the man was Chinese.
The Health Department spokeswoman said that the man seemed to be of Chinese descent but that the agency had been unable to determine the man's nationality.
``He travels a lot,'' the spokeswoman said.
``We don't know his passport.''
Hong Kong still issues separate passports from mainland China, a legacy of its days as a former British colony.
(END OPTIONAL TRIM)
The infected man's odyssey could not come at a worse time for Hong Kong, as countries have begun limiting the entry of people traveling from here or imposing quarantines on them.
Malaysia stopped issuing visas on Thursday to practically all holders of Hong Kong and mainland China passports.
Cathay Pacific Airways, Hong Kong's main airline, announced Thursday night that it had suspended all flights to Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur airport because there were very few passengers left.
(BEGIN OPTIONAL TRIM)
Singapore also imposed on Thursday a 10-day quarantine on all foreign workers earning less than $24,000 a year who have recently been in a SARS-affected country or territory.
Employers must pay all costs of the quarantine.

Singapore has been trying for years to lure high-income expatriates in financial services and other lucrative industries, while making it harder for lower-income workers to immigrate and do jobs that less-educated Singaporeans might otherwise do.
Hong Kong's economy depends heavily on its role as Asia's transportation hub, the place from which businesses can control and coordinate factories and other businesses spread across the continent.

Hono kkng has the world's busiest container port for sea freight, the world's busiest airport for international air cargo shipments and what was, until recently, Asia's busiest airport in terms of international air passenger departures.
(END OPTIONAL TRIM)
But the av!ilbility of flights here is withering as many governments have warned their citizens not to visit and many businesses have ordered their employees not to travel here.
Cathay Pacific has canceled a quarter of its daily flights here.
Dragonair, an affiliated carrier that dominates passenger travel from Hong Kong to cities in mainland China, has stopped operating almost half its flights.
Continental Airlines canceled its daily, non-stop flight from Hong Kong to New York earlier this week for lack of passengers.
The Airport Authority here said that a third of all flights originally scheduled to operate on Thursday had been canceled for various reasons.

Health officials have said that the virus causing SARS can probably survive no more than several hours outside the body, so that air and sea cargo shipments from Hong Kong, as well as mail, do not pose a risk to recipients.
HOUSTON MALL HIT BY FEARS OF SARS
There's the tale of the seafood chef who died from SARS.
Some say an elderly woman at the shopping center succumbed to the flulike disease.
Others say city health authorities are shuttering the place because it's contaminated.
Scary stuff _ except none of it, upon investigation, appears true.
``We've been hearing those same rumors,'' said Kathy Barton, a spokeswoman for the Houston Department of Health and Human Services.
``I think there is a great deal of panic.
I think there also may be a little bit of ...
competitive rivalry going on (between shopping centers).''

Although no one in the United States has died from the mysterious pneumonia from southern China, and Texas has only five suspected casesl nxiety about severe acute respiratory syndrome is unnerving people in Asian shopping districts throughout the country.
In some cities, tourists and diners are staying away.

Hong Kong City Mall, the biggest shopping center in Houston's New Chinatown, on the southwest side, seems to be a particular focus of gossip _ perhaps because of its name, some speculate, or because of business competition from older shopping centers such as Diho Square.
``Oh, your office is open?'' callers ask Dawn Lin, an attorney whose office is on the second floor of Hong Kong City Mall.
``I thought they closed down the whole mall,'' they say.
Worldwide, there have been 2,890 SARS cases and 116 deaths.
There are 166 U.S. cases in 31 states.
There is no treatment for SARS and about 95 percent of those who get the disease recover.
Symptoms ibreath.
Health officials have attempted to put the SARS threat in perspective, pointing out that the ordinary flu kills an estimated 20,000 Americans each year.
They also stress that SARS doesn't appear out of nowhere.

``We would have no reason to expect a chef out of the clear blue sky to be sick without the critical ingredient: foreign travel,'' said Barton, adding that secondary cases have been transmitted to family members and health care workers, not people encountered in a casual setting like the grocery store.
In addition, someone sick with SARS would not likely go unnoticed, Barton said.
Once the high fever and difficult breathing kicked in, an infected person would go to the hospital where doctors are on the lookout for SARS.
If the person's travel history checked out, he or she would be added to the list of suspected cases.
At that point, city health investigators would track down other people potentially infected by the patient.
``We would make some attempt to warn people, or alert people who might have had infectious exposure,'' Barton said.
Nevertheless, the gossip`peSsists.
Gerald Wu, 25, who was sipping a tapioca tea drink at Diho Square on Bellaire Boulevard, said some of his co-workers told him they are avoiding Chinatown for now.
He said immigrants with a distrust of government in their native countries may be fueling conspiracy theories about SARS deaths in Houston.
Indeed, business at the Hong Kong City Mall has been slow this week.
One restaurant owner reported a higher number of customers taking their food to go, rather than eating there.
``I don't know if it's the economy, the war or SARS,'' said a banker.
On Thursday, Lin was eating in a restaurant when she heard someone cough.
These days, such a sound puts her on instant alert.
``I turn my head and hold my breath and walk as far as I can without breathing,'' she said.
Lonnie Han, who works in a cell phone kiosk in the mall, is skeptical that a SARS outbreak at the mall would remain cloaked in secrecy.
Nevertheless, she is taking extra precautions against the disease by swabbing down her countertops with alcohol.
``It's just people.
People gossip like crazy,'' Han said.

IN HONG KONG, YOUNGER AND HEALTHIER VICTIMS SUCCUMBING TO SARS

The respiratory disease known as SARS is beginning to kill younger and healthier adults as well as older people here, as medical treatments are proving somewhat less effective than originally hoped, health officials said here ndrome _ had been largely people over 60, and often were those suffering from other health problems as well.

But eight people with the disease died here this weekend, and five of them were between ages 35 and 52 and did not have medical conditions that might have been contributing factors, said Dr.Liu Shao-haei, a senior manager of the Hong Kong Hospital Authority.
Canada and Singapore each reported three more SARS-related deaths as well.

But Liu said at a news conference here Sunday that a combination of ribavarin and steroids, while helpful for many, had not improved the condition of some patients, whose health has continued to deteriorate even after they entered intensive-care units.
``Some of the patients respond well to treatment and some do not,'' he said.

Efforts to harvest serum from patients who have recovered from the disease and inject it into those still suffering, in the hope that the serum will contain antibodies, have run into safety problems, Liu said.
He declined to identify the safety problems, but he said serum was only being used on a limited and experimental basis while the problems were investigated.
The disclosures came as President Hu Jintao of China came to Shenzhen, the mainland Chinese city that abuts Hong Kong.
He met with Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, and the leaders of Guangdong province, which includes Shenzhen, on how to curb the spread of SARS.

The government of Hong Kong, a fairly autonomous region of China since its handover by the British in 1997, said in a statement Sunday night that President Hu of China had ``pledged the full support of the central government'' in areas like the provision of protective gear for medical workers.
This can be dangerous because the respirators become heavily contaminated with viral particles and therefore dangerous to touch.

Cathay Pacific Airways, Hong Kong's dominant carrier and Asia's fourth-largest airline, said Sunday it was carrying only a third of the passengers that it had a year ago, and had canceled 42 percent of its flights.

Two airline officials said over the weekend the airline might have to ground its fleet if`trffic declines further, but Rosita Ng, an airline spokeswoman, said Sunday night that there were no such plans.

Dr.Lam Ping-yan, Hong Kong's deputy director of health, acknowledged another problem at Sunday's news conference with Liu when he said that ``quite a number'' of people had been arriving in Hong Kknw"and immediately seeking medical care for SARS.
There had been scattered reports of SARS-infected people from mainland China entering hospitals here because Hong Kong has a better medical system.
But Lam did cite encouraging evidence that, as in mainland China, children here seem less affected by the disease than adults.
The World Health Organization said Friday that SARS had hit Hong Kong harder than anywhere else, for reasons that remain unclear.

Including 42 new cases reported Sunday, Hong Kong has three-fifths of the world's current SARS patients, with 887 patients still in hospitals while 40 have died and another 223 have recovered and been discharged from hospitals.
But there have been questions raised about the veracity of mainland China's figures.
China has reportwt fwinter, plus 60 who died.
There has also been some debate here over the Hong Kong government's use of a fairly narrow definition for who has SARS.
The government only counts people with pneumonia symptoms and does not count people who may have been exposed to SARS carriers and become somewhat ill but whom do not show pneumonia symptoms.
Liu, of the Hong Kong Hospital Authority, said at the news conference on Sunday that Hong Kong believed its definitions were consistent with international standards.
REPORTED CASES OF VIRUS JUMP SHARPLY IN CHINESE PROVINCE

Reported cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome rose sharply on Monday in an interior province of northern China, heralding the possible spread of the disease through the country's vast, medically underserved hinterlands.
A report last week that 32 people in Shanxi province, a region of coal mines and factory towns, had been diagnosed with the disease, known as SARS, had already raised concerns among health experts.

The disease, which has been fatal in about 4 percent of cases, has been concentrated in the prosperous, urbanized southeastern province of Guangdong and in neighboring Hong Kong, with small numbers of cases appearing in other Chinese cities.
The worry deepened on Monday when the ministry of health, in its daily update to the World Health Organization, said 47 more cases had been reported from Shanxi on Sunday.
``We're very concerned about what may be happening out in the provinces,'' Henk Bekedan, director of the WHO office here, said in an interview.
The Shanxi cases are concentrated in the provincial capital of Taiyuan, where SARW gcs apparently introduced several weeks ago by a traveler returning from Guangdong.
The new figures bring reported cases in the Taiyuan area to 79.

This is a small number in a metropolitan region of 3.3 million, but it is more than double the 37 cases reported as of Monday here in Beijing, the capital, with a metropolitan area population of some 14 million.
Public fears are being expressed here that the government says are overblown.

Nationwide, China now has reported 1,418 cases of the disease, with 64 deaths, of a worldwide total of 3,619 cases and strong new concern about SARS and called for greater openness and stronger control measures.

He did not describe the disease as ``under effec4mvT"control'' _ as senior health officials had last week in an effort to reassure the public and head off the mass cancellation of foreign tourist and business visits to Chinan
Bekedan said the surge in Shanxi might reflect a natural second wave of infections, as the initial patients exposed others before they were diagnosed and isolated.
What happens next will depend on the effectiveness of control measures introduced by local officials.
Reached by telephone, officials at the national health ministry and the health departments of Shanxi province and Taiyuan city all declined to comment on the increasing caseload in Shanxi.
The ministry is to issue new national data on Tuesday.
Adding to the concern of health experts are the often substandard quality of health facilities and surveillance in much of interior China.

Millions of workers from the relatively prosperous coastal areas made trips home to these interior provinces during the lunar new year holidays in February _ just when the epidemic was reaching a peak in Guangdong.
``Our assumption is that most of China's provinces will have cases,'' Bekedan said on Monday.
Second to Shanxi in reported cases, among the inland provinces, is Inner Mongolia, which as of Sunday had reported 17.

Smaller numbers of cases have been detected in several other provinces, but the vast majority of victims are still in Guangdong, with more than 1,250 reported cases though a declining curve of new victims.

But by the end of the fourth day of what is planned as a six-day mission, the investigators had still not gained access to any of the city's military hospitals, apparently because of foot-dragging by military administrators who are not under the health ministry's-hat the city's military hospitals alone might hold 100 SARS patients.
City and military officials have denied this.

But it appears unlikely that the team, in the short time planned for this visit, can allay public skepticism about the true extent of SARS in Beijing, especially because the government has so far refused to provide data on suspected cases and people who are quarantined for observation.
Scores or hundreds of people, some experts guess, may be in isolation in hospitals now, possibly helping to explain the rampant rumors and conflicting accounts.
Health experts are also worried by the coming May 1 holiday, when many Chinese normally take trips.
In recent years, the government has extended the holiday to a full week and encouraged travel in hopes of stimulating the economy.
The widespread movement of people, uspecse contact with sick people, including the inhalation of droplets from their coughs.
So far, no campaign has been mounted to discourage travel, even to and from the center of infection in Guangdong, or to require the screening of passengers for fever and other signs of illness.
In Hong Kong, health officials said on Monday night that there had been 40 more cases in the Chinese territory, and seven more deaths.

The number of deaths in Hong Kong has jumped lately, but Dr.Ko Wing-man, the acting chief executive of the Hong Kong Hospital Authority, said at a news conference that it was unclear whether the mortality rate had risen or whether there were simply more patients infected with the disease.
SARS SPREADS WORRY IN CALIFORNIA

In her cramped herb and acupuncture shop in the heart of Chinatown, Emmelyn Chu proudly says she has cured everything from acne to colon cancer with her tiny needles and her concoctions of dried plants and roots.
But there's one disease she admits she can't cure.
It's the one on most people's minds here: SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome.
``We don't even know (enough) about this one yet,'' Chu says in a combination of English and Chinese.
``I can't cure.
But I can prevent.''
Since it was recognized in Asia in February, SARS has spread to big cities and rural towns in 25 countries around the globe.
In the United States, no place has seen more suspected cases than California.
As of early Friday, health officials were tracking 47 cases in California, almost double the cases in the next-highest state, New York.
Ten of the California cases are in Los Angeles County.
Given California's close Asia ties, it's surprising there aren't more suspected cases of SARS in the state.
``When you look at the rate ...California really isn't far out of step with rest of the country,'' said Dr.Marc Romney, an epidemiologist with the California Department of Health Services.
Partly as a result, health officials here aren't doing much different than their peers in other states as they try to contain the disease.

Quarantine areas at airports in Los Angeles International and San Francisco have increased in importance after an American Airlines flight from Tokyo was detained and isolated in San Jose this month over SARS concerns that later proved to be false.
Pamphlets about the disease are printed and distributed in Asian languages in Asian communities.
The biggest impact from SARS has been to California's struggling economy.
California's airports are hubs for flights to Asia.
Its shipping ports handle the vast majority of the goods imported from and exported to Asia.
And its companies, from Silicon Valley tech firms to Southern California auto manufacturing plants, have more ties to Asian partners than most businesses elsewhere.
The pain has trickled down in the biggest state economy in the nation.
Companies such as Intel Corp.and Hewlett-Packard Co.are limiting tr#vel to Asian factories and suppliers that help make their goods.
Airlines such as Cathay Pacific and United Airlines, as a result, have cut flights.
Suppliers to those airlines and manufacturers have scaled down in turn, sometimes laying off workers.
The downturn has had a major impact on California's economy at a time when it was already suffering, says Jack Kyser, chief economist for the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corp.
If the SARS outbreak and fears surrounding it continue to grow, it could prompt consumer fears that Asian goods might spread the disease _ something researchers say is unlikely.
``We've sort of already written off all the tourism and business travel from Asia,'' Kyser says.
``Now for other businesses, we're watching very carefully.
We've basically got our fingers crossed.''
Small businesses with an Asian flavor are being hurt as badly as big companies.
In San Francisco, where 30 percent of the population is Asian, restaurants have lost business on rumors that their employees were infected with SARS.
Tourism was already sufferinw12se isn't contained soon, visitors bureau officials say, it could deepen the impact on one of San Francisco's biggest industries.
(Story can end here.
Optional add follows.)

In places like Los Angeles' Chinatown, meanwhile, customers are flocking to shops like Emmelyn Chu's to get special combinations of herbs and other Chinese medicines that purportedly help prevent the disease, often bringing in recipes from doctors back in China.
Few here wear surgical masks like their friends and family in China and elsewhere, but patients line up five and six deep in some shops to wait and see herbalists.
Ginseng sales are better than usual.
For some here though, there's no debate.

ANALYSIS: DISEASE PUTS WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION TO THE TEST
The World Health Organization has said that SARS is over in Vietnam and waning in Hong Kong, and on Tuesday it said it would rescind the warning against travel to Toronto.
Responding to the first favorable news about severe acute respiratory syndrome since the U.N. agency issued a global health warning on March 12, the markets in Hong Kong are rebounding.

But the pronouncements raise questions about the degree of confidence anyone can have in making predictions about the course of a new disease _ a disease about which, as the WHO is the first to acknowledge, so little is known.
``We are sailing a boat while we are building it,'' Dr.Klaus Stoehr, the scientific director of the WHO's SARS investigation, said in an interview.
The WHO has no regulatory or police powers and trusts countries to report honestly to it.

Among other things, the teams also teach proper infection control in caring for patients in hospitals; obtain specimens from patients; and send the specimens to an international network of laboratories that the WHO has created for SARS.

But no one knows how fully the measures traditionally used for known diseases will apply to thIon Monday the WHO declared Vietnam the first country to have stopped its outbreak of SARS (though the agency cautioned that new importations might occur).
In so doing, it relied on a time-honored rule of thumb: An epidemic has ended if no new cases occur in a time span double the longest incubation period.
But among the many unknowns about SARS is for how long someone can transmit the SARS virus after becoming infected.
The WHO uses a 20-day period: twice the 10 days that is the longest known interval between exposure to the virus and onset of symptoms.
Yet the incubation period may have been as long as 13 days in one case.
If 26 days turns out to be a more accurate time span for SARS, then the WHO will adjust accordingly, said Dr.David L. Heymann, who is in charge of communicable diseases for the WHO.
``We are applying what we know and going on what has been observed, although not everything may have been proved,'' Heymann said on Tuesday.
``It has worked so far, and we will adjust if the situation changes.''
Heymann doubts that many such cases have been missed.
``We have been investigating rumors of such cases every day,'' he said, ``and we have not had any cases that could not be traced back to a severe case.''
The biggest handicap is the lack of a reliable diagnostic test for SARS.
The WHO's actions have been generally applauded.
But it became embroiled in controversy last week when it added Canada to its list of areas that people without urgent business should avoid.
Heymann said the decision was based not on politics but three criteria that the agency has set to determine whether to include an area in a travel advisory.
One is the magnitude of the SARS epidemic in a country.
The WHO will list countries that have 60 or more active cases or that have an average of five or more new cases each day in the preceding three days.
Many SARS cases have occurred among health care workers, patients and visitors in hospitals.
So the WHO's second criterion is to list areas where there is community spread, defined as transmission outside of hospitals.
Third, countries are listed if they have exported cases elsewhere.
Heymann said Canada was being removed because it had not exported cases since April 3 and community transmission stopped on April 9.
``We should have issued the travel advisory for Canada a week earlier'' than the WHO did but did not because the agency could not obtain information it needed until after Easter, Heymann said.
``We are often asked why are we doing what we are doing, and the answer is we have no choice,'' Heymann said.

Dr.Alfred Sommer, dean of the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health, said that ``if SARS remains endemic in only one country, the rest of the world will have to constantly guard'' against importations.
The biggest concern is that cases from China coUld0seed SARS through Asia, even Africa.
And the concern about China is the decline of the public health infrastructure over the last decade.
Many local doctors and health workers have moved to the cities and preventive services have suffered, Sommer said.
``The question is: Is SARS already endemic in China?'' said Heymann, who acknowledged that the WHO had not determined the criteria for declaring SARS endemic in a country.
It is not known whether SARS has a seasonal pattern like other infectious diseases and might appear in the Southern Hemisphere this winter.

``Let's not congratulate ourselves,'' Sommer said, ``if we believe the disease has come under control, if all it has done is gone into hiding because of seasonal changes,'' ready to strike again next winter.
IN VILLAGES, MUCH CONCERN AND LITTLE PREVENTION AGAINST SARS
Villagers like Wang Wenlan, who spends these days at home watching her twin grandsons, are accustomed to such neglect.
Nobody cares about us,'' she said.
``We have to take care of ourselves.''
Still, the village authorities allowed them back.
``We haven't let the kids play outside since,'' Wang said.
She said she wanted to buy some disinfectant, but the price was hiked too high.
The fqm)dy has no protective masks nor a thermometer.
She said the village had done nothing except hand out brochures and send a truck with a loudspeaker for a couple days last month to broadcast some announcements.
``We couldn't understand what she was saying,'' said Wang, sitting in the living room of her brick house under a large poster of Mao Zedong.
Preventing the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome in China's under-equipped rural areas has become the government's top priority.

A front page commentary Friday in the People's Daily, the Communist Party mouthpiece, said prevention of SARS in the countryside would determine the success or failure of China's struggle against the deadly disease.
Premier Wen Jiabao has promised free medical care for any rural resident diagnosed with SARS, which has infected nearly 5,000 people in China and killed more than 200.
Asked if he believed such promises, Wang's husband Cheng Guanglong replied: ``I believe the higher-ups, but when it comes to the lower level officials ...'' his voice trailed.
Corruption is almost a given in the countryside and confidence in the local government is low.
Getting China's vast rural population to cooperate and trust authorities will be crucial to containing SARS.
Many fled Beijing to their provincial hometowns in the last several weeks, some bringing the disease with them.
Local authorities are overwhelmed trying to identify and quarantine them.
The biggest victim of the mass exodus so far has been Hebei, a province of 67 million people which encircles Beijing.
More than 1 million workers and students have returned to Hebei, according to the state-run media.
It saw its first SARS case on April 19, and three weeks later, has 147 cases.
An expert team from the World Health Organization arrived in Hebei on Thursday on a five-day mission to investigate its prevention and control measures.
Villages outside Zhuozhou, a city in Hebei six miles from the Beijing border, were on high alert this week, with people at each village entrance stopping all visitors to take their temperature.
Workers returning from their jobs in Beijing are housed in a large tent for 14 days.
A local official said a number of cases have already been found.
When two foreign reporters arrived, Zhuozhou authorities were quick to react.
Despite the central government's self-proclaimed new policy of openness on SARS, the reporters were surrounded by police and escorted out of the province.
Breakneck growth along China's coastal areas has left its vast interior severely lagging in just about all aspects.
Its health care system has been especially neglected.
A government inspection team ly unprepared to deal with SARS.

The entire province has only 30 respirators and not a single hospital had suitable protective suits and goggles for medical staff, meaning an infected patient would likely cause a large outbreak among hospital workers, said the China Youth Daily.
Furthermore, although the central and provincial governments have allocated nearly $2 million, funding is still inadequate and local ic servants, the paper said.

Although Qinghai has not yet reported any ca;24:60 776 12060::2973:46294wYX[\Ye number of students and workers have already returned to the province and another 20,000 are expected in the coming days.
When market reforms started two decades ago, hospitals were made to rely increasingly on their own profits.
That left doctors open to bribes and hospitals were forced to make money by overcharging and overprescribing medicines and diagnostic tests.
Health care costs have grown by more than 400 percent in the last decade, said Ray Yip, a senior advisor to UNICEF in Beijing who has studied public health programs in China for five years.
Only 10 percent of peasants have any kind of health insurance.
Disease prevention has been an even lower priority than medical care.
China has more than 4,200 disease control offices with more than 200,000 staff, but funding is basically enough just to cover salaries, according to the official Southern Weekend newspaper.
There is little left for education, surveys or other investigations, it quoted a former health ministry official as saying.

Moreover, officials pay such little attention to disease prevention agencies, ``they are seen as a good place to put relatives and retirees,'' the paper quoted Jiang Qingwu, director of the school of public health at Shanghai's Fudan University, as saying.
Of Beijing's 5,000 staff at various disease control offices, not more than 50 have had official training and are qualified, said Hu Yonghua, director of Peking University's school of public health.
Two-thirds of the graduates of his school go to work overseas because the profession is so underpaid and undervalued in China, despite its desperate need for people with such training.
When it comes to health care, local governments prefer to spend funds on building hospitals or other facilities rather than on something invisible, such as a disease control network.
Still, the outlook is not completely bleak in China's countryside.
With a disease like SARS, prevention is still possible, making an inadequate health system less of an issue.
``You don't need high-tech equipment or skills.
You just need vigorous supervision and management,'' Yip said.
So I'm pretty confident in that regard.''

Scientists: New virus a potential epidemic

SARS could become a global epidemic if adequate control measures are not taken, two groups of scientists warned*Fr20 47074nfluential medical journal, but stringent control measures can stop the disease if deployed in time.
The papers, published on the Web site of the journal Science, appeared on a day of mixed news that underlined the continuing unpredictability of severe acute respiratory syndrome.
Five new SARS cases cropped up in a Toronto rehabilitation hospital, weeks after Canada's last case of SARS was recorded.
Two patients are in critical condition and one has tested positive for the virus that causes SARS, Ontario province health officials said.
Anyone who visited the hospital between May 9 and May 20 was asked to put themselves in home quarantine.

In response, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta renewed a travel alert for Toronto that it had dropped earlier this month, warning travelers to take extra precautions that include avoiding hospitals and practicing frequent handwashing.
Simultaneously, the World Health Organization dropped its long-standing advisory against travel to Hong Kong and Guangdong, China, the two hot spots for SARS in Asia.
There was no such good news for Taiwan, now the only place where SARS cases are known to be increasing.
The island nation reported an additional 55 cases overnight, bringing its total to 538 cases out of 8,117 worldwide.

Dr. Chesley L. Richards Jr., a CDC epidemiologist from Georgia who may have been infected with SARS while advising Taiwan on controlling its outbreak, boarded an air-ambulance flight in Taipei on Friday morning along with three CDC colleagues.
Richards wore protective gear _ gown, hair covering, mask and eye shield _ and walked onto the plane under his own power, the CDC said.
The plane, a Gulfstream small jet that normally holds up to 20 people, was expected in Atlanta on Friday evening or this morning, CDC spokesman Llelwyn Grant said.
All vour elowed to go home once they are checked by a CDC physician but will be monitored by the Georgia Division of Public Health.
Richards, an infection control expert who had been working in hospitals in Taipei, developed a low fever Monday, recovered, and then experienced a return of fever and cough on Thursday.
His condition did not change during the flight Friday, Grant said.

Richards will be placed in an isolation room _ a special hospital room rigged so that the air within it does not flow into the rest of the hospital _ and treated by employees in protective gear until his symptoms clarify, Grant said.
The CDC declined to say Friday in which Atlanta hospital Richards would be treated.
The agency has a long-standing but informal relationship with Emory University School of Medicine, which operates Emory University, Emory Crawford Long and Wesley Woods hospitals.
Emory University Hospital declined to say whether Richards would be treated there.
Both groups used mathematical models to predict possible spread of the disease.

WORLD MAY NOT HAVE SEEN THE LAST OF SARS VIRUS
The world may not have seen the last of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) virus.

There are concerns in the infectious-disease community that the recent outbreak was merely what some experts call a ``herald wave,'' and that the virus could come back with a vengeance for next winter's flu season.

Dr. Don Burke, a professor at Johns Hopkins University's School of Public Health, said ``if you accept the notion that a lot of respiratory viruses are seasonal, and decline with or without human intervention, you have to consider that when the environmental conditions permit, it could re-emerge.''
How will we know?
``Look very closely in the places it's persisting, like China,'' Burke said.
``Low-level transmission of mild SARS cases'' could still be going on in China today, he said.
``We need to use gene-amplification techniques to look for the SARS virus in respiratory secretions,'' Burke said.
``If there were only a few cases, that can be the final step to eradication.
If it's more serious, then we have a heads up for next season.''

``It's entirely possible that SARS is eradicated _ but if there were more than 10 active strains going on through the summer with minimal intervention and we did nothing, that's the worst possible outcome,'' he said.
``Wrmaceutical companies to develop tests to identify SARS,'' he said.
This cooperation paid big dividends when the United States combatted SARS.
``We coordinated on the state and local level and worked with non-traditional partners like the travel industry.''

MAJOR POWER FAILURE IN MUCH OF U.S. AND CANADA CAUSES DISRUPTIVE

A huge power failure swept through parts of the Northeast, Midwest and Canada on Thursday, causing blackouts, snarling t0affic, shutting down transportation systems and cellular phone networks and sending people pouring into the streets.

The series of blackouts began about 4 p.m. as lights, air-conditioning and transportation shut down in New York City and at least parts of New York state, northern New Jersey, Long Island and Connecticut.
There were also reports of wide power failures as far west as Detroit and as far north as Toronto and Ottawa.
In New York, Gov.George E. Pataki declared a state of emergency at 5:30 p.m. and deployed National Guard and the State Police to assist local authorities.
The cause of the power failure was still not clear late Thursday afternoon, but some information was available,

Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York City said he had been told by upstate authorities that the power failures were due to an overload on the Niagara Mohawk Power Grid, which supplies power to much of the Northeast and, according to a senior New York Police Department official, includes five states.

An official at the New York Independent System Operator, the consortium that manages the state's power grid, said officials had been told that the trouble started with a fire at an upstate power plant.
But there were conflicting reports about whether the plant is in the region of the Central Hudson utility or in Niagara Mohawk's territory.
Independent Power Producers of New York, the association that includes most of the plant owners, said it did not know the cause of the power failure.
Phone calls to the New York Power Authority, Con Edison and Niagara Mohawk did not go through.
The blackout created instant problems for transportation coordinators.
There were initial reports that airports were closed across much of the East late Thursday afternoon, and that controllers were busy rerouting flights.

The Homeland Security Department said it had received no requests for assistance from officials in communities affected by the blackout _ an indication that local government and emergency agencies were not overwhelmed.
On an afternoon that was hot and hazy across much of the East and Midwest, the blackout caused tens of thousands of people to pour into the streets in New York City.
Inbscenes no doubt repeated throughout the affected area, the city's wide avenues turned into rivers of pedestrians as people swarmed through gnarled traffic in streets devoid of traffic signals.
Calm largely appeared to prevail, though so did bewilderment and tension.
Many were at a loss as to how they were going to get home.
(BEGIN OPTIONAL TRIM)
``Right now the power outage is affecting all of our operations,'' a spokesman for the New York Port Authority told Reuters shortly after the blackout hit.
``We have no buses, no trains, no subways running.
'' But a couple of hours later, the Port Authority said buses were again beginning to run from its West Side terminal, offering hope of a hooeknming for thousands of commuters in New Jersey.
But for rail commuters headed to Long Island, propsects were dimmer.
A Long Island Railroad train was reported stranded under the East River.
(END OPTIONAL TRIM)
Regulators said the country's air traffic had been unaffected.
But finding a way home despite a near-total shutdown of the city's public transportation system was only one concern.
Another concern was terrorism, especially in New York, a city still feeling the effects and showing the scars of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
But officials at all levels of government said there were no signs that the blackout had been the work of terrorists.
There were no immediate reports of panic or looting.
Some public buildings were operating on emergency generators.
A spokesman for the New York Stock Exchange said the facility had lost no data from the power failure and that it would resume trading on Friday, under emergency power if necessary.

Thursday afternoon's series of failures recalled those of July 1977, when New York City was plunged into blackness on a sweltering summer evening, and November 1965, when a domino-effect string of power failures darkened lights, trapped people in elevators, stranded commuters and halted the engines of transportation across much of the East.
As Thursday afternoon wore on, a huge parade of people streamed across the Brooklyn Bridge, reminiscent of the exodus from Lower Manhattan following the Sept. 11 attacks.

Lines formed outside pay telephones as cell phones fell silent.
A man who managed to get a cell phone signal worried aloud into the phone about the potential for melting ice and rotting meat.
Marjorie Mitchell, 26, a bank worker in lower Manhattan who lives in White Plains, N.Y., said: ``I don't know how I am going to get home.
The trains are dead.
My cell is dead.

Lights flickered and dimmed in Albany, the New York state capital, a few minutes past 4 p.m., causing computers to shut d-wn in governpublic buildings at 5:13 p.m., telling all nonessential employees to exit with calm and make their way home.
(END OPTIONAL TRIM)
At least three cities on the shore of Lake Erie _ Toledo, Cleveland and Erie, Pa._ were among those hit.
Erie is the hometown of Tom Ridge, the secretary of Homeland Security.
Last year legilators rejected measures that would have provided money to update the nation's power grids.
Bill Richardson, the governor of New Mexico and a former energy secretary in the Clinton administration, told reporters on Thursday, ``We're a superpower with a third world grid.''
He added, ``We have not imposed harsh reliability standards on utlitities.''
President Bush was in Southern California on Thursday for a fundraising and had not commented as of early evening.

But mostly, New Yorkers focused on getting their lives back in order.

Odors were ripe because tons of spoiling food had been thrown out as residents and restaurants were forced to empty their refrigerators and freezers.
