FAILURE OF A LINE LED TO BLACKOUT, AN ANALYSIS SAYS

When an electrical transmission line sagged into a tree just outside Cleveland at 3:32 p.m. on Aug. 14, the events that would lead to the greatest power failure in North American history began their furious avalanche, according to the most extensive analysis of the blackout yet.
The failure of that transmission line was crucial, because it put enormous strain on other lines in Ohio.
Soon, the utility that serves southern Ohio, with its overloaded lines close to burning up, sealed itself off, creating in very real terms, an electrical barrier between southern and northern Ohio.

What happened next, by this account, was almost inevitable: To the north, Cleveland, starving for electricity, began to drain huge, unsustainable amounts of power from Michigan and then Ontario, knocking out more lines and power plants and pushing the crisis to the borders of northwestern New York.
First the New York system, acting to proteproblem: New York power plants, without anywhere to quickly send electricity not needed within the state, overloaded their own system.
That in turn quickly led to a general shutdown _ the last stage in the largest blackout in the nation's history.
That picture, based on large amounts of data from the utilities involved, was presented on Friday by Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a private energy consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass.

Two researchers at Cambridge Energy, Hoff Stauffer and Lawrence Makovich, presented their analysis at a conference as federal energy officials, other industry representatives and reporters participated by telephone and on the Web.
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission was represented by Pat Wood III.
Wood would not comment on whether he thought the specifics of the theory were correct.
When problems soar around the grid in seconds, as they did that day, Wood said, ``you need to make sure that the communication between the different regions can move similarly fast.''

Ellen P. Vancko, a spokeswoman for the industry group charged with preventing grid problems, the North American Electric Reliability Council, said the group had not seen the scenario and could not comment.
That assessment was echoed by the organization that carries out day-to-day management of the grid in New York.
He said a federal investigation just begun by the Department of Energy would give definitive answers.
``Our position is that the facts will come out,'' he said.
``Eventually it will all be there.''

In the days since power went off in eight states and southern Ontario and left tens of millions of people without lights and other necessities, some of the companies involved have made public their partial timelines of events and sometimes their theories about what led to what.
This attempts to say what really happened _ where it started and why it progressed.''
(STORY CAN END HERE.
OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)

The scenario also meshed with data released on Friday by American Electric Power, the southern Ohio utility that sealed itself off from the develop enormous flows in wires headed toward its region of Ohio.
Beyond that, American Energy officials said they would not discuss theories about the cause of the blackout.
But they did insist that they had been in extensive contact with officials with FirstEnergy, the utility whose lines were failing to the north, during roughly an hour of escalating trouble.
They did not describe the substance of that communication.
The prologue to the blackout occurred with problems that on a normal day would have been handled as part of the routine of moving electricity on the grid.
At 2 in the afternoon, one generator shut down at a power plant east of Cleveland that is operated by FirstEnergy.
About a half-hour later, American Electric says, it started detecting unusual activity in shared lines, events that led it to contact control rooms in the region.
From then on it was just a matter of where it would be.
Normally, procedures would have delayed sales of power or diverted them through other lines.
But those actions can require a half hour or more, according to various utility officials, and there was only about another half-hour to go before the troubles hurtled through the system.
But the severing of the two crucial Ohio lines was the equivalent of suddenly damming an onrushing stream: The flow had to divert to find a way to reach the Cleveland area.
The power did that by spilling around the barrier into Indiana, then into Michigan and finally back to Ohi/.

Within a few seconds, the modest amounts of power, around 200 megawatts, that was flowing from a utility in lower Michigan called the International Transmission Co., or ITC, soared to 10 times that amount.

At about the same time, the power that had been flowing from ITC to Ontario suddenly reversed, pouring still more electricity onto that part of the grid, while another Michigan utility began supplying power to the very same area in an effort to meet the demand.
The chain of events overwhelmed lines and power plants on the ITC system, and they all began shutting down.
By a little after 4:10, most of the system was out of service.

Shortly thereafter, the rapidly changing flows in Ontario created alerts or shutdowns of some kind in New York, though the details remain unclear, and the state sealed its border with Canada, according to the Cambridge Energy analysis.
One oddity in Cambridge Energy's reconstruction lies in its theory that it was the relatively low demand for power in New York state on Aug. 14 contributed to the last episode of the blackout.
In the past, of course, it has been the great demand for"pgver in New York that has produced problems.
As it happened that day, because the state had relatively light internal demands, it was exporting lots of power to Ontarin.
$But when the border was sealed, Cambridge Energy says, that large flow of power had nowhere to go and it sparked the abrupt New York shutdown.

(UNDATED) The recent massive blackout has recharged a debate about the wisdom of a trend among federal and state politicians to loosen the tightly regulated system that governed the electricity business in America for much of the 20th century.

Critics of federal and state laws that have partly deregulated the electricity industry say the changes have made power failures more likely because they replaced a system of closely regulated local power monopolies with a more complex, freewheeling system that emphasizes profits at the expense of maintenance.

Under the old system, local utilities ran all aspects of the electricity business _ producing, transmitting and distributing power _ but government regulators closely supervised their practices and profits.

The new laws, passed partly in response to complaints about rising ejebey costs from large U.S. companies, for the first time allowed competition among companies that produce electricity _ a move designed to lower prices.
Under deregulation, any company that produces electricity must be given access to transmission lines that once were reserved for monopolies.
``You hear people arguing that government wastes, government's inefficient.

``We estimate that we're spending roughly $3 billion a year to maintain and upgrade the transmission infrastructure,'' he said.

``One criticism you hear is that since deregulation, they've cut costs, or increased profits by lowering costs,'' he said.

They only had a rate case (in which they could ask to increase utility bills) every 10 years.

MIDWEST GRID CONSORTIUM HAD EARLY TROUBLE FIGURING OUT PROBLEM,

An important element in the blackout of Aug. 14 may have been the inability of the the consortium that controls the Midwest regional grid to learn for 64 minutes prior to the system's collapse about transmission line failures in Ohi and to adjust the system to compensate, the head of a Michigan electric company testified on Thursday.

But, the official added that the pace of events after the system began experiencing trouble made response difficult and that until the last few minutes, the line failures did not seem to be overloading the system.

In the second day of hearings held by the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Joseph L. Welch, chairman and chief executive of the International Transmission Co., said that his company's review of the records of a computerized regional system called the System Data Exchange, turned up nothing about the failure of seven separate transmission lines, most in the territory of FirstEnergy, in Ohio.
Utilities are supposed to report all failures to the System Data Exchange.

The president of the MISO, James P. Torgeson, did not address the issue directly but testified that in the minutes before the blackout, his dispatchers were speaking to FirstEnergy and trying to establish what was happening.
``We were seeing some things, and we were trying to confirm it with them what was going on, and we weren't getting the confirmation immediately,'' he said.
When a transmission line or a generating station goes out of service, flows of power on the grid shift, in ways that can cause overloads elsewhere in the system.
The change in electrical flows can also leave the system vulnerable to overload or collapse if one additional line or generating station fails.

Thus, said Welch, every time the system configuration changes, system dispatchers are supposed to recalculate the flows, and recalculate whether, in the system's new flow pattern, a single failure could cause a blackout.
``Every line on the transmission grid is supposed to be accounted for,'' he said.
But Torgeson, speaking to reporters after his testimony, said that his organization had not found any changes necessary until ``right before things broke apart.
'' And a spokeswoman for MISO pointed out that in the patchwork system of management and ownership of transmission lines, not all of the lines that failed were in MISO's territory.
Also on Thursday, FirstEnergy's top officials sought to cast doubt on the idea that they were at the center of the blackout.

Charles E.``Chuck'' Jones senior vice president of energy delivery and customer service at FirstEnergy said in a telephone interview that if the ``epicenter'' of the event was northern Ohio, then systems in that region would have been expected to fail.

But, he said, the neighboring systems, including American Electric Power, Dusquesne Light, and the Pennsylvania-Jersey-Maryland independent system operator, were not seriously affected, and that three-quarters of FirstEnergy's own customers were not affezation of the power transmission entities.
The council's president, Michehl Gent, said soon after the blackout that it appeared to originate with failures of power lines in FirstEnergy's system.

For two days, the House committee has held extended discussions about the difficulties of expanding the capacity of the transmission grid, but by most accounts, the grid does not appear to have been under any particular strain until very shortly before the lights went out.

And while many witnesses said they would prefer a stronger grid, Eugene R.McGrath, the chairman of Consolidated Edison, added that the system was usually less expensive and more reliable if the generating stations were close to the load centers.
New York state, seeking to increase reliability, requires that 80 percent of the New York City load be generated within the five boroughs.
McGrath and others asked that any national system of mandatory transmission rules allow local jurisdictions to augment those rules with even stricter requirements.
OHIO UTILITY'S ERRORS BLAMED FOR HISTORIC BLACKOUT
``This blackout was largely preventable,'' Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham said a news conference.
``However, once the problem grew to a certain magnitude, nothing could have been done to trevent it from cascading out of control.''
The task force said FirstEnergy violated four reliability standards set by the power industry.
It found that the initial cause of the blackout was three power lines that short-circuited Aug. 14 after heat caused them to sag into trees that First Energy had not trimmed.
Because computer monitoring systems at FirstEnergy were not working properly, operators at the plant didn't know about the downed lines until half an hour after the third line failed.
The instability in Ohio escalated into a surge in power demand that shut down more than 263 power plants in seven minutes, affecting 50 million customers in eight U.S. states and Canada.
Many customers were without power for days, and some places in Ontario experienced rolling blackouts for about a week.
Economic losses are estimated at $6 billion.

The task force's 134-page interim report also found that the Midwest Independent System Operator in Indiana, which oversees the region's power grid, also violated a reliability standard by using outdated data, preventing it from recognizing transmission problems developing in the region.
The reliability standards violated by FirstEnergy and the grid's overseers are voluntary measures set by the power industry, which is largely self-regulating.
Violations of the standards are not punishable by fines, and the task force said the utility broke no federal rules in the incident.
Enforceable reliability standards, such as those in the energy bill currently before the Senate, would help prevent future blackouts, said Abraham.
The company's lower levels of reactive power made the lines sag more than usual that day, said Joe Mosbrook, a spokesman for the nation's fourth largest investor-owned utility company.
While the report cited FirstEnergy for failing to maintain tree growth, Mosbrook said that the company is on a five-year tree trimming cycle, the industry standard.
He blamed the mountil the blackout.

Rep.Ed Markey, D-Mass., called the report ``a blistering indictment of management and operational failures at FirstEnergy'' and said the company ``should take immediate steps to replace its entire senior management.''
The interim report is only the first step in the joint international task force's job.
It will open up the report to comment in cities affected by the blackout and issue a final report next year.

BLACKOUT ANNIVERSARY: LIGHTS ARE ON BUT NOT MUCH ELSE HAS CHANGED
When a major power line goes dead in New York state, its ghost appears in Guilderland, N.Y.
At the control center of the New York Independent System Operator, specialists oversee the state's power transmission system.
A two-story-high schematic diagram covers one side of the room, with New York's major power pathways represented by multicolored lines.
A dysfunctional line turns into a string of colored lights.
During a recent visit, only a couple of lines were lit.
There was little to be concerned about.
On Aug. 14, 2003, however, the whole board was aglow.

That summer day, a power line in Ohio drooped into a tree, triggering a blackout that rapidly blanketed most of New York, Ontario, eastern Michigan and northern Ohio, and parts of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Connecticut and Vermont.
The blackout left an estimated 50 million people without power, and cost an estimated $4 billion to $10 billion in the United States.

Today, the cause of the blackout is known: mistakes and conditions that caused a cascading surge of power to sweep through the complex electric grid, prompting transmission lines and generators to shut down.
But a year later, many in the industry say that if the same thing were to happen, New York and other areas in the affected region still might be left in the dark.
Could we withstand exactly the same thing that happened last year? William Museler, president and chief executive of NYISO, said.
Maybe, maybe not.
While some specific problems have been corrected, the larger situation that allowed the blackout to take place still exists, several experts said.
One of the reasons the blackout spread was that problems in the Midwest went unfixed.
Standards for running the transmission system in New York are generally agreed to be the best in the country.
But as the nation's power grid becomes increasingly interconnected and interdependent, a glitch across a border can have a big impact across the system.
We are as strong as the weakest link in this whole interconnection of energy systems, said New York state Assemblyman Paul Tonko, a Democrat who chairs the assembly's energy committee.
Yet federal legislation to make standards mandatory and enforceable has stalled.
The transmission system is not robust enough to withstand major power swings, because over the years the amount the country has spent on the network has declined.
Meanwhile, demand for power has grown with the population and the proliferation of power-hungry technology.

The bottom line is, we're going to have another failure.
I don't know when, but we will.
There is a big focus on what's called "vegetation management," to make sure trees and plants don't interfere with electrical systems, he said.
The North American Electric Reliability Council, an industry reliability group based in New Jersey, has been conducting readiness audits of regional transmission controllers.
One of the problems last summer was a lack of communication among different transmission regions.
For example, NYISO had no idea what its counterpart, the Midwest Independent System Operator, was doing.
Today, NYISO and MISO have direct lines of communication, NYISO's Museler said.
And operators here have access to data from a larger area of the grid -- they can see beyond the boundaries of New York state, which lets them know about disruptions coming down the pike.
When the power line in Ohio touched a tree and cut out, the electricity began to flow through other lines, which in turn shut down from overload -- a pattern that would repeat again and again.
It should have been a very localized problem, said Ralph Fehr, an electrical engineering professor at the University of South Florida and a power systems expert.
The line was maintained by Akron, Ohio-based FirstEnergy Corp.

The U.S.-Canada Power System Outage Task Force, created by President Bush and former Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien to investigate the blackout, found that, among many other problems, the company lacked emergency blackout plans.
The North American Electric Reliability Council found that FirstEnergy and other institutions violated several of the council's reliability standards, but there are no penalties for that.

The massive energy bills that have been proposed -- and stuck -- inCongress for the past few years have included provisions that would give the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission power to enforce national standards.

The comprehensive bill, which encompassed ethanol subsidies and liability protections for makers of the fuel additive MTBE, passed the House last year but was filibustered, mostly by Democrats, in the Senate.
Some people mistakenly believe that the blackout was about not having enough electricity.
But on the day of the blackout, New York had enough extra generating capacity to power about 3 million homes.
Instead, it was partly about not having extra room to handle the power fluctuations that started in the Midwest.
Reducing the amount of demand can help buy time.
But the amount of power used in New York, for instance, has climbed each year, according to NYISO.
Any given blackout is caused by a trigger, he said.

A squirrel crawling into a transformer and getting fried.
A tree.
You can't control all the squirrels.
EXPERTS ASSESS DEREGULATION AS FACTOR IN '03 BLACKOUT

Twenty-five months after a blackout darkened cities from New York to Toronto and Detroit, the U.S. Energy Department and its Canadian counterpart held their first public technical discussion on the episode Thursday to talk about one factor widely considered to have been behind it: the deregulation of the electric system.

Markets allocate risk, they allocate capital, they provide price signals.
Markets do not have a conscience, they do not provide social policy, and they do not do things they are not paid to do.
For example, participants at the meeting said, utilities that once ran the system sometimes added transmission lines to increase reliability of electric power.

When they did so, their costs would be reimbursed through the regulatory process; now there is less incentive to take on such efforts, and several participants pointed out that in fact investment in transmission had lagged.
The blackout of 2003 began on Aug. 14 and in some places lasted more than two days.

A binational report issued three months afterward did not list deregulation as a cause, instead citing factors like failure to trim trees, train operators and install control systems that could have kept track of the status of all power lines and generators.
Much of the investigation leading to that report was managed by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the architect of utility restructuring in the United States.
The report called for a separate study -- it did not say by whom -- on the role of deregulation in the blackout, but that study has never been done.
One member of the panel, Jack Casazza, a 60-year veteran of the industry, said the changes had brought lawyers and MBA's to the head of these competitive companies, rather than engineers.

Others pointed out that information like a power plant's maximum capacity, and its state of repair on any given day, was now considered proprietary and so was not readily available to system operators, which manage regional power grids.

The North American Electric Reliability Council, whose members come from utilities, marketers, customers and federal agencies, said in a paper submitted for the meeting that the increased demands that deregulation's wider trading had placed on the transmission system "require the grid to be operated closer to its reliability limits more of the time than was the case in the past."
That requires better training and control equipment, said the group, which was founded after a vast blackout in the Northeast in 1965.
Still, not all the industry's changes have affected reliability adversely, participants said.
The energy bill signed into law by President Bush on Aug. 8 provides a mechanism for creating mandatory reliability rules.

The legislation allows the federal government to designate a private group, probably the North American Electric Reliability Council, as an official "electric reliability organization," with authority to set the rules.

But that group pointed out in its paper that while the designated organization would assess the adequacy of the system, it would not have the authority to require anybody to build a generating station or a transmission line.
MADRID SIGNALS TO EUROPE TERROR THREATS ON NEW SCALE

This weekend, many Europeans suddenly confronted the prospect that full-scale attacks by Islamic terrorists were no longer somebody else's problem, as they might have thought, but an immediate and mortal threat.

After Sept. 11, 2001, and especially during the fierce debates leading up to the Iraq war, many analysts say that the Europeans, though deeply sympathetic to the Americans after Sept. 11, did not really believe they faced the same danger.

But now after the bombings Thursday in Madrid that killed 200 people and injured 1,500, it seems likely that the differences will narrow, perhaps substantially, if Islamic extremists are found to be responsible.
If so, Europeans will also watch how politics plays out, both among th-from-behind victory of Spain's Socialist Party in the elections on Sunday may be a first sign of that.
The bombings in Madrid may bring a renewed sense of unity within the Western alliance.
Reports that al-Qaida bore responsibility, inconclusive as they were, overshadowed the final days of the campaign.

But other factors could be at work, including widespread discontent with the government's handling of the crisis, including what seems now a too-hasty effort to blame Basque separatists and to rule out the possibility of Islamic responsibility.
Meanwhile, Europeans were assessing how different their world looks from before the simultaneous bomb attacks in Madrid on Thursday.

The German government conducted an emergency meeting on Sunday of its security Cabinet, which includes Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder, several Cabinet ministers and senior security and police officials.

Afterward, the interior minister, Otto Schily, said Germany was asking for an emergency gathering of European interior ministers and their police and security chiefs to form what he called a ``common assessment'' of the terrorism danger and to ``coordinate how to respond.''
Schily spoke of ``a new quality of threat from Islamic terrorism in Europe'' if Muslims are found to be responsible in Madrid.

Europeans are not strangers to terrorism, having experienced it many times in past decades, perpetrated both by homegrown radicals, like the Italian Red Brigades or the German Red Army Faction, as well as by Middle East extremists.

But the sort of mass attacks on civilian targets seen by security experts as a new threat, larger in scale and more religiously inspired than previous terrorism, did not strike Europe with full force until last Thursday.
Italy, like Spain, was among the strongest supporters of the Iraqi invasion, and both countries have contributed troops to the postwar occupation.
Indeed, 19 Italians were killed in Nasiriyah, Iraq, last November in an attack that U.S. officials have attributed to al-Qaida.
If Islamic groups did cause the bombings in Madrid, Olimpio said, Yt!dians could put more pressure on their prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, to withdraw the Italian contingent.
SPANISH POLICE NAME PLANNER OF BOMBINGS
By DALE FUCHS
c.2004 New York Times News Service

MADRID - Investigators have identified a Tunisian man as the leader of the March 11 bomb attacks on commuter trains in Madrid, and a judge has issued arrest warrants for him and five Moroccans for murder, according to court documents released Thursday.

A Spanish High Court judge, Juan del Olmo, issued a European arrest warrant for Sarhane Ben Abdelmajid Fakhet as the ``leader and coordinator'' of the bombings that killed 191 people and injured more than 1,400.

The warrant said Fakhet ``raised awareness of jihad'' within his circle, and ``indicated specifically since 2003 that he was preparing a violent act in Spain as an expression of the aforementioned jihad.''
Del Olmo issued five other European arrest warrants: Mohammed Oulad Akcha, Rachid Oulad Akcha, Jamal Ahmidam, Said Berraj and Abdennabi Kounjaa, all of whom are Moroccans.
They have been charged with hundreds of counts that include murder, attempted murder and membership in a terrorist organization.

On Tuesday, Angel Acebes, the outgoing interior minister, said the investigation is focusing on the Moroccan Islamic Combatant Group, which authorities have linked to bombings last year in Casablanca that killed more than 40 people, including 12 suicide bombers.
According to the court documents, Ahmidam rented a house outside Madrid where the authorities say fingerprints, traces of explosives and other evidence in the March 11 attacks was found.
The warrants identified the rundown house, in the town of Morata de Tajuna, as the site where bombs were made.
The court documents said Berraj is linked to Fakhet, the suspected Tunisian leader, and is also believed to have met in Istanbul in October with three members of al-Qaida.
The other three men are thought to have stayed at the house with Ahmidam and to have helped obtain the explosives used in the bombings.
The six men named in the warrants have been missing from their jobs and homes since the day after the bombings, Interior Ministry and court officials said.
They had b the officials said.
Until now, the Spanish news media had widely reported that Jamal Zougam, a Moroccan, was the prime suspect in the bombings.
According to the Spanish daily El Mundo, he was recognized by passengers on one of the trains.
His fingerprints also appeared in the home where the bombs were prepared, investigators were quoted in the newspaper as saying.
Since the attacks, 24 people have been arrested, most of them Moroccans.
Del Olmo, who is investigating the bombings, has sent 14 of them to prison.
All of the suspects in the investigation have denied direct participation in the attacks.
LETTER SAID TO BE FROM AL-QAIDA THREATENS SPAIN
Investigators on Monday studied a letter purportedly from al-Qaida promising ``an inferno'' unless Spain withdrew its troops from Iraq and Afghanistan.
Meanwhile, the police reported the arrest of another suspect in the March 11 bombings of commuter trains in Madrid that killed 191 people and wounded more than 1,400.
In France on Monday, special forces rounded up 13 suspected members of a militant Islamic group thought to be behind bombings last year in Casablanca, Morocco.

After a tumultuous weekend, during which at least four suspects in the Madrid bombings blew themselves up, the newspaper ABC published in its Monday issue a Spanish translation of a letter written in Arabic that it had received by fax on Saturday.
It was signed Abu Dujana al-Afghani, who described himself as a member of ``al-Qaida of Europe.''

A videotape found two days after the train bombings had featured a man speaking in Arabic with a Moroccan accent who identified himself by that name and said he was the military spokesman of ql-Qaier said European Qaida operatives had demonstrated their strength on March 11 and with an unexploded bomb on rail tracks last Friday.
It said its truce with Spain was over, unless Spanish soldiers were withdrawn from Iraq and Afghanistan immediately.
If those demands are not met, the letter said, Spain will be converted into ``an inferno and your blood will flow like rivers.''
Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero, who was elected new prime minister days after the train bombings, has pledged to pull troops from Iraq unless the United Nations takes over the occupation force.
But he has also said he$fqtors sending more troops to Afghanistan.
Security forces remained on high alert Monday.
Army and municipal police forces reinforced Spain's national police and home guard officers at subway stops, train stations and other heevyny
dpafficked public buildings, Ibanez said.

In France, counterterrorism police officers conducted a series of raids in multiethnic suburbs around Paris early Monday, detaining 13 people with suspected links to the militant Moroccan Islamic Combatant Group.
The group is believed to have orchestrated suicide bombings in Casablanca last May that killed 45 people.
It is believed to have ties to al-Qaida and has become a focus of the Spanish investigation into the March 11 attacks.
Six of those detained were members of an underground cell of theobeanization that had been under surveillance by the police for several months, investigators said.

Among those arrested was Mustapha Baouchi, a Moroccan citizen thought to be the leader of the terrorist cell, according to a senior official with the Directorate for Territorial Surveillance, France's counterintelligence service.
The official described him as an ``Afghan veteran'' who received military training in Afghanistan in 1998 and 2000.
The official added that of those six, four are French citizens of Moroccan descent and two are Moroccan citizens, all in their late 20s.
Three suspects are wanted under an international warrant issued by Morocco, and may face extradition, he said.
The special forces also seized documents, but no weapons or explosives.
SPAIN ARRESTS 3 MORE SUSPECTS IN TRAIN BOMBINGS
(Dale Fuchs contributed to this article)
By MARLISE SIMONS
c.2004 New York Times News Service
MADRID, Spain - On its last day before turning over power to the Socialists, Spain's conservative government announced it had made three more arrests of suspected Islamic militants.

Interior Minister Angel Acebes, just hours from stepping down, said that the three new suspects included a Moroccan, an Egyptian and a Saudi citizen, all of whom had contacts with a presumed leader of the bombing attack.

The news came shortly after the Socialist Party leader, Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero, was officially endorsed by Parliament as Spain's next prime minister in a vote that gave his government a comfortable major}: worn in by King Juan Carlos on Saturday, also told Parliament that he will make his first trip abroad - to Morocco - ``in the coming days'' to improve ties with the Moroccan government.
Spain's neighbor to the south is the source of most of its migrant labor, and also the home country of 15 of the 21 suspects now behind bars in connection with the March 11 train bombings.

The bombs that shook Spain and the rest of Europe, killing 191 people and wounding more than 1,400, police said, are now largely thought to be the work of militants of the Moroccan Islamic Combatant Group.
This network, whose leaders trained in Afghanistan, has also been linked to suicide attacks in Casablanca in May 2003.
In the weeks following the attacks, cooperation between Spanish and Moroccan police has been close, according to Spanish investigators.

That, and the question of intelligence gaps and poor police coordination within Spain itself, has also occupied a prominent place in Zapatero's speeches and in debates in Parliament of the last two days.
The new prime minister vowed to make the fight against terrorism, whether domestic or foreign, a priority of his government.
As part of a new strategy, he said, he will place the anti-terrorism activities of the country's many security and intelligence services under a single, unified command.
``Our security forces will be better equipped, better coordinated and better informed,'' Zapatero said.

The reform, if carried out, will pool intelligence-gathering by Spain's civil guard, national police and armed forces, which all have their own intelligence services and often carry on parallel operations.
Zapatero has named Jose Antonio Alonso, a judge and close friend, as the head of a new ministry of security that will coordinate external as well as loMastic operations.
It will take over investigations into the train bombings from the Interior Ministry.
As part of the overhaul, Zapatero pledged he would add 36,000 more personnel to the security forces over the next few years.
He said he will create 1,000 new positions for judges and prosecutors and set aside funds to modernize the justice system.
In two final news conferences this week, Acebes recapitulated some of the current investigation into the train bombings.
He said police continued to use the same working premise of recent days, namely that the Madrid attacks were organized inside Spain, largely by Moroccans who built and planted the bombs.
He emphasized that these cells were now largely dismantled and their suspects either in jail or dead.
But he also said that a superior leader or several leaders with religious training and experience in Afghanistan may have been involved or orchestrated the operation from afar.
The arrests on Friday of a Saudi and Egyptian citizen, he said, were still too fresh to conclude that the Moroccan group in Spain was linked to a broader international network.
The minister said that the police were also following leads in Britain, France, Germany, Bulgaria, Belgium, Morocco and Tunisia.
Acebes also announced what he called ``a significant new blow'' against the Basque separatist group ETA following Friday's arrest in France of three suspects who had been wanted since 2001.
The French police had also discovered a workshop where electronic parts for bombs were assembled and tested by ETA.
Some bombs were also found.
WIRETAPS GIVE CLUES TO MASTERMIND OF MADRID BOMBING
Terrorists are not usually talkers.
But the man who calls himself the mastermind of the March 11 train bombings in Madrid is an exception.
For nearly three months, the Italian police have eavesdropped on Rabei Osman Sayed Ahmed, "Muhammad the Egyptian" as the 32-year-old Egyptian is known.

The contents of his conversations, both in custody in Milan, Italy, and before his arrest last month, have provided the police with a mother lode of information about the secret world of a man who claims to have recruited suicide bombers and organized terrorist operations in the name of Islam.

Dozens of pages of transcripts obtained by The New York Times and interviews with officials in Spain, Italy, Germany and France have shed light on Ahmed and his ability over the years to take on new identities, cross borders and avoid the police as he pressed his cause against the West.
They also offer a case study of the challenges and frustrations Europe faces in monitoring radicals, routing out sleeper cells and prosecuting and convicting those they arrest.
In Germany in 1999 and 2000, Ahmed served 16 months in a detention center, feigning different Arabic accents and pretending to be a "stateless Palestinian" seeking political asylum.
In Madrid in 2001 and 2002, he became friendly with a group of radical Muslims, some of whom were involved in the March 11 bombings and were killed in a suicide operation escaping the police.
In a Paris suburb in 2003, he eked out a living as an illegal construction worker and house painter.
In Milan, Italy, in 2004, he lived in an apartment in a tidy, upscale neighborhood, where he seemed to spend most of his day watching Arabic-language movies and news on satellite television.
We looked for a job for him, said Ghazi Bidel, a 27-year-old Egyptian pizza maker who was his roommate in Milan.
But he said he didn't want to work.

Last April, shortly after the Spanish police found Ahmed's Italian cell-phone number in the address book of one of two men suspected of involvement in the plot, the Italian police began tapping Ahmed's phone and bugging his apartment.
He shows off a computer program that activates numerous cell phones simultaneously -- similar to the technology used in the Madrid attacks -- and says he was in Madrid days before the bombings.

He declares that nationality does not matter in holy war, that he has converted drug dealers and criminals to the faith and that Muslims are allowed to marry Christians as a means of acquiring false documents.

He takes what he calls a "beautiful photo" of Yahia Ragheh, a 21-year-old Egyptian whom he is grooming to become a suicide bomber -- and who was arrested with him -- and tells him that it will be sent to his family and other militants after his death.
Even after his arrest on June 7, Ahmed was still talking.
In a conversation with Ragheh in a holding cell that night, Ahmed predicted that he faced a grim future behind bars.
The minimum is 30 years, he said.
I am too trapped.
Some of the conversations are included in a confidential Italian arrest warrant for the two men last month and were first reported by the Italian daily Corriere della Sera.

Last Tuesday, a Milan court ruled that the conversations were admissible in court and described Ahmed as a member of al-Qaida's terrorist network and a "promoter and organizer of a terrorist organization spreading Islamic terrorism" who had played "a high-level role" in the Madrid bombings.

But the case has also divided the police and intelligence and law enforcement officials in Spain's new Socialist government, exposing rivalries between agencies and a lack of trust between career officials and less experienced political appointees.
While some senior Spanish officials have expressed delight that Italy has Ahmed safely behind bars, others are upset that it has not yet granted Spain's request for extradition.
(STORY CAN END HERE -- OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

One example of the apparent lack of coordination in Spain is that key Spanish intelligence officials complain that they have not been given access to voice copies of Ahmed's conversations in Arabic, which they say are crucial for intelligence gathering.
But senior Spanish police officials acknowledge that the Italians began turning over the voice recordings to the Spanish magistrate in charge of the investigation even before Ahmed was arrested.

According to an internal Spanish Interior Ministry document, in Egypt Ahmed was a member of the terrorist group Egyptian Islamic Jihad, was attached to an explosives brigade during his military service and spent time in a maximum security prison for terrorist activities.
The request for information "was communicated to the Egyptian services," the report said.
Unfortunately, these services have given us no data.
Meanwhile, Spanish investigators and intelligence officials are struggling to determine who exactly "Muhammad the Egyptian" is and how big a role he played in the bombings.

Spain's deputy prime minister, Maria Teresa Fernandez de la Vega, said at a news conference on June 11 that Spain had formally requested Ahmed's extradition because he had "very important responsibility" for the attacks.
The confidential extradition request of June 8 calls him "one of the people directly involved in the attack."
We exaggerated to get the Italians to act, the official said.
The Italians have the right to bring Ahmed to trial for crimes committed on their soil before considering Spain's extradition request.

The only physical evidence found by the Spanish authorities against Ahmed is paper-thin: the presence of his cell-phone number in an address book believed to belong to either Fouad Morabit, a Moroccan, or Basel Ghalyoun, a Syrian.
Ahmed was identified by witnesses as having been in the apartment near Madrid where the train bombs were assembled.
And the Italian authorities have evidence that Ahmed called the cell phone of Morabit, who has been arrested in Spain, after the bombings.

Other potential evidence was found in Ahmed's computer, seized during the raid on his Milan apartment, including a downloaded program that allows the simultaneous setting of alarms on up to a dozen telephones, diagrams of explosive briefcases, vests modified for suicide attacks and a video showing the decapitation of Nicholas Berg, an American killed in Iraq in May.
Of the Madrid bombing, Ahmed said in an intercepted conversation on May 26, "The Madrid attack was my project, and those who died as martyrs were my dearest friends."
I was ready to blow myself up, but they stopped me, and we obey God's will, he said.

I had wanted a heavy burden, but I didn't find the means.
This plan cost me a lot of study and patience.
It took me two and a half years.
In a conversation on June 4 in which Ahmed was wooing Ragheh into becoming a suicide bomber, Ragheh posed for photograph that was to be distributed after his martyrdom.
Come a little closer, Ahmed said.

Stop, move just a little.
Like this it will be a marvelous day, with your face illuminated.
You have a light around your face.
It's not artificial.
It's a luminous light that will never leave your body.
Ahmed told his young charge that he listened to soothing cassette tapes of martyrdom continuously, and told him to do the same.
They will make everything easier when you feel them enter your body, Ahmed said, explaining that a suicide mission "takes five minutes, and then everything blows up."
Ahmed talked and talked, despite expressing repeated concern that his phone was tapped, saying on April 12, "Listen to me, brother! Let's stop here.
I don't want us to be caught through the telephone!"
Despite all that talking, Ahmed has refused to cooperate with Italian investigators since his arrest and solitary confinement in a maximum security prison in Milan.

He complains about not being able to talk to anyone except himself.
He is suffering.
SPAIN CONTINUES TO UNCOVER TERRORIST PLOTS, OFFICIALS SAY

One year after the worst terrorist attack in Spanish history, the Spanish police continue to uncover and thwart new plots involving Islamic militants, according to senior Spanish intelligence and law enforcement officials.

Despite sweeping measures to improve their ability to investigate potential terrorist threats since the March 11, 2004, bomb attacks that left 191 people dead, the officials estimate that there are hundreds of people scattered in cells around the country committed to attacking centers of power in Spain.
The police have found indications of a cell of Pakistanis that they suspect was planning an attack on a high-profile target in Barcelona.
They also found evidence of a cell of North Africans in Madrid that apparently wanted to attack Madrid's high court, the officials said.
That means the threats have not disappeared.
As for the investigation into the Madrid bombing, it is far from over.
Spain is still hunting down at least half a dozen suspects, who are probably outside the country.

The great majority of the perpetrators are identified, dead or in prison, said a senior intelligence official at the Guardia Civil, or Civil Guard, a police force with military and civilian functions.

But we cannot say that we have all of them.
There are questions that remain unclear.
The most important is: Who masterminded March 11?
Of 79 suspects believed to be involved in the Madrid bombings, 24 are in jail and awaiting trial.
Seven suspects blew themselves up in a Madrid apartment three weeks after the bombing to avoid capture.
13 ARRESTED IN CONNECTION WITH MADRID TRAIN BOMBINGS

The Spanish police took 13 people into custody on Friday in connection with the deadly train bombings here last year, including a man extradited from Belgium who is accused of being one of al-Qaida's top leaders in Europe, the Interior Ministry said.

A senior police official, who requested anonymity because police rules prevent him from speaking about the investigation publicly, said Belhadj might have been the leader of al-Qaida's military wing in Europe during the time of the train bombings.
The 12 other men taken into custody on Friday in the bombings, which killed 191 people and injured more than 1,000, were arrested in Madrid and charged with collaborating with terrorists.
They include six Moroccans, three Syrians, a Palestinian, an Egyptian and an Algerian.
Four of the men are close associates of Belhadj's, the Interior Ministry said.
Belhadj was arrested in Belgium on Feb. 1.
Investigators say he recruited Muslims in Europe and financed their trips to Afghanistan to train as terrorists.
Documents filed in court say that Belhadj was in Madrid a few days before the bombings.
The documents also say that he had contact with some of the men who carried out the attacks, including Sarhane Ben Abdelmajid Fakhet, a Tunisian who police officials say was the religious leader of the attackers.
Officials said it was not clear exactly what Belhadj's role was in the bombings.
But investigators are exploring the theory that he acted as a messenger who carried instructions from al-Qaida's most senior leaders -- Osama bin Laden and his closest lieutenants -- to the local cell in Madrid that carried out the attacks, according to the police official.
We are working on the hypothesis that Belhadj could be such a messenger," the official said.
But we do not have any objective evidence yet.
Investigators say that the decision to attack Spain may have been made during a February 2002 meeting of members of al-Qaida and their allies in Istanbul, Turkey.

Belhadj is thought to have been at the meeting, which, according to court documents, was coordinated by Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the Jordanian-born militant whose capture is a priority for American forces in Iraq.
Before Friday's detentions, the Spanish police had already arrested 81 people in connection with the attacks.
Twenty-five people have been jailed.
The trials are expected to begin in the summer.
BUSH CITES LEADERSHIP AND DOMESTIC INITIATIVES IN ASKING FOR SECOND TERM

( NEW YORK_Republican George W. Bush asked the American people Thursday night to give him a second term as president to build "a more hopeful" nation at home and pursue the "steady, consistent, principled leadership" required to win the world war on terrorism.

Bush, addressing the final night of the four-day Republican National Convention, told thousands of chanting, cheering delegates and guests at Madison Square Garden that he would devote a second term to changing the tax code, expanding health insurance coverage, protecting pension plans and improving worker re-training.
And tonight, my fellow Americans, I ask you to stand with me.
Bush came as close as he has ever come to acknowledging "shortcomings."
You may have noticed I have a few flaws, too, Bush said, citing a tendency to mangle sentences, "a certain swagger"and coming across "a little too blunt."
You and I have come to know each other,Bush said.
Even when we don't agree, at least you know what I believe and where I stand.
The Nov. 2 election is the first presidential contest since the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks and the first election since 1968 to take place with American GIs engaged in combat.

Bush, speaking three miles from the site of the destroyed World Trade Center, highlighted his campaign against the al-Qaida terrorist network that carried out the Sept. 11 attacks and defended his decision to wage war against Iraq based on what turned out to be faulty intelligence claiming stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction.
The weapons Bush cited to justify the invasion of Iraq 17 months ago have not been found.
Bush said he would continue promoting democracy abroad to nations beyond Afghanistan and Iraq.

Bush took several road-tested swipes at Kerry by name,citing his opposition to his overhaul of Medicare, health-savings accounts, limits on legal and medical liability and his support for "more than $2 trillion in new federal spending so far."
Bush also threw red meat to the conservative right_a constituency he hopes to rally on election day.

He promised to "make a place for the unborn child," protect the definition of marriage between a man and woman from "activist judges," and promised to only choose federal judges who "know the difference between personal opinion and the strict interpretation of the law."

The war in Iraq and Bush's domestic policies sparked a variety of mostly peaceful protests on the streets of Manhattan during the course of the Republican convention, leading police to arrest more than 1,700 demonstrations since last weekend.
New York Gov.George Pataki introduced Bush with quips that ignited the hall.
Republicans were lucky heading into the final election push, Pataki said.
This fall we're going to win one for the Gipper_a reference to the late Ronald Reagan.
But our opponents_they're going to lose one with the Flipper.
They didn't bank on George W.Bush.

Retired Army Gen.Tommy Franks, who commanded the U.S. invasion of Iraq, took the podium to praise Bush in the face of Kerry's criticism that the White House had mishandled post-invasion planning for the U.S. occupation.
Bush addressed the convention as the White House braced for Friday's release of the latest unemployment and job creation statistics_a readily understood yardstick for economic recovery.
White House Chief of Staff Andrew Card, speaking shortly before Bush's speech, conceded that the new statistic would be politically sensitive.

Bush's second term agenda includes a $1 trillion, 10-year plan to revamp Social Security to permit younger workers to privately invest a portion of their payroll taxes, private health savings accounts and permanent adoption of $1.7 trillion in tax cuts.
The Bush and Kerry campaigns jockeyed to be the first out of the starting gate for the 60-day sprint to the Nov. 2 Election in a race that has been a statistical dead heat for months.

It wasn't supposed to be like this.
Everything seemed to be in place for a powerful run by Sen.John Kerry in Ohio in the stretch drive after Labor Day.
Al Gore lost the state by 175,000 votes in 2000, despite having pulled all his advertising early in October.
Ohio has shed 250,000 jobs since George W. Bush became president.
Rocked by scandals and an unpopular tax increase, the statehouse Republicans, from Gov.Bob Taft down the line, have been in unaccustomed disarray for weeks.

At the end of last month, the Census Bureau reported that Cleveland, with a poverty rate of 31.3 percent, led the country in that most dubious category, and at the beginning of this month American deaths in Iraq topped 1,000.
Yet Kerry seems to be falling back.
Ahead by six percentage points in a CNN/USA Today/Gallup poll in mid-July, Kerry trailed by nine points in a similar survey taken Sept. 3 through Sept. 7, immediately after the Republican convention.
Democratic professionals have begun to criticize Kerry's efforts -- privately and, in a few cases, publicly.
Snowboarding in Sun Valley, shooting skeet in the Ohio Valley and windsurfing off that great working-class vacation paradise, Nantucket.
Democrats -- at least Ohio Democrats -- play softball and touch football."

Robert T. Bennett, now in his fifth presidential race as the Ohio Republican chairman, predicted that "trench warfare, down at the grass-roots level" would continue right through Election Day, with a close finish the most likely outcome.

Frustrated in 2000 when Bush's lead shrank in the final 72 hours or so, the Republicans began preparations for 2004 more than a year ago, and 75 people from the state party are now in position around the state, along with 59,000 volunteers, and more than a million pro-Bush phone calls have been placed to voters.
Ohio is one of roughly a dozen battleground states, half of them in the Midwest, that appear likely to prove decisive in the presidential race.
With 20 electoral votes, it is a significant prize, but it has a certain iconic significance as well, because no Republican has ever been elected with out carrying it.

Both parties have mounted all-out efforts this time, with ample advertising and numerous appearances by their candidates -- no fewer than 66 visits this year by the presidential and vice presidential nominees.
On the very night that Bush accepted the Republican nomination at Madison Square Garden, Kerry made a midnight speech in Springfield, Ohio, between Columbus and Dayton.

Last week, his running mate, Sen.John Edwards, was in Chillicothe on Tuesday, Kerry himself spoke in Cincinnati on Wednesday, Vice President Dick Cheney was there on Thursday, and Bush campaigned in Portsmouth and Chillicothe on Friday, his fourth Ohio visit in just 16 days.
Chillicothe -- population a mere 21,796 but with access to several major media markets -- has a respectable claim, if only a fleeting one, to the title of crossroads of American politics.
More ranking politicians have come to town this year than it has seen in all the years since its heyday as Ohio's first capital two centuries ago.
Why this year?
Chillicothe is on the edge of -- and Portsmouth is in the heart of -- the state's hilly and chronically economically depressed Appalachian region.
Much of the region is represented in Congress by Ted Strickland, a Democrat.
Southern Democrats like Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton have fared well there, Bush barely won there four years ago, and it is widely seen as a pivotal area this year.
The president clearly hopes to do better this time, but the Kerry forces greeted him with a locally aired commercial focusing on the economy.
Its message: "In 2000, George Bush never bothered to come to Portsmouth.
Now, he's here promising to take 'the side of working families.
Historically -- in Korea, in Vietnam -- as American deaths mount, public support gradually withers, more or less regardless of what politicians do, Mueller said.

It's eroding now, but probably not fast enough to affect the outcome of this election, in this state or nationally.
Bush wants to make this year into 1944, and Kerry would like to make it more like 1968, I guess.
Another reason for Kerry's difficulties is demographic.
The state has been closely contested so far, but it is less representative of the nation as a whole than it once was.
As labor unions have waned and the suburbs and exurbs around cities like Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati, Toledo and Akron have flourished, the state has become more Republican.

The Republicans now have a 12-6 majority in the congressional delegation, and hold both Senate seats, the governorship, all the other statewide constitutional offices and both houses of the legislature.

Since 1948, Ohio has slowly become less of a barometer, said Michael F. Curtin, president of The Columbus Dispatch, who has tracked Ohio politics for decades, "On average, it has voted 1.7 points more Republican than the country has.
The last Democrat to run stronger here than he did nationally was Lyndon Johnson in 1964."
DEBATE COULD SHOW THAT CLOTHES, IMAGE CAN COUNT MORE THAN MESSAGE
President George W. Bush and Sen.John Kerry tailor political messages not only with their words, but also their clothes.
When the presidential debates open Thursday in Miami, their sartorial selections won't be off-the-cuff statements.
Image will be among the elements scrutinized by pundits and voters.
Color.
Fit.
Cut.
Whether suits or khakis, every bit helps in an election as tight as spandex.
It's a controlled image, said Anna Wildermuth, president of the Association of Image Consultants International.
Four years ago when Bush debated Vice President Al Gore for the first time, they dressed nearly identically in the unofficial uniform of a politician: dark suit, red tie.
The goal: Look presidential.
Think Hugo Boss, not Boss Hogg.
Expect the same Thursday night with minor, if any, adjustments, said veteran political consultant Bill Carrick, an adviser for Rep.Dick Gephardt's unsuccessful presidential campaign.

This election, Kerry -- along with a bipartisan roll call including New York Gov.George Pataki, Secretary of Commerce Donald Evans and Connecticut Sen.Joseph Lieberman -- has moved away from the traditional power tie to more whimsical neckwear.
He's wearing $65 Vineyard Vines ties (made in the USA) that weave in the trappings of the good life: lacrosse sticks, hot air balloons, parrots and palm trees.
He also has a custom-made campaign tie with JK04 and little American flags, which he wore on a Time magazine cover.
But Kerry's switch from swankier, European-made Hermes ties ($120-plus) represents a potentially knotty problem, especially for someone accused by his opponent of political weaving, Carrick said.
He should stay with it to be consistent," Carrick said.
Bush is appealing to the very conservative, traditional man in his Oxxford suit, Wildermuth said.

The biggest thing for Kerry is he has a very somber coloring.
He's trying really, really hard to choose colors that warm him up.
Now, he's gravitating toward powder blue.
While business garb should complement but not overshadow a candidate, it can become a political trademark.
Former Tennessee governor and past GOP presidential candidate Lamar Alexander turned a black-and-red plaid shirt into his personal billboard.
President Ronald Reagan wore a brown suit as his calling card.
Nixon wore no makeup and displayed a prominent 5 o'clock shadow during a TV debate.
Viewers and voters narrowly elected the more polished Kennedy.
In a close election, knowing that 93 percent of a person's effectiveness as a communicator is judged on style, not content, we can expect appearance to play a large role," McClarie said.
Looking like a regular guy, though, has an appeal, especially in the small towns visited by both campaigns.
Bush has flashed boots and a big buckle: Gene Autry with launch codes.
When the president toured coastal parts of Alabama and Florida wrecked by Hurricane Ivan, he wore a light-colored windowpane shirt with gray slacks and casual brown shoes.
On Sunday, Kerry, dressed in a blue button-down shirt and casual pants, made an unannounced stop at the Main Street Pub and Grill in Mount Horeb, Wis., to drink a beer with Green Bay Packers fans.
Recently, after the presidential motorcade rolled impressively through a string of small Ohio towns, Bush put the pedal to the metal on folksiness.
He rolled up the sleeves of his blue dress shirt, worn with dark, pleated slacks.
I like to get out with the people, Bush told the crowd in Ohio, one of the crucial battleground states that will help decide the November election.
I like to tell people where I stand.
Roll up the sleeves and let's talk," Dave Gable, of Portsmouth, Ohio, said in a telephone interview.
The 57-year-old describes himself as an independent voter.
Kerry has displayed maximum comfort in his U.S. Senate garb -- dark suit, white shirt, dark tie.
Alice Carr, a Democratic voter in West Virginia, noticed Kerry's "aristocratic air."
But when the candidate appeared at the annual Labor Day picnic for the United Mine Workers of America in Racine, W.Va., Kerry struck a relaxed pose in a blue opened-collar shirt and khakis.
I wouldn't have liked it, said Carr, a Kerry supporter.

It was just a picnic.
You don't dress like that at a picnic.

BUSH HAILS SWEEPING VICTORY FOR PARTY

George Walker Bush declared victory in the race for president on Wednesday driving a national election that bolstered Republican strength in Congress and led the White House to proclaim that Bush had captured a mandate for a second term.
Bush beamed as he stood with Vice President Dick Cheney at a rally in Washington, D.C., four hours after accepting a concession call at the White House from Sen.
John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who waged a fierce challenge to unseat him.

In calling the president, Kerry abandoned a threat to contest the election result in Ohio in deference to a decisive popular vote victory by a man who four years ago won the presidency with less than 50 percent of the popular vote.

The victory by Bush amounted to a stunning turn in fortunes for the nation's 43rd president, who had at times this year seemed destined to repeat his father's fate of losing a second term because of a weak economy.

Instead, Bush won more popular votes than any president in history -- 58.6 million, or 3.5 million more than Kerry, albeit in a nation with an expanding population of voters -- and positioned himself and his party to push through a conservative agenda in Washington over the next four years.
Bush became the first Republican president since Calvin Coolidge to win re-election while gaining seats in the House in the Senate; a gain of at least two in the House and four in the Senate.

While Republicans did not win enough seats to provide Bush a veto-proof Congress, the party's surge resulted in the defeat of Tom Daschle, the South Dakota senator who was the Senate minority leader and was one of the most familiar Democratic faces in Washington.

Cheney, in introducing the president at the rally at the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center less than half mile from the White House, left little doubt about how this White House saw the election, and what it intended to do with it.

Bush's victory was powered in no small part by a huge turn-out among Evangelical Christians, who are now likely to seek a bigger voice in key White House decisions over the next four years -- in particular, nominations of Supreme Court justices that are certain to confront Bush in the months ahead.

Tracy Dahlby, a longtime Asia hand, notes in a new book about Indonesia, "Allah's Torch," that at least one poll shows that roughly 75 percent of Indonesians had good feelings about the United States in 2000 -- a period that followed the American intervention in the Asian financial crisis and the forced resignation of President Suharto.
That figure, he says, has fallen to about 15 percent.
Another noted that such a reaction is inevitable, even when good work is being done."
(END OPTIONAL TRIM.)
Early reports indicate that even in a holiday week, the U.S. bureaucracy swung into gear fairly quickly.

But to some degree, the war of perceptions has to do with whether the Asian nations believe Bush focuses on the tsunami tragedy with the same kind of energy he put in to making sure that other nations signed on to his counterterrorism agenda after Sept. 11.

Just weeks after those attacks, Bush traveled to Shanghai for the annual summit meeting of Asian leaders and said that the world's foreign policy agenda must be redrawn, making it clear he would judge allies on the basis of how well they joined the fight.
Many responded.
Among the first visitors to the Oval Office after the attack was Megawati Sukarnoputri, then Indonesia's president.
She pledged to join the hunt for al-Qaida operatives on her territory, and largely made good on the promise.

The equivalent of that visit came Wednesday morning when Bush, operating from a trailer just across the road from his ranch that has been converted into a secure communications center, called the leaders of Sri Lanka, Thailand, Indonesia and India to pledge his support.
He acknowledged that it will take months to assess the damage and get help to the remote areas.

Yet as they measure the need, Bush's aides are aware that the depth of America's compassion will be compared with other yardsticks, specifically, what other nations are spending, what Washington spends on lesser disasters at home, and what is now being spent in Iraq.
Spain, with an economy a fraction of the size of the United States', has publicly committed about $68 million to the disaster.
Australia has pledged $27 million.
Then there are the domestic comparisons.
Congress has approved roughly $13 billion for aid related to the hurricanes that hit the country in the late summer and throughout the fall.
Most of that is going to Florida, where Bush personally loaded fresh water and dry goods into the trunks of cars.
Of course, that was home turf, and an election campaign was under way, and even Bush's critics do not expect spending on that scale for the far greater disaster in South Asia.
And there are already signs that Democrats want to link the response to this disaster to spending in Iraq.
We spend $35 million before breakfast in Iraq.
BUSH ANNOUNCES FOUR-NATION DISASTER RELIEF EFFORT, MILITARY HELP IN WAKE OF TRAGIC QUAKE, TSUNAMI

President Bush announced Wednesday that the United States would head a group of nations coordinating relief to areas devastated by Sunday's earthquake and tsunami, while defending the speed and scope of the American response to the tragedy.
We pledged an initial $35 million in relief assistance, Bush said in his first remarks since the disaster struck 12 nations in South Asia and Africa.

We have deployed disaster experts to the region.
We're dispatching a Marine expeditionary unit, the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln and the Maritime pre-position squadron from Guam to the area to help with relief efforts.
The president indicated that the United States would continue to help over the long term.
I spoke with the leaders of India, Sri Lanka, Thailand and Indonesia, and expressed my condolences and our country's condolences, he said.
Secretary of State Colin Powell contacted leaders in Japan, Australia and India to set up a task force to administer world relief efforts, Bush said.
A State Department official had a teleconference Wednesday night with counterparts in those nations to lay out an initial plan.
Predictions regarding the eventual death toll soared.
I think it's going to be well over 100,000, said Andrew Natsios, head of the U.S. Agency for International Development.
As many as 3,000 Americans, mostly tourists in Thailand, had not been accounted for, the State Department said.
So far, 12 Americans were known to have died after the 9.0 earthquake off Indonesia created the tsunami that inundated areas in 12 nations.
In the year 2004, our government provided $2.4 billion in food, in cash, in humanitarian relief to cover the disasters for last year, Bush said.

That's 40 percent of all the relief aid given in the world last year, was provided by the United States government.
Natsios said that Sunday, within hours of the disaster, teams of American experts began assessing how much aid was needed and how it should flow into the ravaged countries.
The U.S. pledge of $35 million in initial relief tops the funds promised by individual countries so far, according to the Geneva-based U.N. Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs.
That money will end up being a small percentage of U.S. government and private assistance, including the costs of sending U.S. military ships and aircraft to the region, officials said.
The first U.S. military C-130s carrying supplies stockpiled in Dubai landed in Indonesia on Wednesday, said Lt.Gen.James Conway.
P-3 reconnaissance planes from a group of nine sent to the area made an aerial assessment of damage sites.
Two Navy task forces set sail for the region, Conway said.
One group of Navy ships and U.S. Marines, headed by the carrier USS Abraham Lincoln, will operate out of a Thai base at Utapao.
The carrier, which has helicopters that can help evacuate the injured and deliver supplies, left Hong Kong and will arrive in the area in about seven days, Conway said.
The second task force, which includes the helicopter carrier USS Bonhomme Richard and a force of Marines, steamed from Guam for the Bay of Bengal to help with relief efforts in Sri Lanka and India.
It will arrive about Jan. 7.
Seven of the U.S. ships can each produce 90,000 gallons of fresh water daily to help alleviate fears of cholera from contaminated water.
The task forces will also have medical facilities.
Private aid organizations were receiving enormous pledges to help from U.S. citizens, officials said.
Bush and other officials urged people wanting to help to send money -- not food or clothing.
If people give commodities, it'll take a month to get there, and the transportation costs are more than the value of the commodities," Natsios said.
SIGNIFICANT AID BEGINS ARRIVING IN TSUNAMI-STRICKEN REGIONS
Cargo-laden ships and planes converged Sunday on stricken coasts in Indonesia and other countries, and helicopters ferried food, water and medicines to desperate, isolated survivors.

Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and President Bush's brother and personal representative, Gov.Jeb Bush of Florida, left Sunday for Asia, and Secretary-General Kofi Annan of the United Nations will depart Monday to tour the hardest-hit regions and to join a conference of Southeast Asian nations in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday to map a strategy for the relief effort.
Jan Egeland, the U.N. emergency relief coordinator, recounted progress in relief efforts in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, India, Thailand and other nations.
It was only the beginning of a relief campaign that has drawn pledges of $2 billion from 40 countries.

But after a week of horrific reports -- with estimates of as many as 150,000 dead, 500,000 seriously injured, millions of homeless and hungry, and tens of thousands missing -- there was a sense of progress.
A fisherman, 24-year-old Tengku Sofyan, was found barely alive under his beached boat in Lampulo, in Aceh Province on the Indonesian island of Sumatra.
He had been trapped for a week without food and water, could barely speak and was badly dehydrated.
Lamsar Sipahutar, the director of search efforts in Indonesia, said that the government was ready to call off the search for missing people to concentrate on getting help to known survivors.
Indonesia, closest to the epicenter of the undersea earthquake, has said that 100,000 of its people were killed.
After days of red tape, washed out roads and bridges and other problems, substantial help was finally getting through, officials said.
A steady stream of cargo planes from many nations, and U.S. Black Hawk transport helicopters and C-130 cargo planes, continued to land supplies in Indonesia at the Banda Aceh and Medan airports.
Health officials in Sumatra said no major epidemics or medical crises had broken out, although the need for clean water and sanitation was urgent.
In Sri Lanka, government officials raised the death toll to 29,729, with 5,540 missing and more than 800,000 left homeless by the tsunami.
Aid officials said there was plenty of food and clothing, even a surplus.

But thousands of people were living in hundreds of small camps and other temporary shelters without adequate sanitation, and health officials in Colombo warned of the possibility of widespread disease.
