IN RAVAGED INDONESIA, AID WORK IS AN ACT OF FAITH
Children ran after a truck as it made one of what have become daily deliveries of aid in the region.
MEDAN, Indonesia - The trail of aid from the Church of the Tabernacle of David begins at an unmarked storefront in an inconspicuous alley a few miles from the sanctuary.
Boxes from the Samaritan's Purse, the relief organization run by evangelist Franklin Graham, son of the Rev.Billy Graham, are stacked to the ceiling.
Pickup trucks laden with rice, biscuits, and mattresses arrive and are unloaded.
A church representative buys the goods from wholesale sellers with contributions from Indonesia and abroad.

Truckloads of the supplies leave the storefront in the evenings, arriving in the devastated city of Banda Aceh, 260 miles northwest, in time for the goods to be unloaded, then repackaged at a sprawling hotel serving as headquarters for church volunteers and countless others from Indonesia and abroad assisting them.
Members of a Bali surfers' group separate the goods into black plastic bags - one package of biscuits, one of dry noodles, one of milk.
The aid is then delivered to tsunami survivors in the ravaged northernmost tip of Sumatra island.

Volunteers from the Medan church, led by Pastor Sukendra Saragih, are among the thousands of humanitarian workers who have poured into Aceh Province, the epicenter of the disaster that struck two weeks ago, spurring one of the largest international aid efforts in history.

Saragih's outfit, although dwarfed by international aid groups, is the face of a new, grass-roots relief movement that is attracting unprecedented numbers to Aceh, a region that had been all but closed to outsiders, strangers because of Indonesia's 28-year conflict with separatists.

The church group's effort is not only challenging and grueling, it is also dangerous: Christians, a minority of about 8 percent in the world's most populous Muslim country, have often been targets of attack in Aceh, according to church leaders.
I believe Aceh will change, he said.
Christian churches in Indonesia have launched what they call the largest Indonesian Christian response to a disaster.

A group that Saragih's church is assisting, Bless Indonesia Today, is spearheading a ministry appeal to raise $50,000 for administrative expenses alone, so that all other donations from the general appeal will go directly to assisting victims, according to IndonesiaWatch.org., a religious website.

In partnership with foreign missionaries, Indonesian churches are building on the work of Christians in the United States, where members of the National Council of Churches dispatched $1 million in immediate tsunami aid and set a goal of raising $5 million.

It's very sensitive," Dean L. Rompis, a 28-year-old member of a Church of the Tabernacle of David branch in Jakarta, said as he worked out logistics of aid convoys in flip-flops and a large blue sun hat at the Banda Aceh hotel.
They might think we're here to preach gospel in a Muslim area.
Rompis asserted that pastors had been killed in Aceh in the past by the Free Aceh Movement, even as the Indonesian military is accused of killing thousands of civilians in Aceh.
Right now, all the Christians are more concerned about humanity, he said.

We are all the same nation.
We want to help them, not because of religion or tribe.
A call to duty
For some, a disaster as massive as this can shake their faith and cause onlookers to question why God would allow it.
But for Saragih, as for many of his Muslim counterparts, the suffering is simply a mandate to mobilize and assist.
When the earthquake and resulting tsunami hit Dec. 26, Saragih dropped all other plans and drove the next day with another pastor to Aceh, where he had spent nine years quietly working among a tiny community of Christians and building up contacts.
When he arrived, the city was unrecognizable, with hundreds of bodies scattered in a field across from the Kartika Hotel, which is run by a friend of Saragih.
He asked if the Kartika could be used for the humanitarian effort, and his friend, a civilian who has run the military-owned hotel for decades, agreed.
But as word spread of Saragih's work and of the scale of the disaster, the endeavor took on a life of its own.
Christian doctors from the Oregon-based Northwest Medical Team International came to stay a few nights in the front bedrooms.
Christian surfers known as Conquerors of the Wave" arrived from Bali, sleeping five to a row on the floor in a back room.
A Christian political group arrived from Jakarta and camped out in a meeting room.
Korean Christians arrived, along with many others, crowding the hotel's corridors with their bedrolls and pitching tents on the front porch.
About nine days in, the operation became unwieldy.
The cooks wondered how many people to make food for every day and who all these new faces were.
Saragih said he wondered how he would pay the electric bill.
He grew exhausted, but could not take a rest.
To make matters worse, he received a phone call from the military asking whether it was true that he was charging people for staying there and taking advantage of this disaster?
No, he assured the caller; everyone stays for free, and eats for free, paying only a donation.

Still, the hotel has taken on the look of a refugee camp, with vats of rice cooked outside on smoky fires, unexpected guests begging for access to a bathroom from those lucky enough to have self-contained rooms, and the shelves behind the bar stacked high with clothes, shoes, and toiletries.
But even he has opened his little room to newcomers, laying four mattresses across the floor and housing at least five humanitarian squatters.

Just as the big-ticket aid agencies faced massive logistical difficulties until they agreed to meet regularly in Banda Aceh to coordinate their work, the groups at the Kartika finally held a meeting to decide how to divide up tasks and set rules.
With his blue hat shielding him from the sun, Rompis slowly began to organize the chaos.
If I get a printer, I will ask everyone to fill out this form, he said as he canvassed groups about how long they intended to stay and what kind of goods they had brought to donate to the aid effort.
As evening fell, the weary Saragih propped himself up in the open doorway of the hotel lobby after a hectic day.
The delivery truck laden with rice and biscuits had made the 16-hour trek from Medan and deposited its daily load in the front yard.
Volunteers had sorted the goods into family-sized packages.
The drivers had loaded thousands of the packages into ragtag vehicles and left for coastal villages full of refugees.

That afternoon, he had watched volunteers load the packages onto a truck that finally pulled out of the Kartika parking lot and wound its way northeast down the coastal highway toward an area called Ladong, accompanied by a Globe reporter.
Alongside the road, children sat at tables lined with donation boxes.
Sometimes the truck stopped, and villagers ran after it, reaching for the packets handed out through the back door.

After about an hour's journey past ruined houses and flattened factories, the truck climbed a hill up to a refugee camp, where Idawati, a 25 year-old housewife, had taken refuge in a school with 90 other families.
Idawati, who like many Indonesians goes by one name, smiled shyly when the food and supplies were unloaded from the truck, one of about four aid deliveries that stop in Ladong every day.
She did not know whether Christians or Muslims donated the food - nor did she care.

We just take everything.
We don't care where it is from, said Idawati, who fled with her young son up the nearest hill the moment she saw "the water stand up like a tree," ready to wash away her fishing village.

At another stop farther down the road, a wizened district officer named Yusman Ahmad smoked and fiddled with his false teeth under a tarp as he presided over mountains of rice, used clothes, and medical supplies.
Ahmad estimated the huge bags of rice would only last two days, as they had to feed 2,800 people.
When asked whether every religion was free to donate to the camp, Ahmad nodded his head.
Relieved of its load, the truck headed back to the Kartika Hotel.
Back at the headquarters, the delivery was reported as a success.

But the volunteers returned to discover the stunning news that about 50 bodies had been found outside a church, struck down by nature on the day after Christmas with a force that has been described as biblical.
First, the earthquake struck, prompting parishioners to run outside as their church crumbled.
Then, the giant wave came, killing what appeared to be the entire Sunday school.
I think he did this to show us that he is still almighty, that there is something bigger than the power of man.
A short distance away, in the lobby, Saragih looked a shade more ashen.
As he talked about plans to be in Aceh, on and off, for the next two years, he acknowledged: "Physically, I am very tired.
And that's why I have persevered."
BUSH NEARLY TRIPLES TSUNAMI AID REQUEST TO CONGRESS

President Bush said Wednesday he would ask Congress for $950 million for tsunami relief, nearly tripling U.S. aid pledged for victims of the monstrous seismic wave that swept the Indian Ocean in December.

The beefed-up aid proposal, to be part of a supplemental budget request to go to Congress later this week, includes money to cover emergency relief efforts as well as new funding to help rebuild bridges, roads, schools and housing destroyed in a natural disaster that took some 150,000 lives.

In a statement, Bush said the money would help restore communities and rebuild "vital infrastructure that re-energizes economies and strengthens societies" in Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Thailand and other countries that bore the brunt of the tsunami's wrath.
Days after the Dec. 26 earthquake and tsunami rocked the Indian Ocean region from Indonesia to the horn of Africa, Bush pledged immediate aid of $35 million.
He quickly raised that pledge to $350 million.
On Wednesday, he increased that pledge by another $600 million.
Some $236 million has already been spent in emergency aid and military rescue efforts.

The $950 million Bush is requesting includes money to cover those efforts as well as longer-term reconstruction aid needed to continue addressing victims' needs, said Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz.
(Optional add begins here)
The new aid request will be part of an $81 billion supplemental budget request the White House is expected to send up to Capitol Hill later this week.
Most of that money will go to fund continuing military operations in Iraq - now costing an estimated $5 billion a month - and Afghanistan.
The tsunami relief request includes:
- $346 million to replenish costs incurred by the U.S. Agency for International Development and the Pentagon for emergency relief and humanitarian aid.
- $339 million for rebuilding roads, bridges, schools and other critical facilities.
- $168 million to provide food, shelter, grants and loans aimed at helping victims to get back on their feet and restoring their communities and local economies.
- $62 million to help governments in affected countries plan long-term rehabilitation efforts.
- $35 million for ocean-borne sensors and transmitters to make up an early warning system to signal oncoming tsunamis and typhoons.
(Optional add ends here)

In addition to the official U.S. assistance, private American donors have provided more than $800 million in corporate and individual donations toward various tsunami relief efforts, said Alan Larson, undersecretary of state for economic, business and agricultural affairs.
At the height of the U.S. emergency response, there were some 16,000 U.S. military personnel in the Indian Ocean region, Wolfowitz said, aboard 26 U.S. warships.

Those concerns have abated, said Wolfowitz, a former U.S. ambassador to Indonesia, as the U.S. military presence in the region has been reduced to some 3,600, many of whom are aboard the Mercy, a naval hospital ship that has treated more than 2,500 Indonesians seriously injured by the tsunami.
We came, we gave help and we left, he said.

DOCTOR'S AID TO TSUNAMI VICTIMS CHANGES PERSPECTIVE
The woman stumbled into the makeshift health clinic in Banda Aceh, Indonesia.
Five weeks after being knocked unconscious in the Dec. 26 tsunami, she complained of headaches and disorientation.
Dr. Michael Geci Black, who took time off from his job as an emergency room physician at St.Peter's Hospital in Albany, examined the woman.
He decided she needed a CAT scan for head trauma.
He walked with the patient to a nearby Indonesian Army Hospital, passing hundreds of armed soldiers along the way.
Through an interpreter, Black asked them to airlift the woman to the nearest medical facility with a CAT scanner, a one-hour flight.

They held their rifles, smoked their cigarettes, drank their soda and stared at me.
They wouldn't lift a finger, Black said.
Eventually, Black arranged for her to to go to a nearby hospital.
He never found out if the woman received a CAT scan because the Banda Aceh clinic was swamped with more than 500 patients daily.
The only American physician on site, he worked 12-hour shifts alongside doctors from Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia.
He treated patients with malaria and typhoid, and with respiratory problems from the burning of debris.
Black's plan to treat survivors of the tsunami that killed more than 170,000 people in 11 nations, including more than 125,000 in Indonesia, collided with geopolitics.
Banda Aceh is the northernmost province on the island of Sumatra.
It has a history of resistance and distrust of outsiders.
The Acehnese, who are Muslim, fought against Dutch colonial occupation in the 19th century and control by the Indonesian military in recent decades.
Since the late 1970s, rebels with the Free Aceh Movement-GAM have waged guerrilla warfare against the government.
The province has been shut off to visitors and ruled by martial law.
He returned recently after a few weeks in Banda Aceh.
He paid his own way and took time off.
He volunteered under the auspices of United Planet, a Boston-based humanitarian agency that works in developing countries.
The experience put the American doctor's workaday world in perspective.
Where do you begin to rebuild?"

Now, slightly more than two months after the tsunami struck, relief efforts are shifting from emergency needs of medical care, shelter and food to long-term treatment, such as mental health counseling.
Black said he saw no mental health professionals while he was there.
Physicians prescribed Valium to the distraught.
A lot of people came with psychological problems, but there wasn't a lot we could do for them, Black said.

Eric Hardiman, a State University of New York at Albany associate professor of social welfare, hopes the four-day training he helped lead last month for 50 Indonesian educators, psychologists and doctors will begin to fill gaps in mental health services.
It was a partnership that hopefully will begin to snowball and produce a contagion effect that spreads across Indonesia, Hardiman said.
The plan in this "training the trainers" approach is that the 50 Indonesians will pass along the strategies to 50 more and the sphere of influence will grow exponentially.

The Red Cross estimates 35,000 children in Indonesia lost a parent or close family member in the tsunami and about one-third of them are still seeking an identity match or closure on their missing parents.
Hardiman has immersed himself in Indonesian culture since he was a student at the University of California at Berkeley, where he began playing gamelan, traditional Indonesian music.
He currently plays with a group called Gamelan Giri Mekar at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.
I hope to be able to go back and follow up.
Hardiman's training in Jakarta, Indonesia's capital city, late last month was a collaboration with professors from Ohio State University and the University of North Carolina at Greensboro.
Hardiman's travel costs and lodging were paid for by SUNY Albany and the Indonesian Ministry of Sport.
It was titled "The International Workshop of Addressing Trauma and Depression of the Post-Earthquake and Tsunami Through Sport."
Hardiman based his training on U.S. studies that show physical activity and team sports can help alleviate depression in children.
Black and Hardiman agree the cultural divide may be the biggest challenge ahead.
Indonesia has 350 ethnic groups, each with unique cultural nuances.
If this is going to work, it's going to have to be done from within," Hardiman said.
They experienced a staggering, mind-blowing loss, said Hardiman.
Depression, withdrawal, lack of enthusiasm and other symptoms the children are experiencing are very normal.

Just a few weeks after the tsunami, they managed to smile and laugh.
They were hard at work rebuilding.
BC-MERCY-MAPPING-SPI USING HIGH-TECH MAPPING TO AID TSUNAMI VICTIMS
Glenn Brooks once used remote sensing and computerized mapping technology to track down and nab crooks in Alaska.
Now, Brooks and a gang of volunteer data crunchers plan to use GIS -- geographic information systems -- and other high-tech mapping technologies to assist with the rebuilding efforts in Indian Ocean communities devastated by the tsunami.
He leaves for Sri Lanka Friday.
It's an experiment," the former Anchorage police officer said.
I think it will make a big difference, but we need to demonstrate that it can work.
Brooks left police work years ago to pursue a career in GIS technologies and now works for Mercy Corps out of donated space on the University of Washington campus.

The Portland-based relief organization is sponsoring the project to see if Brooks and his team can use their talents at processing satellite imagery, GPS measurements and sophisticated computer mapping techniques to help Indonesian and Sri Lankan villagers find the best sites for building homes, digging wells or catching fish.
About 75 people have volunteered, many of them experts with the Central Puget Sound GIS Users Group.
UW students, through the Marc Lindenberg Center at the Evans School, are pitching in as well.
The question now for these communities is what to do about reconstruction, said Steve Claiborne, Mercy Corps' director of operations.
We want to provide people with the information they need to rebuild their lives.
The Dec. 26 earthquake and tsunami did much more than kill people and destroy homes.
The massive wall of water literally wiped communities off the map and redrew the coastline in some areas.
Sources of fresh water are contaminated by seawater.
Once fertile fishing grounds are now barren.
Property disputes have arisen over who owns what, and between locals who wish to rebuild and officials who want them to relocate.

In some areas of northern Indonesia, where the government continues to battle with separatist rebels, some aid groups say there still may be remote communities that have yet to receive adequate food and basic relief supplies.
How can a map, even a computerized map, help solve such complex problems?
It's better to think of this technology more as a collection of a lot of different kinds of spatially related information, said Dave Brown, a GIS expert and member of Brooks' team.
Our job is to take all those layers of information and make maps out of it.

Unlike a printed map, Brown noted, GIS produces an interactive computerized map that allows the user to zoom in and out, focus on specific questions or tasks and continually update with new information (like a satellite image of a newly built road or evidence of people migrating into or out of a region).
Disaster relief initiatives often tend to get launched with plenty of good intentions and not much reliable information, Claiborne said, which makes for some disorganized and even futile efforts.
But information is power.
Brooks had first intended to go to northern Indonesia because the need is greatest there.

But Indonesia has been unpredictable lately in its policy toward relief organizations, so he instead decided to take the pilot project to Sri Lanka, where the government has been less skeptical of relief organizations.
Also, the Sri Lankan government and the Tamil rebels have established a steady, if at times uneasy, peace.
Claiborne said Mercy Corps recognizes that GIS mapping is "pretty high-powered stuff," so the organization will work closely with government officials.
They plan to use the mapping technology to help communities make decisions, he said, but likely won't be distributing the maps to locals if there's any government concerns about doing so.
In Sri Lanka, a British group of GIS experts called MapAction has already familiarized officials with the technique.
MapAction arrived in Sri Lanka just three days after the tsunami and used GIS to help coordinate emergency relief for three weeks.

Now, Mercy Corps wants to see if the technology also can be used for the longer-term reconstruction and development efforts by focusing the power of this information on specific communities' needs and rebuilding projects.
Before the tsunami, Brooks was using GIS technology to try to help Mercy Corps locate people who had fled their villages due to violence in Sudan's Darfur region.
He used GIS to identify watersheds and grasslands suitable for refugees.
Now, he will head to Sri Lanka to see if his team can make an impact on the tsunami reconstruction front.
Brooks will be followed by Daphne Karypis, a GIS expert with experience using the mapping technology for landmine-removal efforts.

Academic experts and students with the UW's Mark Lindenberg Center for Humanitarian Action, International Development and Global Citizenship have offered to assist with -- as well as learn from -- the Mercy Corps project.

Working in donated UW space on donated Intel computers, using GIS and image processing software donated by Leica, ESRI (a leading GIS company) and others, Brooks' colleagues in Seattle have spent the past few months collecting images and data to help them assist those working in the tsunami disaster areas.
Mercy Corps has agreed to cover the other costs of this pilot project for six months.

The organization's GIS Seattle Data Center will stay in constant communication with Brooks, Karypis and others, who will begin operations in the Sri Lankan community of Arugam Bay on the southeast coast.

The idea will be to use satellite images, GPS readings and interactive maps to respond to the specific needs of these hard-hit communities: Where should we rebuild? Where is the most likely place to dig a well for fresh water? Where are the best fishing grounds now? The answers will be different in every community.
This technology has been in use a long time, but not much in the humanitarian community, Brooks said.
BUSH ADMINISTRATION MOVES CAUTIOUSLY ON CLIMATE CHANGE

The U.S. Climate Change Science Program, a consortium of 13 federal agencies, opened a three-day conference on such issues as the way climate events are monitored and recorded, the models scientists use to study the phenomenon, natural variability in the climate and human contributions to change.

Citing uncertainties about these and other issues, President Bush in March 2001 rejected the Kyoto Protocol, a climate change treaty that former President Clinton signed but never submitted to the Senate for ratification.
In its place, Bush called for an essentially voluntary program of greenhouse gas reduction and energy efficiency for the next 10 years _ and further study.
The three-day conference appears to be dominated by the departments of Commerce and Energy, but also includes environmentalists and other outsiders.
Delegates were presented a 177-page draft statement to be reviewed during the week and finalized Thursday.
``What we are arguing is that we need more information to have a clearly articulated policy that is practical,'' said Marburger, former president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

He noted that scientific findings reported by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a United Nations initiative that led to the Kyoto Protocol, was omitted from the draft scientific statement.
(Story can end here.
Optional add follows.)
One agency that seemed under-represented at the conference was the Environmental Protection Agency.
Organizers said more than 1,500 persons had signed up to attend at least some sessions.
A list of 1,000 officials attending the meeting, most of them from the federal government, included names of only 15 EPA employees.

Among persons not on the list was Robert Watson, the former NASA scientist who headed the United Nations panel on the Kyoto agreement until he was sacked earlier this year in a parliamentary maneuver supported by the Bush administration.

Among those whose names did appear were industry lobbyist Donald Pearlman and Southern Co.official Robert P. Gehri, who were reportedly involved in the maneuvering to have Watson replaced, and Randy Randol, an Exxon Mobil lobbyist to whose fax machine memoranda recommending the action were traced.

BIPARTISAN ON WARMING
On Thursday the Senate has a chance to take the lead on this issue when it votes on a bill sponsored by John McCain and Joseph Lieberman.
This bipartisan measure asks much less from US industry than the Kyoto Protocol does.

But at least it begins the process of treating the chief greenhouse gas, carbon dioxide, as an emission that has to be reduced if the planet is to avoid severe and unpredictable changes in weather, wildlife, and agriculture because of the warming that occurs when man-made gases function as a greenhouse layer above the earth's surface.
Under the McCain-Lieberman bill, major energy, transportation, and manufacturing companies would have to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions to year 2000 levels by 2010.

To keep costs manageable and give firms maximum flexibility in achieving this goal, the bill calls for establishment of a market-based emissions trading program similar to the one that has worked well for reductions of acid-rain-causing emissions.

Rwt a Massachusetts Institute of Technology study published in June found that the cost of the bill would be minimal _ about one-10th of 1 percent, or $20 per household for the years it takes for industry to come into compliance.
In July, leaked documents showed that Bush's own Env5977ere suppressed.
F%w Rupporters of the bill expect it to pass in its first Senate test.

But a substantial vote in favor would indicate that the Senate has come a long way from its 95-0 vote in 1997 for a nonbinding resolution expressing concerns as the Kyoto Protocol was being finalized.
Since then, research has only strengthened the conclusion of most scientists that global warming is occurring and that the emissions of cars, factories, and power plants add to it.
Kyoto's critics fault it for not demanding equal reductions from India, China, and other developing countries.
But it is unrealistic to expect efforts from those countries as long as the world's largest producer of carbon dioxide sits on the sideline.
With 4 percent of the world's population, the United States emits 25 percent of all greenhouse gases.
Passage of McCain-Lieberman _ preferably this year _ would demonstrate to the world that not all Americans are locked in a state of denial about this threat to the planet.
EFFECT OF KYOTO PROTOCOL DEBATED AGAIN
Russian ratification of the Kyoto Protocol would leave U.S. companies cut off from new markets worth billions of dollars, according to supporters of the treaty aimed at limiting "greenhouse gases."
Although the United States signed the treaty in 1997, it has withdrawn from it.
Members of Russian President Vladimir Putin's cabinet were signing on this week to his request that the Duma, the lower house of the country's parliament, ratify the treaty.

If that happens, it will satisfy a provision that says the agreement goes into force 90 days after it is ratified by industrialized countries responsible for 55 percent of the 1990 global emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases.
The treaty has been ratified by more than 100 countries, including Japan and all countries of the European Union.
But the refusal of the United States and Australia to sign up means that only Russia had sufficient 1990 emissions to push the total up to the 55 percent figure and bring the agreement into force.

The accord sets 1990 as a baseline year against which developed countries must cut emissions, and provides a trading mechanism whereby countries that produce less greenhouse gas than their 1990 baseline can sell "allowances" to those that fail to do so.
Russia will benefit from a great wealth transfer as EU funds flow into the country in exchange for rights to Russian carbon dioxide allowances, Institute President William O'Keefe said.
The tangible effect on carbon dioxide emissions will be nonexistent.

By some estimates, because of Russia's economic decline following the 1991 breakup of the former Soviet Union, its industrial activity -- and therefore its production of greenhouse gases -- has declined.
Illarionov argued that Russia is growing fast enough that it soon will produce more than enough greenhouse gases to exceed its 1990 baseline.
Caps placed on further emissions will inhibit the country's economic growth, he said.
They can't both be right, Petsonk said of the opposition from O'Keefe and Illarionov.
Russia will sell greenhouse gas allowances and use the income to help finance modernization of its economy, thereby reducing its emissions, she predicted.

Benedikt(cq) von Butler, a greenhouse gas broker with the London-based energy broker Evolution Markets LLC, said the Kyoto treaty was drafted with the assumption that U.S. participation would offset the large volume of Russian allowances.
It was assumed that America would suck up all the Russian hot air, he said in a telephone interview.
Now the European Green parties are insisting that the Russians do more than merely sell allowances, insisting that they want to see some economic benefit.
The protocol was signed by the United States and other countries in 1997 in Kyoto, Japan.
Shortly after taking office in 2001, President Bush withdrew the United States as a signer.

U.S. TURNS ITS BACK ON GLOBAL WARMING

There's one in every neighborhood: the petulant, uncooperative homeowner who refuses to cut the grass in his front yard, drives faster than the speed limit and is content letting others pick up trash he thoughtlessly dumped at the curb.
You know the type.
After almost eight years of negotiation and delay, the Kyoto Protocol officially goes into effect Wednesday.

The international treaty binds 131 industrialized nations to gradually lower their output of carbon dioxide and other "greenhouse gases" produced by human activities such as burning coal to produce electricity.

A lengthening list of scientific studies conducted by our own government as well as independent researchers has confirmed that the proliferation of these gases is melting ancient glaciers, raising sea levels, endangering low-lying areas and threatening the survival of plant and animal species around the world.
All of the European Union countries have ratified the treaty, as has Russia, a reluctant latecomer hoping to join the organization for economic, if not environmental, reasons.
Besides America, the only other Kyoto holdouts with mature economies are Australia and Monaco.
There's a great irony here: One of the reasons negotiations dragged on so long was the initial insistence of U.S. officials that the final Kyoto document contain a "cap-and-trade" system.

As envisioned, participants that reduce their own greenhouse gas emissions more than required by the treaty would be allowed to sell their excess pollution "credits" to companies that exceed their mandated limits.
The problem isn't only that many of our elected officials have spurned the Kyoto Protocol, it's that they've refused even to admit that global warming is occurring.

Since the United States, with 4 percent of the world's population, is responsible for 25 percent of the world's greenhouse gas emissions, it's incumbent that we show leadership befitting world's last remaining superpower.
That isn't happening.

Bush and the nation's lawmakers have refused to increase fuel efficiency for American-made cars and trucks, an overdue move that would lower carbon emissions while reducing our dependence on foreign sources of energy.
They've also been lukewarm to forward-looking legislation such as the McCain-Lieberman Climate Stewardship Act that would mandate limits on greenhouse gases for polluting industries.
Given the projected rate of global warming, some fear Kyoto may be too little, too late.
British Prime Minister Tony Blair recently pointed out why it's critical for the United States to remember the good-neighbor policy when it comes to global warming.
This editorial appeared in The Atlanta Journal-Constitution.
It sets the world on a course to economic disaster while doing nothing to alleviate global warming.
Kyoto attempts to alleviate what may be a major cause of warming -- the emission of greenhouse gases -- by suppressing energy use in the developed world.
Yet energy use is vital to modern health and wealth.
The Kyoto treaty itself recognizes this fact by exempting developing countries, eager to achieve prosperity, from greenhouse gas reductions.
As a result, China and India are likely to become the major emitters of greenhouse gases on the planet within a few decades.
This means that, even with Kyoto, global emissions of greenhouse gases will continue to increase.
So the Kyoto Protocol will do virtually nothing to halt any possible global temperature increase -- the temperature that would have been reached in 2100 will be reached in 2106.
Yet independent analyses of the annual cost to the world of complying with Kyoto put it at between $150 billion and $350 billion a year (the global development aid budget is $50 billion annually).
For a fraction of the annual cost of Kyoto, we could do much to alleviate these problems -- and thereby render any possible effects of global warming much more manageable.
We do not know what the extent of future warming will be.
One such key strategy is to allow and encourage the creation of wealth around the world.
For example, when several hurricanes hit Florida last year, the death toll was low.
But when those same hurricanes hit Haiti, thousands died.
The hurricanes were not appreciably stronger over Haiti, but Florida, being richer, proved more resilient.
By eliminating barriers to wealth such as trade restrictions and building up incentives to wealth such as property rights, we can put the world on the path to prosperity.
Then if the world does turn out to be appreciably warmer, the effects will be less in a more resilient world.
Kyoto supporters argue that this treaty is just a first step, and they're right -- it is a step in the wrong direction.
Iain Murray is a senior fellow at the Competitive Enterprise Institute in Washington.
REBUFFING BUSH, 132 MAYORS EMBRACE KYOTO RULES

Unsettled by a series of dry winters in this normally wet city, Mayor Greg Nickels has begun a nationwide effort to do something the Bush administration will not: carry out the Kyoto Protocol on global warming.
The mayors, from cities as liberal as Los Angeles and as conservative as Hurst, Texas, represent nearly 29 million citizens in 35 states, according to Nickels' office.

They are pledging to have their cities meet what would have been a binding requirement for the nation had the Bush administration not rejected the Kyoto Protocol: a reduction in heat-trapping gas emissions to levels 7 percent below those of 1990, by 2012.
On Thursday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg brought New York City into the coalition, the latest Republican mayor to join.

Nickels said that to achieve the 7 percent reduction, Seattle was requiring cruise ships that dock in its bustling port to turn off their diesel engines while resupplying and to rely only on electric power provided by the city, a requirement that has forced some ships to retrofit.
And by the end of this year the city's power utility, Seattle City Light, will be the only utility in the country with no net emissions of greenhouse gases, the mayor's office said.
Salt Lake City has become Utah's largest buyer of wind power in order to meet its reduction target.
In New York, the Bloomberg administration is trying to reduce emissions from the municipal fleet by buying hybrid electric-gasoline powered vehicles.

Nickels said he decided to act when the Kyoto Protocol took effect in February without the support of the United States, the world's largest producer of heat-trapping gases.
On that day, Nickels announced he would attempt to implement the agreement himself, at least as far as Seattle was concerned, and called on other mayors to join him.
The coalition is not the first effort by local leaders to take up the initiative on climate change.
California, under Gov.Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Republican, is moving to limit carbon dioxide emissions, and Gov.George A. Pataki of New York, also a Republican, has led efforts to reduce power plant emissions in the Northeast.
Michele St. Martin, communications director for the White House Council on Environmental Quality, said the Kyoto Protocol would have resulted in a loss of 5 million jobs in the United States and could raise energy prices.
(STORY CAN END HERE.
OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)
But many of the mayors said they were acting precisely out of concern for the economic vitality of their cities.
Nickels, for example, pointed out that the dry winters and the steep decline projected in the glaciers of the Cascade range could affect Seattle's supply of drinking water and hydroelectric power.
The mayor of low-lying New Orleans, C.Ray Nagin, a Democrat, said he joined the coalition because a projected rise in sea levels threatens the very existence of New Orleans."
I'm hoping it sends a message they really need to start looking at what's really happening in the real world, Arakawa said.
Nickels said it was no accident that most cities that have joined are in coastal states.
The mayor of Alexandria, Va., is worried about increased flooding; mayors in Florida are worried about hurricanes.
But Nickels has also found supporters in the heartland.
Jerry Ryan, the Republican mayor of Bellevue, Neb., said he had signed on because of concerns about the effects of droughts on his farming community.
Ryan described himself as a strong Bush supporter, but said he felt that the president's approach to global warming should be more like his approach to terrorism.
You've got to ask, Is it remotely possible that there is a threat?' he said.
If the answer is yes, you've got to act now.
U.S. TO JOIN CHINA AND INDIA IN CLIMATE PACT

The United States plans to join China and India in an Asian-Pacific climate agreement intended to replace the Kyoto pact as a method to control greenhouse emissions, an official attending the annual conference of Asian nations in Vientiane, Laos, said Wednesday.

The new five-member pact, described as an initiative of the Bush administration, would group the United States and Australia, developed countries that have not signed the Kyoto accord, with China and India, major producers of greenhouse emissions.
Even though they are major contributors to air pollution, China and India have not been required to sign the Kyoto protocol because they are considered developing countries.

The pact, to be called the Asia-Pacific Partnership for Clean Development and Climate, will join as partners nations that together account for more than 40 percent of the world's greenhouse gas emissions, said the official, who spoke anonymously so as not to pre-empt the formal announcement.
The agreement will be a major item on the agenda this week at the summit meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations now under way in Vientiane, the official said.
The deputy secretary of state, Robert Zoellick, who is representing the Bush administration at the conference, is scheduled to arrive Wednesday.
The aim of the pact will be to curb greenhouse emissions without hurting economic growth in the region, the official said.

Instead of mandatory targets, the new pact would aim to use the latest technologies to limit emissions and would try to make sure the technologies were available to countries that need them most, the official said.
The members of the new grouping would include some of the world's major coal producers and exporters: China, South Korea and Australia.
ON CLIMATE CHANGE, A CHANGE OF THINKING
In December 1997, representatives of most of the world's nations met in Kyoto, Japan, to negotiate a binding agreement to cut emissions of "greenhouse" gases.
They succeeded.
The Kyoto Protocol was ultimately ratified by 156 countries.
It was the first agreement of its kind.
But it may also prove to be the last.
Now, in the middle of new global warming talks in Montreal, there is a sense that the whole idea of global agreements to cut greenhouse gases won't work.

A major reason the optimism over Kyoto has eroded so rapidly is that its major requirement -- that 38 participating industrialized countries cut their greenhouse emissions below 1990 levels by the year 2012 -- was seen as just a first step toward increasingly aggressive cuts.
But the current stalemate is not just because of the inadequacies of the protocol.
It is also a response to the world's ballooning energy appetite, which, largely because of economic growth in China, has exceeded almost everyone's expectations.
And there are still no viable alternatives to fossil fuels, the main source of greenhouse gases.
Then, too, there is a growing recognition of the economic costs incurred by signing on to the Kyoto Protocol.
This is as true, in different ways, in developed nations with high unemployment, like Germany and France, as it is in Russia, which said last week that it may have spot energy shortages this winter.

The basic template came out of the first international pact intended to protect the atmosphere, the 1987 Montreal Protocol for eliminating chemicals that harmed the ozone layer, said Richard A.Benedick, the Reagan administration's chief representative in the talks leading to that agreement.
That agreement was a success, but a misleading one in the context of climate.

While it was relatively easy to phase out ozone-harming chemicals, called chlorofluorocarbons, which were made by a handful of companies in a few countries, taking on carbon dioxide, the main climate threat, was a completely different matter, he said.
Carbon dioxide is generated by activities as varied as surfing the Web, driving a car, burning wood or flying to Montreal.
Its production is woven into the fabric of an industrial society, and, for now, economic growth is inconceivable without it.

Developing countries -- China and India being only the most dramatic examples -- want to burn whatever energy they need, in whatever form available, to grow their economies and raise the living standard of their people.
All this has turned the Montreal meeting, many participants have conceded, into, at best, a preliminary meeting on how to start over in addressing the threat of global warming.

Indeed, from here on, progress on climate is less likely to come from mega-conferences like the one in Montreal and more likely from focused initiatives by clusters of countries with common interests, said Benedick, who is now a consultant and president of the National Council on Science and the Environment, a private group promoting science-based environmental policies.
The only real answer at the moment is still far out on the horizon: nonpolluting energy sources.
The train is not leaving the station, and it needs to leave the station, Richels said.

BY PLAYING AT 'RAGE,' CHINA DRAMATIZES ITS RISE

The banners had been carefully printed, the slogans memorized, and the students and young unleashed onto the streets of China's largest, most sophisticated city, where they were to speak sacred truths and make the enemies of the people tremble.

Chinese today have little experience of mass organized protests, so when the government tolerated -- some would say encouraged -- a huge anti-Japanese demonstration here that flirted with turning into a riot over the weekend, for many it bore echoes of the mass manipulation of students of another era, the Cultural Revolution.

For hours on Saturday, thousands of Chinese, from teenagers to people in their 30s, lay siege to the Japanese consulate in this city, smashing its windows and defacing its walls with a copious rain of rocks and bottles.

But for all the expressions of anger against Japan by people far too young to have memories of China's brutal subjugation by its neighbor, at its most basic level this was a festival of runaway nationalism, of a government-nurtured Chinese-ness.
Declaring themselves to be all one people, the demonstrators proclaimed their love of the police who escorted them as they marched to the consulate, smashing Japanese shops along the way.

Banners extolled Chinese greatness, in contrast to little Japan; chanters called for their homeland to stand tall; and talk was dominated by Chinese "feelings," a word repeated over and over, as if no other feelings counted.
They were old enough to remember just how badly things can go when intoxication is the order of the day, and laws are swept aside by feelings.

I watched the police cars escorting the demonstrators and felt this all looked familiar, like an official event in the Cultural Revolution, but those drew bigger crowds and were more emotional, said Zhu Xueqin, a historian at Shanghai University who emerged from a public library to watch the march go by.
I observed it as a bystander, and the people observing around me looked indifferent, seemingly full of reservations.
Shanghai is the most dazzling symbol of a China that has changed so much since the Cultural Revolution as to be almost unrecognizable.

But in some important ways, most notably the government's will to control information and through it people's minds, the events of the weekend here and their aftermath show that this country has barely changed at all.

The Maoist slogans of 40 years ago have been replaced by anti-Japanese watchwords, and then as now, few of those caught up in the excitement paused to examine the relationship of today's slogans to the truth.
Here were students mouthing such claims as "Japan has never apologized to China," or "Japanese textbooks whitewash history.

Many Japanese textbooks have recently de-emphasized atrocities committed in China, and some have been widely distributed.
But in China, the most tendentious of them is the one cited as a representative sample, although it is used by less than 1 percent of Japanese schools.
Never mind that for over two decades, Japan has been a leading source of development assistance for China -- to the tune of $30 billion in low interest loans -- helping build everything from Shanghai's futuristic airport to expensive highway and water systems in the country's vast, impoverished west.
Few in the Chinese crowds, including many educated in the country's best schools, seemed aware of facts like those, or of any other side to the story save what could be fit into the dichotomy of a China that is essentially good and a Japan that is predatory, evil, conniving or, in a word heard over and over, disgusting."
Like anything that involves information in China, this ignorance seems the result of careful planning.

Since diplomatic relations between the two countries were normalized in 1972, for example, Japanese officials have apologized numerous times to China for the suffering their country inflicted in the 20th century.

In 1995 on the 50th anniversary of the war's end, for example, Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama spoke of the " tremendous damage and suffering" his country had caused, adding "I regard, in a spirit of humanity, these irrefutable facts of history, and express here once again my feelings of deep remorse and state my heartfelt apology."
But China's state-controlled media have usually focused on finding fault with each Japanese pronouncement, sustaining the belief that Japan has indeed never apologized.
The largest question, perhaps, is why China would so carefully sustain anger at Japan.

One possibility is that in recent years, the legitimacy of China's leadership has rested on few things so much as the idea of inevitability -- a destined ascension of the country to prosperous world-power status and a return to the unquestioned pre-eminence in the East that it enjoyed before the 20th century.
In this picture there is little room for Japan, a country that has derailed China's ambitions before, and suddenly seems unwilling to fade.
By midweek, signs were multiplying that China's leaders were rethinking their confrontation with Japan, at least at the level of public relations.

With the ugliness toward their neighbor threatening a loss of international sympathy on other issues, China first reportedly made a quiet offer to repair Japan's damaged consulate, and on Tuesday urged an end to demonstrations.
(STORY CAN END HERE.
OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)
Left aside in the weekend's atmospherics and the effort to dispel them was the question of whether China has done a better job teaching history than its neighbor.

In the West, it is accepted as fact that more Chinese were killed by the policies of Mao Zedong than by the Japanese, including many by summary execution and other atrocities that are glossed over in Chinese textbooks.
In those books, Mao is still treated with reverence.

China also claims never to have seized territory from a neighbor, but China attacked India by surprise in 1962 and the details of other campaigns, from Korea and Xinjiang in the north to Vietnam and Tibet in the country's south and west, are also absent from textbooks.
More remarkable than any glance at the receding past, however, was the way news of the anti-Japanese demonstrations has been treated in China in the here and now.

Chinese authorities televised notices that the protests had not been approved on the eve of Saturday's anti-Japanese demonstration, which served as much as anything else as an announcement of the event.
The news the next day avoided all mention of disorder.
Similarly there were no images of young people pelting the Japanese consulate at their leisure, within arm's reach of paramilitary police.
The seeming contradictions in all of this were not lost on all Chinese, however.
Discussions have raged all week on the Internet, with many questioning their countrymen's behavior and the government's permissiveness toward anti-Japanese violence.
You call yourselves patriotic? Patriotic what?

We don't expect the economic and trade relations between the two countries to be infringed upon, Bo was quoted as saying by the official New China News Agency.

Many youthful Chinese are strongly anti-Japanese, and critics say the country's education system distorts history and demonizes Japan while whitewashing the darker periods of the Communist Party's own history.
The police took the harder line after Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing on Tuesday made the government's first public appeal to end the protests so that diplomats could solve the crisis.
State media outlets, which often take a starkly anti-Japanese position, have shifted tone this week and are now placing greater emphasis on the need for comity between the two Asian powers.
PROTESTERS OUTFLANKED GOVERNMENT CENSORS

The thousands of people who poured onto the streets of China this month for anti-Japanese protests were bound by nationalist anger but also by a more mundane fact: They are China's cell phone and computer generation.
As the protests grew larger and more unruly, China banned almost all coverage in the state media.
But it hardly mattered.
An underground conversation was raging via e-mail, text message and instant online messaging that inflamed public opinion and served as an organizing tool.
Last Friday the government banned the use of text messages or e-mail messages to organize protests.
They are afraid the Chinese people will think, 'OK, today we protest Japan; tomorrow, Japan,' said one Asian diplomat who has watched the protests closely.
But the day after tomorrow, how about we protest against the government?
Few countries censor communications as tightly as China, which has as many as 50,000 people policing the Internet.
Yet China is now the largest cell phone market, with nearly 350 million users, while the number of Internet users is roughly 100 million.
The result is a constant tension between a population hungry for freer communication and a government that regards information control as essential to its power.
Anti-Japanese protesters have been able to spread information and loosely coordinate different marches in a country where political organizing is illegal.
Chain letter e-mail messages and text messages urged people to boycott Japanese products or sign online petitions opposing Japanese ascension to the U.N. Security Council.
Information about protests, including marching routes, was posted online or forwarded by e-mail messages.
Banned video images of protest violence in Shanghai could be downloaded off the Internet.
In Shanghai, local police even sent out a mass text message to cell phone users on the day before that city's raucous protest.
We ask people to express your patriotic passion through the right channel, follow the laws and maintaining order, the message said.
Some marchers interpreted the message as a signal to proceed, while other people took it as a warning.
In the past, the government has shown it can tighten monitoring of these technologies.
Security officials are thought to be able to track a person's whereabouts by intercepting cell phone transmissions.
One reason is that a growing number of young Chinese have multiple e-mail accounts, including with providers based outside China that are not filtered.
EXPERTS SUSPECT AL-QAIDA ALLY IN LONDON ATTACKS
Little is known about the "Secret Organization of al-Qaida in Europe," the group that claimed responsibility for Thursday's terror attacks in London.
What terror experts do know is the attacks have all the markings of terrorists who use the tactics of al-Qaida's leader Osama bin Laden.
The four blasts that rocked London were well-coordinated, timed for a major political event and aimed at undermining the economy.
But it is unclear how connected, if at all, the group is to the upper reaches of al-Qaida.

If a group labels itself al-Qaida, it doesn't necessarily mean that bin Laden is giving it orders, said Michael Swetnam, founder of the Potomac Institute for Policy Studies, a nonpartisan foreign policy think tank based in Virginia.

The group that struck London probably acted independently of al-Qaida's top leaders in the same way that the bombers who attacked commuter trains in Madrid last March acted without the direct support of bin Laden, Swetnam said.
It's a different group, different set of guys, but exactly the same modus operandi, said Swetnam, who also advises the Senate Intelligence Committee on terrorism.
It fits to a T the way al-Qaida works.

The terrorists' goal behind the London bombings likely was to punish Britain for its close relationship with America and its involvement in Iraq, said Milton Bearden, a retired senior C.I.A.official who was the agency's ranking officer in Afghanistan, Pakistan and the Sudan.
He, too, draws a parallel to the Madrid bombings that killed 191 people.

TIMERS USED IN BLASTS, POLICE SAY; PARALLELS TO MADRID FOUND
Don Van Natta Jr.reported from London for this article and Elaine Sciolino from Paris.
Reporting was contributed by David Johnston, David E. Sanger and Scott Shane in Washington, Stephen Grey in London, Tim Golden in New York and Souad Mekhennet in Frankfurt, Germany.

LONDON -- Investigators searching for clues in the attacks here said Thursday that the three bombs used in the Underground appeared to have been detonated by timers, not suicide bombers, and that a fourth device may have been intended for a target other than the city bus that it destroyed.
Senior police officials said they had not received a message claiming responsibility for the attacks from any group, and had made no arrests.
But officials immediately drew parallels between the London bombings and the ones that struck commuter trains in Madrid, Spain, 16 months ago, which were carried out by a Qaida-inspired cell.
By Thursday night, there were far more questions than answers confronting Scotland Yard.
One official said none of the scores of suspected terrorists watched closely in England appeared to be involved.
Police and intelligence officials acknowledged they were taken completely by surprise by the coordinated bombings, even though they had been anticipating a terrorist attack for years.

The officials said there was no warning or even a hint that an attack was imminent among the blizzard of intelligence accumulated in recent days by the Metropolitan Police and MI5, the domestic intelligence services.
There was no intelligence in our possession that these attacks were going to take place today, said Brian Paddick, deputy assistant commissioner of the Metropolitan Police.
We were given no warning from any organization that this was going to happen.

Since Sept. 11, 2001, senior police officials have warned that a large-scale terror attack in Britain was not a matter of if but when, a prediction repeated by a senior police official late last month.
The Joint Terrorist Analysis Center reduced the threat level of a terrorist attack from "severe general" to "substantial" early last month.
There are seven levels to the security scale, with severe general the third most severe and substantial the fourth.
The threat levels are not made public, but they reflect the intelligence on potential attacks and help officials to make decisions about staff levels.
The alert level was not raised to coincide with the opening of the Group of 8 summit meeting in Scotland, officials said.
Paddick and other police officials denied that the lower ranking affected the level of the emergency response to the bombings on Thursday morning.
He also rejected the suggestion that the ranking reflected a conclusion that the terrorist threat had eased here.

Michael Mates, a senior member of Parliament's Intelligence and Security Committee, said, "There was certainly a heightened awareness this week, although it's likely that resources were a bit more focused on the G-8 summit."

Upon his return to London on Thursday afternoon, Prime Minister Tony Blair vowed that the authorities would mount "the most intense police and security investigation to bring those responsible to justice."
Foreign Secretary Jack Straw said the explosions bore "the hallmarks of an al-Qaida-related attack," but police officials stopped short of assigning any blame to a particular group.
A group calling itself the Secret Organization of al-Qaida in Europe announced on a Web site that it was responsible for the bombings.
The announcement also threatened Italy and Denmark, which have provided troops to the U.S.-led coalition fighting in Iraq.
U.S. intelligence officials said they had begun a detailed review of data gathered in the weeks before Thursday's attacks in London to search for possible clues.
Everybody's going back and looking over their reporting to see if we overlooked anything or failed to share it, one senior intelligence official said.
(BEGIN OPTIONAL TRIM.)
Counterterrorism officials in London said they were still trying to determine the type of explosives that were used.
One official said speculated that the No.30 bus whose roof was blown off at 9:47 a.m. in Bloomsbury was demolished accidentally by a suicide bomber.
But another theory gaining momentum was that the bomb exploded prematurely as a bomber was carrying it to an intended target, several U.S. and British counterterrorism officials said.
(END OPTIONAL TRIM.)
The officials said that the three subway bombs appeared to have been detonated by timers, not cell phones or other remote triggers.
The bombs on the trains were believed to be package bombs and are believed to have been left by attackers who fled before they went off.
Officials refused to confirm or deny reports that two unexploded package bombs were recovered from trains.

A senior U.S. intelligence official said that the British had conducted "at least one controlled explosion" of a suspicious package found after the attacks, but said he could not confirm that the package was another bomb.

The bombings in Madrid and London were separated by 16 months, but the attacks on the two major capital cities in the heart of Europe bear eerie similarities, as well as grim lessons for counterterrorism officials.
(BEGIN OPTIONAL TRIM.)
Like Madrid, the attacks on London were aimed not at symbols of power like Big Ben or Westminster Abbey, but at the mundane: ordinary workers making their way to work at the busiest time of the day.
In Madrid, 191 people were killed when 10 bombs ripped through four commuter trains during the morning rush hour.
The effect in both cities was to paralyze the ordinary workings of the city.

British authorities announced that every inch of every subway train in London would be examined to insure that no more explosives had been planted, just as Spanish authorities examined every commuter train wreck.
The explosions were designed to elicit panic among the people, said Gen.Hamidou Laanigri, Morocco's chief of security, in a telephone interview.
Another similarity is that politics may have played a role in the timing.
Thursday was the first day of the G-8 summit, hosted by Blair at Gleneagles, near Edinburgh, Scotland.
At the time of the bombings in Madrid, Spain was only three days away from a close national election.
(END OPTIONAL TRIM.)

Both Spain and Britain sent troops to aid the U.S.-led war in Iraq and the military attack in Afghanistan, although it is not known whether support for U.S. foreign policies played a role in the London attack.

He is accused in the United States of working with Abu Hamza al-Masri, an Egyptian-born cleric embroiled in judicial hearings in Britain to determine whether it will approve his extradition to the United States.
Like Aswat, al-Masri is accused of involvement in the 1999 plot to establish a training camp in Oregon.

Aswat lived in Dewsbury, in northern England, in the same area as some of the four bombers who killed 52 people, along with themselves, in coordinated attacks on the London transportation system on July 7.
Two weeks later, at least four men staged what appeared to be an attempted copycat attack, but their explosives failed to detonate properly.
Aswat was detained in Zambia on July 20.
His deportation had initially been expected last Wednesday, but was delayed while he was being questioned about any ties he may have to terror networks in Pakistan, Zambian officials told Reuters.
The United States had reportedly sought Aswat's arrest earlier while he was in South Africa, but he slipped away through Botswana to Zambia.

In the investigation into the July 7 attacks in London, the police had reportedly initially sought to trace 20 phone calls made by Aswat to establish whether he was linked to the London bombings, but the police here have since played down the possibility of a connection.

The investigation has thrown up many theories, one of them of a link -- as reported in British newspapers on Sunday -- to two Moroccans suspected as Qaida members who were shot dead in Saudi Arabia earlier this year.
The men were identified in news reports as Abdulkarim el-Mejjati and Younis al-Hayyari.
It is under investigation by both your security forces and our security forces, he said.
News agencies also quoted the Saudi foreign minister, Saud al-Faisal, as saying in Riyadh that British and Saudi intelligence officials routinely exchange information.
I'm sure there is some information that may be linked to events in England, he said.
They have also passed some information that was important to some of the incidents here.

The theories surfaced as Britain brought formal charges against Yasin Hassan Omar, a 24-year-old Somali who was arrested in Birmingham after the July 21 bombing attempts and who is accused of conspiracy to commit murder and possession of explosives.
Omar was the first of the main suspects to be charged formally.
He is to appear in court on Monday.
(STORY CAN END HERE.
OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)
The measures could include closing some mosques, banning organizations and deporting some clerics.

She introduced herself to the audience of up to 2,000 mainly young people by saying the clothes she was wearing -- red and black scarves and a long dark blue dress -- were those she wore in captivity, not the orange coveralls given to detainees at the American facilities at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.

It is time to stand up together.
Resistance is our duty.
If you want to make war against Islam," she warned Blair, "I am ready."
However, others, like Sheik Shabir Ally, a cleric from Canada, expressed different views.

And people are using sentences from the Quran out of context.
People have to be careful.
Taje Mustafa, a spokesman for Hizb ut-Tahrir, an organization Blair said he would ban, said: Tony Blair wants to divide the Muslim community into two parts -- into extremists and moderates.
But who is extremist and who is moderate?
At a news conference on Friday, Blair warned that Islamic militants inciting hatred and violence could be deported or held under a form of house arrest known as control orders.
Several Muslims who offered fiery remarks to television interviewers last week are under investigation to determine whether they committed offenses, including treason, in making their statements.
One is Omar Bakri Mohammed, a Syrian-born cleric who led a group called Al Muhajiroun -- now said to have been disbanded -- whose successor organizations Blair also wishes to outlaw.
The debate over militant language extends beyond Muslims.
KATRINA-ADVISORY-NYT
Editors, The New York Times plans a package of stories on Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath for release Thursday, Sept. 1.
KATRINA-RDP (New Orleans) -- A ledeall as estimates of the death toll from the storm and flooding continue to rise.
New Orleans officials try to move out anyone remaining in the city, including a massive relocation of the 20,000 plus refugees at the Superdome, who will be relocated to the Astrodome in Houston.
By Robert D.McFadden, Joseph B. Treaster, Felicity Barringer and others.
With photos and graphics.
An early lede, KATRINA, has moved.
KATRINA-FEDS (Washington) -- A ledeall from Washington.

The Bush administration began mounting a massive federal response on Wednesday to the devastating damage from Hurricane Katrina, deploying active duty military forces to the Gulf Coast to help with rescue and relief missions, authorizing the release of oil from the nation's strategic reserve to blunt the economic effects of the storm and dispatching growing quantities of food, water and medical supplies to the region.

President Bush returned to the White House from his vacation home in Texas to oversee the effort, getting a view of the damage en route as Air Force One altered its route to take him on a low-altitude pass over New Orleans and other stricken areas in Louisiana and Mississippi.
He will speak later in the Rose Garden.
By Richard W.Stevenson.
With

BUSH-ASSESS (Washington) -- Not since he sat silently in a classroom in a Sarasota, Fla., elementary school as the World Trade Center burned and collapsed a thousand miles away has President Bush faced a test quite like the one he returned to Washington to confront on Wednesday afternoon.
But when the enemy is nature and the scene is spread over several states, the challenge is quite different.

And to complicate matters, Bush confronts this disaster at a time that his political capital is depleted, his poll ratings are at record lows and even some in the White House worry that Bush, on the last days of a month-long vacation, appeared out of position -- and perhaps too detached from the disaster unfolding along the Gulf Coast.
A news analysis by David E.Sanger.
KATRINA-EVACUATE (New York) -- A rescue effort is under way to move the refugees from the Superdome to the Astrodome in Houston.
Officials hope to also move anyone else still remaining in the city.
By Joseph B.Treaster.
KATRINA-RESCUE (Gulfort, Miss.) -- A report on the massive airlift rescue going on in Mississippi where -- it turns out -- people have been stranded on rooftops and islands for three days.
By Shaila Dewan and Kate Zernike.

KATRINA-LAWLESS (Dateline TK) -- With law officers and National Guardsmen focused on saving lives, looters around the city spent another day brazenly ransacking stores for food, clothing, appliances -- and guns.
(Summary from wires) By Felicity Barringer, Joseph B. Treaster and Jere Longman.
From the Business Desk:
KATRINA-OIL (Undated) -- For the first time since the 1970s, gasoline lines reappeared in some corners of the country.

Three days after Hurricane Katrina dealt a devastating blow to the nation's largest energy hub, the worst-case scenario was quickly becoming a reality: Oil prices surging to stratospheric levels, services stations running out of gasoline, drivers waiting in line for dwindling supplies.
The storm, which submerged New Orleans as it slammed into the Gulf Coast, also impaired the country's energy industry from Houston to New England.
Around the region, in Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama, power supplies were down, refineries went underwater, and nearly two dozens offshore platforms were submerged.
The impact is likely to be widely felt across the nation for months.
By Jad Mouawad, Simon Romero and Vikas Bajaj.
With photo and graphic.

KATRINA-TELECOMS (Undated) -- A look at the communications situation in the disaster area: status of telephone lines, cell-phone and text-messaging service; how people are getting information in and out, and how companies are going about restoring service.
By Ken Belson.
KATRINA-CARGO (Undated) -- New Orleans was a key port for many raw materials needed to run the economy -- steel, fruits and vegetables, and chemicals.
By Alexei Barrionuevo and Melanie Warner.
KATRINA-POWER-LINES (Undated) -- As utilities in the South begin the task of rebuilding power lines, companies from other regions of the country mobilize to help.
By Barnaby J. Feder and Jennifer Boyot.
From the Culture Desk:
NEW-ORLEANS-MUSIC (Undated) -- A Critic's Notebook: New Orleans is a legendary center of American music.
It's thought of as a jazz hotspot -- the birthplace of both Dixieland and Wynton Marsalis -- and that's all it once was.
The contemporary New Orleans music scene is at least as important for hip-hop as it is for jazz.
What it mostly is is singular: a place where musicians play a gig in one club at 7:30, cross the street to play in another club at 9, then cross again to play a third club at 11.
By Ben Ratliff.

KATRINA-TV (Undated) -- For the broadcast networks and cable news channels, the logistics of covering Katrina have been more difficult than covering Iraq or even the recent tsunami because of the almost complete lack of available power.
By Bill Carter.
From the Science desk:
KATRINA-HOSPITALS (Undated) -- Flooded and otherwise damaged hospitals are overwhelmed.
How governments at all levels are responding to the health emergency.
By Alan Feuer and Lawrence K.Altman.
KATRINA-LEVEES (Undated) -- More on how the two big levees breached and what must be done to fix them.
Were they allowed to deteriorate needlessly? By Andrew C. Revkin, Cornelia Dean and Chris Drew.
KATRINA-WATER (Undated) -- "Toxic gumbo": A look at what's in the water covering much of New Orleans, and what sort of residue it will leave when things finally dry out.
By Kenneth Chang.
KATRINA-COPING (Undated) -- The psychological fallout.
Coping with floods is usually more difficult than coping with other natural disasters.
How and why.
By Benedict Carey.
And from the Style Desk's Home section:

KATRINA-WARD (Washington) -- Sitting safely in Washington, I am watching harrowing footage shot from helicopters above the Ninth Ward of New Orleans, submerged under 14 feet of water when the Mississippi thundered through the breached levee at the Industrial Canal, destroying everything in its swirling waters.
My home is there, a West Indian-style plantation house built in 1826, standing as an ancient relic amid a maze of wooden houses a century younger.
Some are classic bungalows, but most are distinctly New Orleans building types, with fanciful names like shotguns and camelbacks.
I watch as a neighbor is rescued from his rooftop, the water swirling only a few feet below him.
Dazed, he has just emerged from his attic, wriggling through a hole he hacked in the roof, to be swooped up on a swinging rope.
He is safe.
Scores of others aren't.

Tuesday night the mayor reported bodies floating through the streets of the Ninth Ward, bodies of the poor blacks and whites, creoles of color, and sprinkling of artists of every type who inhabit this deepest-dyed old New Orleans neighborhood.
By S. Frederick Starr.

KATRINA-ROOFS (Undated) -- On Tuesday night, Reed Kroloff, the dean of the architecture school at Tulane University in New Orleans, was holed up in a hotel in Houston watching footage of his city -- and possible his century-old Victorian house -- being walloped by Hurricane Katrina.
The roof might be gone, or a giant oak tree has crashed through a window, Kroloff said in a phone interview.
Like many residents of New Orleans who fled, Kroloff was imagining the worst, and with good reason.
Although he had tried to secure his house by covering his windows and French doors with plywood, and closing shutters with bag ties, strong winds can wreak havoc with such measures in seconds.
Structural engineers say roofs are weak spots when it comes to high winds because when they hit a house an uplift is created that can tear away shingles and separate the roof from the rafters.
Winds also create horizontal pressure, called shear.
If a house isn't properly secured, the combination of uplift and shear can sometimes tip the house over.
By Ernest Beck.
