EATING WELL: FILLING YOU UP WITH DIET IDEAS
Every 10 years or so, it seems, the nation's anxiety over dieting builds to a peak and a realization hits home: Whatever weight-loss program has so recently captivated us is wrong.
Fat might be good for us now, some people say, and carbohydrates bad.
Not so long ago, the opposite was true.
Probably it will be again.
These things tend to work as pendulums do.
Diet fads and government guidelines over the last quarter century have not helped to produce a slimmer America.
We are a fatter nation now, on average, than we were in the 1970s.
What diet fads have given us are short-term losses and long-term gains because few if any of them emphasize a key fact: If you consume more calories than you expend, you will gain weight.
Despite what the opposing sides in this long-running debate assert, it doesn't make much difference where the calories come from.
A successful dieter needs to burn them.
At the two poles of the current debate over diet are the protein- and fat-rich Atkins diet and the high-fiber, low-fat program put forward by Dr. Dean Ornish.
In the middle sits the Agriculture Department's Food Guide Pyramid, which tells consumers to reduce fats, but allows them to increase carbohydrates significantly.
The Atkins diet doesn't seem to restrict calories.
In fact it does.
The diet makes it difficult to eat as many calories as one gets from the carbohydrates that contain no fiber: sugar, white flour, pasta and the like.
Filled with steak, in other words, you're simply too ``full'' to eat dessert.
The Ornish diet is at the other extreme, saying you can eat all you want, but only of foods very low in fat and very high in fiber, making it a low-calorie diet because fiber acts like fat.
It fills you up.
It all seems very simple: Eat fat and protein (Atkins) and a process takes place that most of us don't understand, and you lose weight.
Barely eat any fat and stick to complex carbohydrates and the weight will pour off (Ornish).
In both cases it will, at least for the short term; there are no studies to show whether the Atkins diet, in particular, is safe over a lifetime.
Ornish's diet is designed mainly for people who have clogged arteries or have had heart attacks.
Using his strict regimen, some of these people have been able to reverse the course of heart disease.
Whether the diet is the most desirable for people who are simply overweight has not been determined.
There are no lifetime studies.

Caught directly between these two diet extremes is the Food Guide Pyramid, which tells us that fat should be reduced to 30 percent of calories consumed, and that carbohydrates should be increased significantly.
It does not, however, distinguish clearly enough between complex carbohydrates like whole grains, fruits and vegetables and refined ones like sugar.
Refined carbohydrates turn into blood glucose quite quickly, which in turn drives up insulin production, which lowers blood sugar and _ guess what? _ makes us hungry again.
The result is one of unintended consequences.
Since the late 1980s this government-approved diet appears to have provided people with permission to eat as many carbohydrates as they want, no matter the source.
And many of them have.
Over the last 10 or 15 years people not only have continued to consume the same amount of fat but they have also added 200 to 400 calories more a day from carbohydrates.
The result is what experts are describing as an epidemic of obesity.
With the two hats that it wears _ one to protect consumer health and the other to help farmers sell food _ it cannot tell us to eat fewer calories.
That would fly in the face of its mandate to help farmers.
There is another unintended consequence of the government's advice.
``They knew exactly what to do with it.
They said, `You want us to sell foods that are low fat or no fat?
Sure, but you didn't say anything about calories!'
And so the calories remained the same.''
Remember Snackwells, the wildly popular cookie of the 1990s?
It had no fat but plenty of refined carbohydrates.
The ``no fat'' label made many people think it was all right to eat an entire box.
In one sitting.
No fat, but the cookies still had plenty of calories; they just came from a different source.
At the same time that people increased their consumption of carbs, serving sizes were rising dramatically.
Mindy Hermann, a registered dietician in Mount Kisco, N.Y., said: ``Everything is supersized.
A single serving of a soft drink was once six ounces; today it is 20 ounces.
A bagel no longer weighs two ounces; it weighs four or six.
Hamburgers come in double and triple sizes with two buns, twice as much cheese and a high-calorie sauce.''
``The average American child sees 10,000 food ads on television each year,'' he said.
There are places you never expected to eat, Brownell said, like gas stations and drug stores and shopping malls.
Snack food and soft drink machines are installed in American schools, even as physical education in schools is waning.
Add to these difficulties Brownell's view of a toxic environment in which food is shoved at people from every angle.
As ever, losing weight is not easy.
Keeping it off is even harder.
SWEETIE, WHO'S SLIMMING YOU THIS SEASON?

You can stare all day at the stylists, photographers and designers who will be flocking in and out of the Bryant Park tents for the New York fashion shows this week and still miss the accessory of the season.
It's not some luscious, tangible object like Marc Jacobs' vintage-looking military jacket with chevrons and pewter buttons.
The accessory of the moment is the diet.
In the front row and backstage, count on the chatter to be peppered with talk of points and portions.
Text messages will fly with the titles of diet books and ``natural'' appetite suppressants like Xenadrine and Hydroxycut.
The names and numbers of obscure doctors will be scribbled messily inside Smythson leather-bound notebooks.

And in some Celine Boogie bags, you might find a stainless-steel thermos of bancha twig tea, a Japanese concoction favored by macrobiotic eaters, who take great pains to explain that they are balancing their acidity with a judicious splash of alkaline.
Or something.
Like label groupies devoted slavishly to one designer for a season before moving on to the next hot thing, fashion and Hollywood folk have fallen for fad diets and are enticing friends to join them.
They are creating mini-societies, each with a common devotion to one regime, and along with it the giddy sense of being in on something new, of belonging to a group that's cool.
Can there be any news in the fact that fashion and body-obsessed celebrities are chattering about diets?

The real stop-the-presses story would be if the fashionistas gathering this week in New York for their semiannual round of designer shows and latte bingeing had renounced their quasi-pathological obsession with weight.
Diets have always been woven into the life of the image-conscious, but it used to be something you didn't admit _ like the model ``sent away'' to drop 5 pounds before she could work again.
Now diets are discussed openly, unashamedly, cheerfully.
Having a diet is almost ...de rigueur.
``Diets had a connotation of shame before,'' said Brana Wolf, a prominent fashion stylist.
``Now it's, like, Hey, who's your doctor?
Today it's a swapping of information like never before.''

The latest trend among the style-setters and celebrities is to claim membership in a diet tribe _ a group whose individuals happily share their shortcuts, chemical-free protein bars and secret splurges.
While Gwyneth Paltrow and Madonna were performing onstage in London last season, they bonded over a macrobiotic regimen featuring the green bancha twig tea.
Jennifer Aniston reportedly turned the cast of ``Friends'' on to her Zone program.

The model Amber Valetta and Orlando Pita, a hairstylist, have introduced a bevy of fashion pals, including the designer Narciso Rodriguez and the photographer Steven Meisel, to a New York chiropractor and nutritionist named Charles Passler.
``Because somebody says it works, other people try it,'' Nestle said.
It's not a normal eating pattern to exclude whole food groups from what you eat, so you eventually stop and gain the weight back and start all over again.''
Unlike the situation in fashion, where innovation is the relentless mantra, the most popular diets aren't necessarily the newest ones.

Despite the endless stream of newfangled ways to count calories and cut fat, it's the vintage systems like Weight Watchers, the Atkins program, macrobiotic diets and even Dolly Parton's program of eating many tiny meals that seem to have the strongest pull.
Maybe that is because, just like fashion trends, diets slip in and out of vogue.
And, just like the Marc Jacobs military jacket, the vintage aspect of a diet can hold a lot of appeal.
``It's funny that these old-school diets keep coming back,'' said Angela Mariani, a fashion publicist who has done the 20-year-old Herbalife diet twice.
``People remember their mothers doing Atkins.''

These days Atkins, whose protein diet allows the consumption of fat but not carbohydrates, is experiencing a somewhat triumphant revival: the latest edition of his 1972 book, updated and retitled ``Dr.Atkins' New Diet Revolution,'' has been hovering at or near the top of The New York Times' list of best-selling advice, how-to and miscellaneous paperbacks for 275 weeks.
The Atkins method isn't the only one that has captivated the fashion and Hollywood crowds.
Thanks to Rosie O'Donnell and her former publicist Jennifer Glaisek, Weight Watchers has also gripped Hollywood.
Over a year ago, O'Donnell conscripted her entire staff to follow the regime as she did so herself and discussed it on the air.
Soon a dozen of Glaisek's colleagues at the powerful public relations firm of PMK/HBH were also showing up for weekly weigh-ins at the offices of the ``Rosie'' show.
``It was the visual of Jennifer Glaisek,'' said Toby Fleischman, a PMK/HBH publicist who joined the group.
I did Weight Watchers when I was 14, and it was a very humiliating experience, but this time Rosie was often at the meetings, and there was a great sense of camaraderie.''
The group, all women, stuck together in the Weight Watchers meetings for only about six months, just long enough to squeeze into Seven low-rider jeans.
Like fashion trends, diet tribes often maintain a life span of only that long.
``It died off around the holidays,'' Fleischman said.
``The career lifestyle of a publicist just isn't that conducive to the points system.''
But as with any trend, denim or otherwise, there is always something new to move along to, even if it isn't necessarily so new.
The Zone, a diet created by Dr.Barry Sears in the late 1980s and introduced to a wider public in a best-selling book in 1995, has kept a firm grip on a group of Hollywood devotees for seven years.
The only problem is that after a while, some people grow sick of the food.
``Anyway, I hear Sugar Busters is on its way back,'' he said of a diet that restricts sugar and refined carbohydrates.
``It's the Dolly Parton portion control diet,'' he said.
``You just eat fist-size portions of the food you'd normally eat.
It's a very 1950s way of eating.''
(STORY CAN END HERE.
OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)
Not everyone following a diet is trying to lose weight.
Many fashion professionals and celebrities seek out diet doctors or nutritionists for advice on how they can eliminate stress, stop smoking or generally change an unhealthy lifestyle.
That was the case for Gwyneth Paltrow, who, after five bouts with a nasty flu virus, decided it was time to take steps.
Her yoga teacher, Eddie Stern, recommended a nutritionist who prescribed a macrobiotic diet.
``I was working on `Possession' in London at the time,'' Paltrow said.
``And it's very hard to avoid dairy and meat there, so I had all this stuff brought over, and it happened to be macrobiotic.
SIZING UP THE TOP DIETS
Don't you know it's the season of New Year's resolutions?
Promises to the self to abstain from unhealthy behavior and to be a better person?
Or maybe lose a few pounds and eat healthy?
Or heck, maybe just try not to gain another five pounds this year?
Easier said than done, no doubt, especially once you brush the doughnut crumbs off the front of your shirt and take a stroll down the diet and fitness aisle of your neighborhood bookstore.
One book tells you to eat fat, the other says fat will kill you.
One says to cut back on carbohydrates, the other says carbs are the only way to go.

We thought we'd take a look at five of the most popular diets (not the craziest ones -- you won't read about colonics and blood types here), take a look at who is doing them and what the experts think.
Although all these diets vary in ways great and small, it's worth noting that they all stress the importance of exercise, so no tossing out the exercise bike with the doughnuts.

Dr.Adam Drewnowski, director of nutritional sciences at the University of Washington, and registered dietician Kathleen Mahan, author and personal nutritionist at Seattle's Nutrition By Design, weigh in on a handful of the most popular diets.
But they're willing to indulge us here.
``The Carbohydrate Addict's Diet''by Dr.Rachael F. Heller and Dr.Richard F.Heller
(Signet, 322 pages, $7.99)
Who's doing it: Oprah Winfrey.
Promises, promises: Weight loss, fewer mood swings and more energy.
The scoop: That some overweight people release too much insulin after eating high-carb meals.
This increases the appetite, resulting in overeating.
The idea is to eat fewer carbs at two meals and have one ``reward'' meal each day.
What is this world coming to?
Furthermore, there's no snacking at all between meals.
And you have to eat your reward meal within one hour (so no splitting up that bowl of popcorn!)
Perfect for you if: You want to have your (flourless) cake and eat it too -- during your 60-minute reward meal window.
Expert opinion: Drewnowski -- First off, he said there's no way you can talk people into using up their reward meal with broccoli and such.
``Number one, the glycemic index of bread and boiled carrots is higher than a Snickers bar,'' said Drewnowski, explaining that the fat in the Snickers bar lowers its glycemic index.
``Number two, if you eat a whole meal and everything gets all mixed up ..the glycemic index of the whole meal will not equal the sum of its parts.''
In other words, it's impossible for the average person to calculate the glycemic index of a meal.
And anyway, Drewnowski said there's no scientificexplanation for why high insulin levels would cause us to crave specific types of carbohydrates.
Even so, there's something to this idea of carbohydrate addiction.
``Sugar/fat mixtures, yes, these are the foods that lots of people have trouble with, interestingly enough, mostly women,'' Drewnowski said.
Chocolate, cake and ice cream always show up on the list of foods women crave.
And while chocolate does show up on the list of male cravings, they generally struggle more with protein, salt and fat mixtures -- hamburgers, pizza, meatloaf, that sort of thing.
Ice cream also shows on the men's list.
Male and female rats indicate similar preferences, so don't go blaming societal gender roles for this stuff.
``The advantage of it is that it doesn't take things away from people.
In other words, they know they can have their carbohydrates during a certain period of time in a day,'' said Mahan.
``The disadvantage is that I think with eating all the carbs in a short period of time, your body is going to have to release a lot insulin to deal with it.''
``Eat More, Weigh Less''by Dr.Dean Ornish
(Quill, 448 pages, $15)
Who's doing it:
Well, no one famous has made a point of endorsing it, but the Swedish Medical Center's Heart Institute offers a Dean Ornish Program for Reversing Heart Disease.
Promises, promises: Ornish says a vegetarian (or near vegetarian) diet low in fats and high in complex carbs can reverse prostate cancer, shrink tumors and help maintain a healthy weight.
The scoop: Ornish doesn't see his diet as one of deprivation -- he touts complex carbohydrates, beans and legumes, fruits and vegetables.
Fats (nuts, seeds, meats, oils) are out, as are dairy products, eggs, sugars, honey, white flour, salt, white rice and alcohol.
Even non-fat dairy products and low-fat processed foods are to be eaten in moderation.
You are encouraged to meditate.
The poop: One gin martini with a couple of olives and you've blown the whole thing!
Perfect for you if: You derive sustenance from your own self-righteousness.
Expert opinion: Drewnowski -- ``I think it's lucky that Dean Ornish combines his diet with meditation and prayer because that will help -- it's not a very tasty diet.''
That said, he adds that ``over-fed males of 50'' with high cholesterol levels and other cardiac issues will benefit from Ornish's diet.
``This is a clinical intervention type diet which is fine if you are a cardiac patient ...but it's not nutritionally balanced for a growing adolescent, a pregnant woman or a healthy, active adult.''
Mahan -- ``The problem with that diet is that it's so restrictive in fat that it causes you to restrict even good fats,'' says Mahan.
``Not only is fat essential in the body, but the fats available in olive oil and avocados and nuts are good for you.
You need more than 10 percent of fat in your diet -- not saturated fat, but the good fats.''

``He's talking more about healing the heart and the spiritual aspects of heart disease, not just the physical disease,'' says Mahan, adding that Ornish's diet, in general, is ``the one approach that's actually been shown to reverse plaque buildup in the arteries.''
``The Macrobiotic Way''by Michio Kushi
(Avery, 251 pages, $12.95)
Who's doing it: Madonna, Gwyneth Paltrow and ex-Spice Girl Geri Halliwell.
Promises, promises: High in fiber, the diet is supposed to prevent colon cancer.
The scoop: The macrobiotic diet is based on eating whole foods (as opposed to processed foods, heavy on preservatives and additives), organic grains as well as leafy, root, ground and sea vegetables.
Kushi recommends a diet of 50 to 60 percent whole cereal grains, 5 to 10 percent soups, 20 to 30 percent vegetables and 5 to 10 percent beans and sea vegetables (a variety of seaweed).

The poop: The no-no list is long: No dairy, red meat, poultry, cane or beet sugar, salmon, mackerel, tuna, swordfish, ginseng, commercial soy sauces and salt, mayonnaise, cashews, Brazil nuts, avocados, dates, figs, lemons, limes, oranges, mangoes, pineapple, hard liquor, wine, black tea, coffee, soda, tap water ...plus there are specific ways to cook everything -- pressure-cooking, picking and water-saute9ing among them.
Perfect for you if: You have a personal chef or have nothing better to do than fret over your next meal.
On a more serious level, Drewnowski worried that someone on this diet is looking for something more than a nutritionally balanced diet.
``To some extent, this is not a diet, this is a monastic way of life.
The people who adopt this don't do it for nutrition purposes, but for psychological reasons.
They need the discipline to get on with their life,'' said Drewnowski, adding that seeking this sort of diet might be a symptom of an eating disorder.
``Diana Vreeland said that elegance is refusal ...the macrobiotic diet is basically about refusal.''
But the diet does have its drawbacks.
Even then, I'm not sure you could get enough.''
``Enter the Zone''by Barry Sears
(Harper Collins, 328 pages, $25).
Who's doing it: Jennifer Aniston, Brad Pitt, Rene9e Zellweger, Sandra Bullock ...the list goes on and on.
Promises, promises: Lose weight, live longer, be fertile and pain free!

The scoop: Eat a diet consisting of 40 percent carbohydrates (veggies, not bread and pasta), 30 percent fat (the good stuff, like olive oil) and 30 percent protein (lean meats and fish) at every meal.
Eat up to six meals a day rather than gorging on larger portions.
The poop: The only grain allowed is slow-cooked oatmeal (say goodbye to bread, breadsticks and breadcrumbs).
But compared to the macrobiotic diet, the Zone is wild and crazy in terms of what it allows you to eat.
Perfect for you if: You have time to plan your meals well ahead of time or are rich enough to have Zone meals delivered to you.
(A local company called ZoneSeattle has been doing just that since August.
For more information: 206-236-9663, 1-866-317-9663 or www.the-zone-diet.com.)
Combining carbs, proteins and fats like the Zone causes a ``lower and slower release of insulin,'' which she says causes less fat depositing and more fat burning.
The Zone is also good because ``it forces people to look at the protein content in their diet -- and most people eat way too many carbs.''
Adding a little fat to every meal balances out the meal, keeping us satisfied longer because fat stays in the stomach the longest.
But, she cautioned that you can still go wrong.
``One of the problems is that you can still get too many calories -- it's not just proportion but portion control.''
``It's a very doable diet, but you cut out the cheap beans and grains, and your frisee lettuce and your arugula cost more,'' he said, adding that this is basically a diet for the upper-middle class.
``But there's nothing wrong with it, nutritionally.''
``Dr.Atkins' New Diet Revolution''
Dr.Robert C.Atkins
(Harper Collins, 540 pages, $13.95)
Who's doing it: Dennis Franz, Al Gore, Catherine Zeta-Jones.
Promises, promises: Lose weight, burn fat, reverse Type II diabetes, and never feel hungry or deprived.
The scoop: Developed by Atkins in 1972, the diet gives you license to eat cheese, meat, eggs and, well, mostly cheese, meat and eggs.
Atkins maintains that consuming sugars and other carbohydrates inhibits the body from burning fat.
By depriving your body of carbs, you force it into ketosis -- the burning of stored fat.
And the diet is high in animal fat, which can be tough on the kidneys.
Speaking of animals, and their fat, this diet is not doable for vegetarians.
But most importantly, ask yourself: Is life without pain au chocolat worth living?
Perfect for you if: You were a Tyrannosaurus rex in a past life and have little use for vegetables.

Expert opinion: Drewnowski -- ``He exaggerates the amount of fat that you can eat,'' said Drewnowski, pointing out that the Atkins diet includes about five time the amount of cholesterol recommended for a healthy diet.
``It has the potential to increase your cholesterol, but if you lose weight, your cholesterol could drop, so it could balance out.
At what point things balance out, I don't know.
There's not enough research on that,'' said Drewnowski, adding that whether you're talking about fats, proteins or carbs, at the end of the day, it's the calories that matter.

``The idea is that this works through reducing caloric intake through eating nothing but proteins and fat,'' he said, referring to the fact that proteins and fats are more filling than most carbohydrates.
``It's not what you eat, it's how much you eat.''
However, adding carbs to proteins generally makes them taste better, leading us to eat more of them.
``Bitter chocolate is fat -- there's no sugar, so when you eat bitter chocolate, you're eating fat, not sugar and you don't eat so much.
But the second you add sugar to it, you can eat it like bread.''
Mahan -- ``People do lose weight on it, and a recent study has shown that people's cholesterol doesn't go up.''

She added that the diet is good because it makes people focus on the amount of protein in their diet, but ultimately, she would recommend that Atkins followers focus on lean proteins rather than steaks and full-fat cheeses.
``The fact is that people eat high-fat pork rinds -- they sell them in nine different flavors -- and the reason is the Atkins diet, because they are carbohydrate free!''
Putting the squeeze on diet scams
Did you know you can ``lose from two to five pounds a week eating yummy Peanut Butter Snacks?''
Have you heard about the brand new, revolutionary natural energy tablet that lets you ``Eat All Day and Melt Away?''
Did you see the guy who went from looking like Gerard Depardieu to Arnold Schwarzenegger in 65 days?
And what about that diet that is ``chemically and enzyme balanced'' to help you lose 10 pounds in three days?
These claims and hundreds of others like them are included in Internet advertisements, and Becky Merk, a dietitian at Miami Valley Hospital, has probably heard of most of them.
She teaches a 12-week weight-control course for Miami Valley employees, and participants in the course have tried just about every supposed miracle body reformation scheme ever offered.
``Slim Fast.
LA Weight Loss.
The Hollywood Diet.
Sugar Busters.
The Zone.
The Atkins Diet.
People tell me they've tried all of them,'' Merk said.

``A lot of people are making a lot of promises about weight loss, but even if you manage to lose weight with one of these programs, it's very hard to maintain your new weight without making some basic lifestyle changes.''
Television, magazines, newspapers, billboards and the Internet are teeming with come-ons for weight-loss systems that promise dramatic results with little effort.
According to the Federal Trade Commission, which tries to enforce restrictions on fraudulent diet product claims, about 50 million Americans will go on a diet to lose weight this year.
Of those 50 million only about 2.5 million will succeed in losing weight and keeping it off.

And the fact that so many people keep paying billions of hard-earned dollars for special foods, supplements, books, equipment and seminars that don't work shows how desperate and gullible people can be, says author and fitness advocate Stephen Grisanti.
``Unfortunately, it's no different than the Lotto.
People want to get rich quick and easy, but how many people do you know who have won the Lotto?
They want to lose weight quick and easy, too.
That's not the way it works, though.''
Grisanti last year wrote ``Industry of Illusions: Health & Fitness Industry Scams, Frauds, Fakes and Personal Trainers Exposed.''
Grisanti said his father was a martial arts expert and amateur boxing coach, so he became interested in physical fitness young and maintained his interest through adulthood.
``The people who need the most help are the ones getting scammed,'' Grisanti said.
``You see a lot of products advertising that they are `scientifically tested' or `medically proven.
' It's not science.
What it is is science fiction.''
Merk said the truth is that the only way to lose weight is to burn more calories than you consume.
That means exercising more and eating less.

Miami Valley Hospital has a wellness center with exercise equipment for its employees, and Merk teaches a 12-week weight reduction course that focuses on eating a healthy, balanced diet, exercising and modifying the behaviors that lead to overeating or inactivity.
She said most diet advertising talks about quick weight loss but says little or nothing about the more important issue of long-term weight management.
``What you lose is likely to be mostly water weight, and you're going to quickly gain that back.''
Merk said the first step in starting a weight-loss program should be a consultation with your doctor, not buying something based on an advertisement.

Some people think herbal products are safe because they're supposedly natural, but Merk said herbal products often contain active ingredients that can be harmful or that can interact badly with other medications.
``Also herbal products aren't regulated by the (Food and Drug Administration).
``You should be getting your nutrients from the foods you eat anyway, not from supplements.''
Melinda Abney, who completed Miami Valley's weight management course last year, said she had tried just about every type of diet available at one time or another, but none of them worked for long.
``You may be able to say, `I'm never going to eat bread again,' but how realistic is that?'' Abney said.
``I was on a diet once where you had to fast on Wednesdays.
I don't know what was special about Wednesday, but that was the day you didn't eat.
``Any of those diets were fine as long as you could keep them up, but they all got boring after a while.
When you're an old married woman with kids and a real life, you can't spend all your time thinking about a diet.
And as soon as I stopped following the diet, all the weight would come back.''
Abney, who works for the Miami Valley human resources department, said she has been dieting since high school with little lasting success.
She was able to lose 10 pounds last year after taking the hospital's weight management course and hasn't gained the weight back.
In addition to watching what she eats, Abney now exercises regularly, including mid-morning treadmill walks at the wellness center.
``One of my activities is going out Rollerblading with my kids,'' she said.
``I don't think of it as exercise.
I'm taking time to get out and play.''
James Cummings writes for the Dayton Daily News.
E-mail: james_cummings(at)coxohio.com.
Helpful hints from the FTC
The agency suggests that before you spend money on products or programs that promise fast or easy weight loss, weigh the claims and consider these tips:
``Lose 30 Pounds in Just 30 Days.
'' As a rule, the faster you lose weight, the more likely you are to gain it back.
Also, fast weight loss could harm your health.
Unless your doctor advises it, don't look for programs that promise quick weight loss.
``Lose All the Weight You Can for Just $39.99.'' Some weight-loss programs have hidden costs.
For example, some don't advertise the fact that you must buy their prepackaged meals that cost more than the program fees.
Before you sign up for any weight-loss program, ask for all the costs.
Get them in writing.
``Lose Weight While You Sleep.''
Claims for diet products and programs that promise weight loss without effort are phony.
``Lose Weight and Keep It Off for Good.
'' Be suspicious about products promising long-term or permanent weight loss.
To lose weight and keep it off, you must change how you eat and how much you exercise.
``John Doe Lost 84 Pounds in Six Weeks.''
Don't be misled by someone else's weight-loss claims.
Even if the claims are true, someone else's success may have little relation to your own chances of success.
``Scientific Breakthrough ...Medical Miracle.''
There are no miracle weight-loss products.
To lose weight, you must reduce your intake of calories and increase your physical activity.
Be skeptical about exaggerated claims.
To file a complaint with the FTC or to get free information on consumer issues, visit www.ftc.gov or call toll-free, (877) FTC-HELP (382-4357); TTY: (866) 653-4261.
Story Filed By Cox Newspapers
For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service
DIETS BY THE DOZEN
Diets were first documented about 170 years ago, but who knows?
Maybe Eve was eating fruit because she wanted to look good in her fig leaf.
Folklore has it that in 1087, William the Conqueror discovered that he was too fat to ride his horse, so he climbed in bed and went on a liquid diet.
His liquid of choice was alcohol, but if the tale is true, it may be the first known instance of someone changing his food intake to lose weight.
Because William died from injuries suffered during a riding accident, one can speculate that he was successful in dropping enough bulk to mount his horse again.
As humans became more knowledgeable about producing and storing food, they indulged themselves.
The industrial revolution contributed to more food on our plates and more circumference to our waistlines.
Eventually, people started looking for ways to take the pounds back off, and diets have been in fashion ever since.
It's estimated that Americans will spend $40 billion on diets this year, according to the National Eating Disorders Association.
They are not realistic because they are so hard to stick to, she said.

Most are not meant to be followed for life, so most people gain the weight back when they quit them.
There is no easy way out of being overweight," she said.
It still comes down to following the Food (Guide) Pyramid guidelines, proper portion control and regular exercise three to four times a week.
The evolution of trend diets in American history has picked on just about every food group and even, in some cases, a specific food.
Here's a brief look at a few of the more noteworthy diets.
The first documented diet in the United States was the bland diet, advocated by Presbyterian minister Sylvester Graham in the 1830s.
His diet consisted of coarse-ground whole wheat flour baked into flat bread, which became known as graham crackers.
The low-carb diet craze of recent years isn't as new as people might think.
In the late 1850s, an English casket maker named William Banting found that he was so overweight he could no longer tie his own shoes or navigate stairs.

Fed up, so to speak, he developed the first documented low-carb plan, published as "Letter of Corpulence," in 1862 after losing 50 pounds in a year's time on a diet of lean meat, dry toast, eggs, green vegetables and unsweetened fruit.
The theory behind "Fletcherizing" was that chewing food until it was liquid resulted in less overeating and improved digestion and nutrient absorption.
Some accounts hold that novelist Henry James and oil baron John D. Rockefeller were Fletcherizers.
Counting calories came along in the 1920s, and the 1950s saw the birth of the diet pill Dexedrine.
The stimulant is no longer prescribed because of harmful side effects.
The most fruitful plan of the 1960s was Weight Watchers, established by Jean Nidetch using a diet plan devised by Dr.Norman Jollife of the New York City Department of Public Health.
By the end of that decade, the group had grossed $8 million.
Today it's a $1 billion a year business with the Duchess of York, Sarah Ferguson, its leading spokesperson.
The early 1970s saw vegetarianism launched, followed closely by publication of "The Diet Revolution" by Dr.Robert Atkins.
His low-carb diet book raised skeptical eyebrows in the medical community.
Twenty years later he tried again with "The New Diet Revolution," published in 1994, and the idea caught on like wildfire.
The book sold 10 million copies and remains one of the top-50 best-selling books of all time.
The craze led to Atkins food products and special Atkins sections on many current restaurant menus.
Critics maintain that long-term effects of the diet include heart and kidney problems.
The '80s gave us Jenny Craig, and the '90s brought Slim-Fast shakes, the Zone Diet and Sugar Busters.
In 2003, The South Beach Diet tweaked the already prevalent low-carb diets.
The low-carb craze seems to be fading, however, according to a survey by New York market research firm NPD Group.
NPD found that the number of low-carbonistas peeked in March 2004, when 9 percent of Americans were following the popular diets.
By September, the number had dropped to 4.6 percent.
So, what might be next on the minds of waist-watching Americans?
The early favorite seems to be The Satiety Diet, according to a December 2004 report by the online health site WebMD.
The diet consists of eating more of the foods that make you feel full but don't make you fat and is also called "volumetrics" in the report.
The plan also recommends dishes rich in water content, such as soups, stews and casseroles but, unlike many diets, does not exclude any specific foods.
They don't teach healthy eating habits and are usually not nutritionally balanced.
For comprehensive diet information and analysis checkout The Diet Channel at www.thedietchannel.com.
John Allen writes for the Waco Tribune-Herald.
E-mail: jallen@wacotrib
The ``somebody spiked my drink'' dodge is passe among doped athletes in the Ripped Fuel era.
Now, it's ``I didn't know it was loaded.''
Loaded with steroids, ephedrine, caffeine, whatever.

When US bobsledder Pavle Jovanovic tested positive for norandrostenedione and got thrown off the Olympic team last week, he said it was because he unwittingly took a dietary supplement that contained steroids.

Latvian driver Sandis Prusis made the same claim when he lit up the board in November, but the international bobsled federation bought it and gave Prusis a three-month retroactive ban that allows him to compete in the Games.
But even if Jovanovic can wangle the same deal, he'll still miss the Games, since he tested positive at the December team trials.
And driver Todd Hays, who was counting on Jovanovic for both his two-man and four-man sleds, might miss out on the medal that would end the Americans' 46-year dry spell at Olympus.
Last fall, the International Olympic Committee warned all athletes to avoid supplements, because many of them contain banned substances.
The US Anti-Doping Agency said the same thing, advising athletes not even to take multivitamins.
If athletes have any doubt, they're supposed to bring the supplement to their federation for testing.
They've been told that for years.
But some, like Jovanovic, either don't listen or don't care.
And their teammates pay the price.
Hays, who had a shot to make the podium in both events, is in limbo.
Jovanovic technically is still on the team, pending his appeal hearing this week.
So does Hays still train with him, or with substitute Garrett Hines?
Hays, not Jovanovic, is the victim here.
He skipped the final two World Cup races _ and likely forfeited the six-figure overall champion's bonus _ to get ready for the Games.
Even if he hadn't, Hays would have lost out.
Jovanovic's ban also cost Hays one of his Cup victories.
Meanwhile, IOC president Jacques Rogge expects up to 10 positive tests at Salt Lake, which would be twice as many as all of the previous Winter Games combined.
``I'd much prefer there were none,'' Rogge said, ``but we don't want to let anyone get away with it.''
Will the Boys of Winter get to ignite the cauldron at Friday night's opening ceremonies?
Nobody's saying, but the 1980 US men's hockey team, garbed in game jerseys, will be introduced on the floor of the stadium during the festivities.
And after that?
Only chief organizer Mitt Romney and a handful of others know for sure.
The hottest rumor has been that captain Mike Eruzione and Soviet counterpart Boris Mikhailov will light the candle together.
So determined are the organizers to keep the final torchbearer(s) secret that they've been circulating fake confidential memos with different names . . .
The White House won't confirm it until Wednesday, but President Bush is all but certain to formally open the Games.
If he does, Bush will be the first chief US executive to do the honors at the Winter Games.
Herbert Hoover (1932), Dwight Eisenhower (1960), and Jimmy Carter (1980) all declined . . .
After two months of meandering, the Olympic torch relay finally reaches Utah Monday at sunrise for the final 1,050-mile trek through 50 cities and towns.
Among the modes of transportation: plane, boat, bicycle, stagecoach, horse, skis, and snowshoes.
The torch will arrive in Salt Lake Thursday afternoon . . .
One thing Rogge won't do at Salt Lake's closing ceremonies is declare these Games ``the best ever.''
``I won't do that,'' said Rogge.
``I'll give the opinion of the IOC on the Games, but I will not compare to the other Games.
Also unlike Samaranch, Rogge still plans on living in the athletes' village instead of the usual hotel suite downtown.
The Salt Lake bidders weren't lying when they promised the Lords of the Rings that they'd have snow aplenty for the Games.
Another storm is expected to blow through town the morning of the opening ceremonies . . .

Deadline for bidding for the 2010 Winter Games comes Monday, with at least seven cities expected to be in the scramble: favored Vancouver (British Columbia, Canada), Sarajevo (Bosnia), Bern (Switzerland), Salzberg (Austria), Harbin (China), Jaca (Spain), and Kangwon province (South Korea).
The IOC will choose the winner next year.
What's Jean Racine's side of the US women's bobsled dust-up?
That she offered brakeman/best friend Jen Davidson a chance at a pushoff after she'd dumped her, and that Davidson said nix.
``The day I decided to put Gea (Johnson) in my sled, I offered Jen a chance to push off,'' said Racine, ``and she wouldn't hear of it.''
Racine, stung at being tagged ``Mean Jean'' by critics who called her cold-blooded, says she was just trying to field a gold-medal sled.
``How could I put my best friend on the team,'' she said, ``when she just wasn't pushing well?'' . . .
The US women's ice hockey team pitched a shutout during its four-month exhibition tour, going 31-0 with 22 victories against Games rivals.
The Americans were 8-0 vs.world champion Canada (with a 31-13 goal aggregate), 6-0 vs.China (69-5), 4-0 vs.Sweden (40-3), 3-0 vs.Russia (26-1), and 1-0 vs.Germany (7-1).
They'll open Olympic play with the Germans a week from Tuesday, then face the Chinese and Finns.
Canada, Russia, Sweden, and Kazakhstan are in the other group . . .
Looks like the Olympic ice dancing will be the most competitive in years.

Italy's Barbara Fusar-Poli and Maurizio Margaglio, beaten by Canada's Shae-Lynn Bourne and Victor Kraatz at the Grand Prix final, were knocked off again by France's Marina Anissina and Gwendal Peizerat in the European championships . . .
Now that she's raised eyebrows by making the Olympic figure skating team, Sasha Cohen wants to make jaws drop in Salt Lake by becoming the first woman to land a quadruple jump.
``I'm always looking for ways to push anything I do,'' said the 17-year-old Cohen, who has tried the quad salchow several times in competition.
``It would be amazing to be able to make history in figure skating.''
If Cohen lands the quad, it'll be the biggest breakthrough in women's skating since Japan's Midori Ito landed the triple axel in 1989 . . .
Mixed results for the US skaters at the recent Four Continents championships in Seoul.
Jennifer Kirk of Newton and dancers Naomi Lang and Peter Tchernyshev won titles, but the men didn't make the podium, and Stephanie Kalesavich and Aaron Parchem were fifth in pairs.
Based on this year's World Cup results, Germany's lugers figure to clean up once again at the Games.

They finished 1-2-3 in the women's standings (Silke Kraushaar-Sylke Otto-Barbara Niedernhuber), 1-2 in men's doubles (Patric Leitner-Alexander Resch and Steffen Skel-Steffen Woeller), and third in men's (Georg Hackl).
Though the Americans came on strong in last weekend's Cup finale in Germany (silvers by Tony Benshoof and Chris Thorpe-Clay Ives in doubles), they don't rank in the top three in any category . . .
Not that the average age of Olympic athletes is getting younger, but for the first time in history, there will be an orthodontist on duty at the village polyclinic, just in case a band snaps . . .
Tonya Harding's latest tale of woe:
She and roommate/manager Linda Lewis were evicted from their Washington ranch house by a county judge last week for nonpayment of more than $4,500 in rent.
SOME WINTER STARS PREFER NOT TO GO FOR THE GOLD
Tara Dakides sat comfortably behind the wheel of her Cadillac Escalade as it gulped down the paper-clip bends in the mountain roads before her earlier this week.
She was on her way to yet another snowboard event, and if she needed guidance, there was always the OnStar button.
Her internal compass has its limits, though:
It won't direct her to the Olympics.
As one of the best freestyle snowboarders in America, Dakides competes everywhere, but she will not journey to the Winter Games.
Who needs it?
For most athletes, winning an Olympic medal provides not only the payoff for years of training but also a one-shot chance to slip into a celebrity skin and parlay the moment into a financial gain.
``That's individualized.
If you let it, it will.''
As torn as some snowboarders are on the issue, there is an ambivalence toward extreme athletes from inside the Olympic structure, too.

Some purists recoil at marketing ploys and dismiss these sports as a fad, but leaders of several U.S. sports federations, including those in luge, bobsled and short-track speedskating, want to market the thrill-seeking danger of their sports in order to attract a new wave of athletes.
We just haven't positioned them that way, and we haven't connected with our youth that way.''
Olympians are customarily expected to fit a certain wholesome ideal.
But they were also the same officials who were desperate to introduce snowboarding at the 1998 Nagano Games after watching participation levels double while skiing lost ground.

Even though Olympics officials were embarrassed by the Canadian Ross Rebagliati's positive test for marijuana as a snowboard gold medalist in Nagano, they also recognized the need for tolerance in order to expand their reach.

Jacques Rogge, president of the IOC, did not mention extreme sports by name, but in a speech to the opening session Sunday night, he alluded to the Olympics' need to remain relevant by attending to every generation.
(STORY CAN END HERE.
OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)
The allure of an Olympic gold medal is different for these younger athletes.
Figure skaters like Michelle Kwan earn $3 million annually on Olympic build-up, and downhill skiers like Picabo Street also need a Winter Games moment to catapult their marketability.
Snowboarding blossomed independent of the Olympics, and so a resistance to the Olympic structure seemed inevitable.
Some snowboarders fancy themselves as outlaws fresh from a jailbreak.
Less than a decade ago, snowboarders were either forbidden on the slopes or were required to have a stamp on the hand to glide down a mountain.
There is something real about that.
I've also gotten to see where it's at now, see it evolve.''
On NBC, snowboarding is scheduled to air eight times during the Games, with four prime-time segments and four afternoon slots.

While producers want to resist turning the event into a music video and to avoid the use of snowboard slang _ such as referring to a good aerial as ``sick'' _ NBC executives are seeking the Mountain Dew demographics (ages 18 to 28) that ESPN has tapped into with the X Games.
They won out.
They don't fit the traditional Olympic mold.''
Beyond snowboarding, NBC has also cast lugers and bobsledders as extreme athletes, with a hard sell on speed and risk.

``One of the very important parts of our lead-up promotion is to remind younger adults that the Olympics have sports and athletes who are right up their alley, that some of the original extreme sports are not on some made-for-TV event, but are in the Olympics,'' Neal said.
But whether NBC can translate this approach into Winter Games ratings is up for debate.
Ron Simaio, ESPN's vice president for programming, who is managing director of the Global X Games, wonders if NBC will see an uptick in young adult viewers.
For years, aerialists and mogulers were the quintessential thrill-seekers as they twisted and flipped through the air like Cirque du Soleil stars on skis.
Jonny Moseley morphed into a movie star with the use of his trick skis.
Now, freestyle skiing is feeling the effects of snowboarding's popularity in the form of a reduced participation rate.
The U.S. snowboarding team would benefit from the gravitation of youths to their sport, if all the elite athletes had Olympic dreams.
In 1998, the U.S. snowboarders mustered just two bronze medals.
This year, there are crossover artists like J.J. Thomas, an X Games star, who will dot the American roster.
People want to compete, and the Olympics is a competition.''
The Olympic competition needs the extreme athletes, not just for the American viewers but for the worldwide audience.
Zaynab Behzadnia, director of public relations for the Familie, an action sports marketing agency, represents several extreme stars who have turned what were once cult sports into a global business.
Behzadnia noted that the X Games (the annual winter version was just staged in Aspen, Colo.) are the Olympics to many extreme athletes.
But he said the buzz did not fizzle after the closing ceremony as with the Olympics.
With the Gravity Games, X Games and dozens of other competitions, the money from sponsors keeps rolling in, much to the amazement of the athletes.
Most hope it settles down into a more civilized dialogue.
``I read a lot about X Games athletes and how they diss the Olympics and stuff like that,'' said Jeremy Bloom, the top moguler on the U.S. Olympic freestyle skiing team.
The Olympic athletes also do, too, so I don't think there has to be trash-talking on either side.''
She laughs when she mentions the word career, but Dakides has had to make serious business decisions.
Suddenly, she is able to buy her mother a new television set, keep her father in some very hip clothes and make appointments with real estate agents.
Dakides has a home near Mammoth Lakes, Calif., and a condominium, too, plus a sports utility vehicle the size of a Manhattan apartment.
``It's amazing,'' Dakides said.
You know, after that, what else do you want?''
Some would say an Olympic gold medal.
For many athletes, that is the cherished top prize of their sport.
FROM SECURITY TO SHARED GOLD, THESE WINTER OLYMPICS WERE
An embarrassing bidding scandal, sluggish ticket sales and the specter of terrorism fed a sense of foreboding about the games.
The anxiety seemed to mock a handmade sign hanging two weeks ago outside a house 40 miles from here in the tiny town of Mountain Green: ``Welcome Olympics, Feel at Home.''

By the end of the two weeks that followed, Americans were feeling more at home than ever at a Winter Olympics, relishing their mastery in new-age sports that spawned a record haul of 30 medals through Friday's events, broadened interest in the Winter Games and boosted television ratings by nearly 20 percent.
There was also a pervasive sense of satisfaction over a smooth logistical success amid unprecedented security.
But not everyone felt at home, or wanted, at the Salt Lake Games.
What began in splendor and spiritual unity at the opening ceremony on Feb. 8 is ending with charges of a North American bias wrapped in a vehement anti-American fervor.

The breakdown of collegiality began three days into the games, when the Canadian figure skating pairs team of David Pelletier and Jamie Sale were denied a gold medal victory that many people thought they had earned.
On nearly every day since, the Olympics proceeded on dual tracks: one following the riveting, uplifting competition, the other pursuing a burgeoning backlash and undercurrent of finger-pointing.
These were the fun Olympics, the safe Olympics, the largely compact Olympics, the demographically blessed Olympics and the telegenic Olympics.

In keeping with the rogue spirit of the newer sports of skeleton, snowboarding and short-track skating, there was a rakish appeal to these Olympics from the moment the Americans marched into the opening ceremony in berets and hip, baby-blue vests.
These were also the sour-grapes Olympics.
No result seemed official until the post-event hearing was completed.
As the games unfolded, the figure skating pairs decision appears to have opened the door for aggrieved national federations to protest any ruling they considered unjust.
For most Americans, however, these were the Winter Games that worked.
Launched in the wake of the bidding scandal and with the burden accompanying a record budget of nearly $2 billion, the Salt Lake Games did seem to find a home in the hills and valleys of Utah.

Picabo Street, the American skier who went through an extensive rehab of a badly injured knee just to compete in the games, said: ``The last four years for me have been about that one moment coming into the finish when I heard the Americans roar and saw kids' faces painted red, white and blue.

While the 1994 Olympics in Lillehammer, Norway, have long been credited with reviving interest in the modern Winter Games by capturing the essence of winter climate sports with an ancient setting and simple Nordic charm, the Salt Lake Games captured a Winter Olympics popularly marching into a new century.

At a time when many wondered if the Olympics could endure or remain relevant in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks last September _ when many of its sports were deemed outdated, with its international leadership denigrated or ignored, and with old world alliances threatening its credibility _ the 2002 Olympics instead broke ground, altering the way the games are perceived.
The Salt Lake Games had drama and pathos and were executed with a certain folksiness, but their real success may be the path left for the Olympic movement.

As the most costly Olympics in history, and the first to impose vast security measures that will very likely now become routine and further increase Olympic budgets, the Salt Lake Games may also have demonstrated how difficult it will be for the International Olympic Committee to bring the Olympics to Africa and South America, as it would like to do.

Ultimately, the Salt Lake Games conferred upon the Olympic movement an updated, modernized blueprint for how to run a novel Winter Games that was cozy, attractive to a younger audience, and with significance and sizzle.
Like virtually every Olympic Games, whether modern or ancient, it could not avoid quarrels, frequently with political and geographic resonance.
True to form, the winners were happier than the losers, and again, as in most Olympics, the home team won more medals than usual.
The 2006 Winter Games in Turin, Italy, will very likely benefit from a well-earned bounce from the Salt Lake Games.

If the Olympic movement was shaken by protests and the new ground underfoot, the games still proceeded, for the most part, as if at home in the uncomplicated and largely unadorned mountains and plains of Utah.
COMPETITIONS: IT'S NEW AGE VS.TRADITIONAL

The Salt Lake Games expanded the demographics of the television audience, but they also exposed a split in the Winter Olympics between the traditional sports, like the biathlon and ski jumping, and the new-age sports like moguls and snowboarding that appeal to younger fans.
In the future, the networks and the IOC will have to confront a competition quandary: how to balance tradition with all the wily, young Turks bucking it.

More specifically, how do Olympic officials ensure that Swiss ski-jumping legends, Norwegian gold-medal biathletes and champion Dutch speedskaters are not obscured by all those attention-grabbing snowboarders and short-track speedskaters.
On the surface, it was business as usual in Salt Lake City.
The Nordic nations _ Norway, Sweden and Finland _ won a combined 40 medals at the 1998 Games in Nagano and 35 medals in Lillehammer in 1994.
Through Friday, they had accumulated 35 medals, with Norway leading the way with 11 gold, seven silver and four bronze.
All but one of Norway's 22 medals came from traditional Nordic sports like Alpine skiing, biathlon and cross-country.
The Netherlands continued to be seen as a speedskating power.
All seven medals won by the Dutch entering the weekend came on the large oval.
With 33 medals, Germany led the overall medal count, as it did in Nagano, Japan, in 1998.
It had won nine medals in biathlon and dominated the bobsled and luge events entering the weekend.
Sylke Otto, the gold medalist in the women's luge singles, led three Germans to the podium during a sweep of the competition.

Yet the so-called extreme sports have not only lured younger viewers to the television set in hopes of catching a glimpse of their Generation X brethren catching air out of the halfpipe, they have also given American athletes a stranglehold on newfangled, made-for-TV winter sports.
Snowboarding, skeleton, moguls skiing, short-track speedskating and women's bobsled accounted for 12 of the 30 medals won by American athletes entering the weekend.

Whether it was the strains of the band Blink 182 ringing through Kelly Clark's minidisc headphones as she flew out of the halfpipe to win America's first gold medal at the 19th Winter Games or Apolo Ohno's body nearly perpendicular to the ice as Ohno, a goateed Seattle teen-ager, wove around the short-track oval, these were not your grandfather's Olympics.

Younger, hipper audiences who would not sit through a 30-kilometer cross-country skiing race were glued to television sets for Jim Shea's 51-second, headfirst joy ride on a rattling fiberglass sled in a driving snowstorm to win a gold in the skeleton.

Nowhere was the shift in the balance of power at the Winter Games more noticeable than the night when three Americans, Ross Powers, Danny Kass and J.J. Thomas, took the podium at the medals plaza downtown, having swept the men's snowboarding halfpipe.
Soon after, the Foo Fighters rocked the open-air theater, as snowboarders and their legions crowd-surfed through the night.

Soldier Hollow, the site of the cross-country skiing and biathlon competitions, was perhaps the least-crowded place over the past two weeks _ even though some of the games' most compelling stories took place there.
CONTROVERSY: SHARING THE GOLD, WITH THE PAIRS WILD
On the third night of Olympic competition, Russia's Elena Berezhnaya and Anton Sikharulidze were awarded the pairs gold medal in a split decision that plunged the games into controversy.

The uproar turned the Canadians, Sale and Pelletier, into talk-show guests for a North American audience that adored the pair, and it introduced the world to the French judge Marie-Reine Le Gougne, who had impeccable credentials, and who first admitted and then retracted statements acknowledging pressure she felt to favor the Russians.

Under an intense public outcry, skating officials rushed to douse the firestorm by suspending Le Gougne and inventing a loophole that would allow them to give a duplicate gold to Canada's popular pair, even though the investigation was far from over.
The allegations spun out of control for days.

In an attempt to prop up figure skating _ which had already been besieged by ice-dance judging scandals in the past _ the president of the International Skating Union, Ottavio Cinquanta, proposed a scoring system that abolished the magical 6.0 perfect score.
In June, the skating union is expected to vote on the new scoring method, which would use the marks from seven of 14 judges, selected at random by computer, to determine the final total for a skater.
Many questions about the system are yet to be worked out, and whether the proposal will be approved by the tradition-bound skating union is uncertain at best.
In April, the ISU council is expected to hear the evidence involving the judging scandal surrounding Le Gougne and to make a decision about who is telling the truth.
As long as humans are judging a subjective sport, controversy will loom.
That's part of the beauty of figure skating.
TELEVISION: NBC DOES ITS SHARE OF WINNING, TOO
To televise the Salt Lake Games, NBC reinvented its staid Olympic formula.

It integrated live and taped events to invigorate the tempo; it showed fewer and shorter athletic profiles that shed the weepy motif of many features in Olympics past; and it appealed directly to young viewers by producing sports like snowboarding and aerials as if they were in ESPN's hip, rambunctious X Games, not Baron Pierre de Coubertin's Olympics.
NBC crafted its Salt Lake City production template from what went wrong at the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney, Australia, where ratings fell far below the network's guarantees to advertisers.

But even before NBC rewrote its playbook, it had three advantages that CBS had lacked at the 1998 Nagano Games: a domestic location, a strong American team and a traditional Olympic month to show the Olympics, unlike back-to-school and back-from-vacation September when the Sydney Games took place.
The result: Through the first 14 days, NBC's prime-time Nielsen rating soared to a 19.
3, 18 percent better than CBS' rating four years ago at Nagano.
By the end of the games, more than 180 million people _ individuals who watched at least six minutes once during the Olympics _ will have tuned in.
NBC will make an estimated $75 million profit.

But the lessons learned in Salt Lake City may not be easily applied to the next three Olympics: the 2004 Summer Games in Athens, Greece, the 2006 Winter Games in Turin and the 2008 Summer Games in Beijing.
Yes, NBC can continue with fewer profiles and can still promote and produce with viewers 18 to 34 years old uppermost in its mind.
And it will no doubt add to a technical arsenal that included replays superimposing two skiers racing each other on a slalom course.
Each of the next three Olympic host cities is at least six time zones from New York, however, meaning that NBC will probably revert to heavily taped productions in prime time, as it did in Sydney.
Beijing is 13 time zones away, creating the same potential problems NBC faced in Sydney, when it showed taped programming long after the results were known.
In Athens, NBC is thinking about carrying live events on MSNBC from 7 a.m. to 4 p.m. Eastern time, and an afternoon program with live coverage on NBC.
``But the majority of track and field, swimming and gymnastics will be on tape in prime time,'' Dick Ebersol, chairman of NBC Sports, said.
The Summer Olympics have more events than their winter counterpart, and require more time on NBC.
Yet NBC has learned that broadcasting for three-and-a-half hours in prime time (sometimes four) keeps more viewers watching for longer periods of time than did its five-hour broadcasts from Sydney.
Ebersol said that the lessons from Salt Lake City about the pacing of a prime-time telecast _ with more events and fewer features _ can be employed in a somewhat longer Summer Olympics production.
``We can get more on the air if we do less,'' he said.
FRESH FACES: WHO WILL FORGET SALE AND PELLETIER?
The fresh faces of Sale and Pelletier beamed from cereal boxes in Canada even before the controversy over the pairs skating competition made them the sport's most recognized faces.
But the cries of unfairness that followed their silver medal and eventually won them their own gold medal catapulted them into an international spotlight.
They were among many new faces to emerge from the Salt Lake Games, athletes who got boosted from relative anonymity to international prominence.
Sarah Hughes won a sure sweetheart's place in the heart of a nation when she rose from fourth in the skating short program to first after moving flawlessly through a challenging long program.
This was supposed to be Michelle Kwan's moment, after she had lost four years ago in Nagano to Tara Lipinski.
In aerials, Alisa Camplin of Australia flipped her way to win a gold medal, even though she had never won a major event before.
Jill Bakken and Vonetta Flowers, an American bobsled duo, also made an unexpected appearance in the lineup of smiling gold medalists.
Flowers took up the sport only after failing to make the American track and field team for the Sydney Games, and she had been dumped as brakewoman for another bobsledding pair last fall.
She became the first African-American to win a medal at the Winter Olympics.
In another first for an increasingly diverse country, the speedskater Derek Parra became the first Mexican-American to win a medal in the Winter Olympics.
If Ohno, his U.S. Olympic teammate, was the bad-boy teen-ager of the games, Parra came off as the good guy, a new father who worked at Home Depot to support himself while training.
Jim Shea Jr.was a first of a different kind: the first third-generation Olympian, whose father and grandfather had both competed in the Winter Olympics.

The youngest Shea, a skeleton competitor, was popular before the games, having been chosen by his fellow American athletes to say the athletes' oath at the opening ceremony, just as his grandfather had done in 1932.
But Shea had not been expected to even medal.
He placed a photograph of his grandfather, who was killed by a drunken driver last month, in his helmet before taking off down the mountain.
When he arrived at the bottom, he was in first place, having won the gold, as his grandfather had done in speed-skating.
SECURITY: ORGANIZERS' MOTTO IS SAFETY FIRST

Years of intense planning, enhancements after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and the use of 15,000 law enforcement and military personnel so far are keeping the Olympics as safe as federal officials predicted they would be.

From the beginning, the Bush administration made security at the games a priority, underscoring it in the weeks before the opening with visits to Salt Lake City by Attorney General John Ashcroft and Tom Ridge, the director of Homeland Security.
President Bush attended the opening ceremonies, and Vice President Dick Cheney was scheduled to attend the closing ceremony on Sunday.
The huge federal investment in security _ $400 million _ reflected the enormous challenge of safeguarding the 900 square miles of northern Utah in which the Olympics took place.

It resulted in a massive showing of police and military presence, with checkpoints and magnetometers at the mouth of almost any place an Olympic athlete, official or spectator might visit, including competition sites, downtown hotels, even public plazas for nightly entertainment.

In all, 60 local, state and federal law enforcement agencies have been involved in the security effort, all of them linked for the first time at a major international sports event in the United States through coordinated computer and communication programs.

The need for this type of extensive security arose from the aftermath of a bomb exploding at the 1996 Atlanta Games _ when law enforcement agencies had difficulty coordinating their response _ and then because of the threats and acts of terrorism against the United States, at home and abroad.

Going into the final weekend of the games, the authorities had only garden-variety problems requiring a response, including street protesters getting a little too rambunctious, a man trying to scale the fence of the athletes' quarters, dozens of bomb scares, at least one anthrax scare and about a dozen small planes wandering, unannounced, into Utah airspace.
Nothing much came of any of the problems, officials said.
But the greater relief was that none of the threats so feared after Sept. 11 had materialized thus far.
The security efforts were complemented by thousands of volunteers who kept lines moving, directed pedestrian traffic near competition sites and helped the authorities at the various checkpoints.
Early in the games, there were waits of 30 minutes and more to get through security and into athletic sites.

That, according to Robert Flowers, commander of the Utah Olympic Public Safety Command, was partly because of the diligence of volunteers at checkpoints who were eager to conduct a thorough search, as well as because of the forgetfulness of spectators, who sometimes failed to empty their pockets of potentially dangerous items.
But as the days passed, the system kicked in as planned, and few complained; it became increasingly evident that security was now as visible a part of the Olympics as the five Olympic rings.
TURIN 2006: FOR FUTURE REFERENCE, A NEW STARTING POINT
The two Olympics, they say, will be quite different.
``We cannot copy what they did in logistics,'' said Franco Frattini, Italy's minister of public function, who heads the Italian government's role in the Turin Games.
``But we have to find a path for the Italian Olympic Games.''
But Turin is clearly eager to adopt some of the innovations of Salt Lake City.
Organizers in Salt Lake City decided to award most medals not at the site of the competition, but at a downtown medals plaza.
Turin will have a similar nighttime ceremony, but not in a downtown parking lot transformed into Cinderella's two-week Olympic ball.
It will take place in Piazza Castello, the city's most famous square.
``We don't need to build a medals plaza,'' Valentino Castellani, president of Turin's organizing committee, said.
``History built it for us.''
There will be no new sports or events for the Turin Olympics, and the number of athletes is expected to remain stable at 2,500.
Unless technology intervenes, fewer speedskating records would be set in Turin.
The city is 800 feet above sea level, 4,000 feet below Salt Lake City.
For athletes, breathing easier will mean more air resistance and slower speeds.
Castellani said that after the terrorism attacks in New York and Washington, there had been concern in Italy about how much money could be raised for the Turin Games through sponsorships.
The Salt Lake Games' ability to combine tightened security with down-home friendliness also earned high marks.
``It's not easy to make people feel secure and relaxed at the same time,'' Castellani said.
``The situation we have faced here has been an emergency, and a little bit exceptional, not normal.''
Salt Lake takes home the gold
For many day and in many ways the XIX Winter Games glided along almost as smoothly as the world record-setting speedskaters at the Utah Olympic Oval.
At the United States' first Winter Olympics in 22 years, busses ran on time.
The unprecedented $400 million security effort worked.
The U.S. squad tapped new, diverse talent and was hotter than their blue Roots berets, the must-have fashion statement here.
Americans amassed more than twice as many medals as they'd won at any previous Winter Olympics, fueled in part by loud, proud and appreciative fans.
``The sound literally lifts you,'' U.S. speedskating gold medalist Chris Witty said.
``Generations will pass before we hear that sound again.''
Romney, squeaky clean head of the once scandal-racked Salt Lake Organizing Committee, had no idea how prophetic he would be.
Political squabbles and backbiting have lately marred a well-run $2 billion effort here.
As these Games conclude today, they may be fighting for an unofficial silver or even a bronze in world opinion.

These technically proficient Olympics, the first held in the U.S. since the the problem-scarred 1996 Summer Games in Atlanta, have drawn low scores from Russia, South Korea and sometimes even Canada for the artlessness of officials for everything from figure skating to short track speedskating.
``North American athletes receive a clear advantage,'' Russian president Vladimir Putin claimed, while declaring these Games a ``flop.''
Not that such divisive episodes dampened the exuberance of the fans at the sold-out, flag-festooned venues that many spectators paid more than face value to attend.
``Luge, I've got luge!'' scalpers yelled on street corners here.
Rare was the sport _ major, minor or made-for-MTV _ that didn't have a compelling performance, story or controversy.
Some had all three.

Figure skating was NBC's television ratings star with Sarah Hughes' come-from-behind gold medal performance drawing the most Thursday-night viewers since Jerry Seinfeld's finale about an Olympiad ago.

At office water coolers from Texas to Moscow the hot topic was the dual gold medals awarded Canadian pair figure skaters Jamie Sale and David Pelletier and their Russian rivals, Elena Berezhnaya and Anton Sikharulidze.
But there was so much more.
Speedskater Derek Parra became the first Mexican American to win a gold medal in the Winter Games; Vonetta Flowers the first black.
Steven Bradbury, after a NASCAR-style pileup, became the first Australian to go gold in the Winter Games, pulling his upset in the 1,000 meters short track speed skating.
Liver transplant recipient Chris Klug, an American, took a bronze in snowboarding.
The American hockey team hung on to beat the Russians 3-2 in Friday's semifinal, 22 years after Lake Placid's Miracle on Ice.
Today they'll play Canada in a much-anticipated shootout for the gold.
``Yaaaah! Gold medal!'' Switzerland's Simon Ammann summed up after the Harry Potter lookalike won the first of two surprise gold medals in ski jumping, floating on air longer than anyone else.
Sometimes the world's best winter athletes even offered wisdom.
U.S. skeleton gold medalist Jim Shea, a third generation Olympian, touched hearts by sliding down the hill with the funeral card of his recently deceased grandfather tucked in his helmet.
It's about the friendships.
It's about competing and the world coming together.''
Nyet!
It's all about the medals, winning, the Russian delegation all but screamed Thursday.
And that was before Hughes' bold long program ripped the gold from the grasp of Russian hopeful Irina Slutskaya and American Michelle Kwan.
While stopping short of asking for the return of Alaska, the Russian delegation here did inquire about a dual gold medal for Slutskaya.
They also pressed for a gold for the Russian women's cross-country relay team, which lost nine-time Olympic medalist and national heroine Larissa Lazutina for high levels of hemoglobin.
Can't we all just get along?
Oddly enough, the squabbling and backbiting may have erupted after almost two weeks here because larger problems didn't materialize.
Coming in and going out, security was the major issue of these Games.
As host to the world the U.S. threw almost quadruple the amount of money that was spent on the much larger 1996 Atlanta Games.
As many as 15,000 security personnel were here, almost six guards for every athlete.
The Games hoped for the best, but tried to prepare for the worst.
A 36-member National Response Team, standing by to handle the most serious biological and chemical disasters, sat happily idle.
Almost one dozen small planes were escorted by military jets out of the no-fly zone around events.
Unattended bags prompted bomb scares, which almost became routine, as about one dozen of those were also recorded.
Things that used to wind up in the lost and found, some lunch pails and a backpack, ended up being detonated.
While ever-present, the security stopped short of being heavy-handed or depressing to the Olympic spirit, the way some felt it was in Atlanta.
That was just one edge Salt Lake had on America's 1996 host.

``There were problems with transportation and the computer information systems in Atlanta,'' said Don Mischer, a University of Texas graduate responsible for producing the opening and closing ceremonies in Salt Lake and Atlanta.
``Excellency,'' as Samaranch liked to be called, ruled 21 years.
He liked to be treated as a head of state and some International Olympic Committee members got used to being bribed like corrupt politicians.
That's how the Salt Lake Games really began, with a scandal that would see 10 IOC members resign or be forced from their positions.

Romney was called in to clean up the mess and SLOC bid leader Tom Welch and SLOC vice president Dave Johnson were hit with 15 criminal counts that were dismissed, but recently appealed by the Justice Department.
Jacques Rogge, 59, the current president of the IOC, is trying to set a new tone for the Olympics.
A former Olympic athlete for Belgium, he stayed in the Olympic Village here instead of a five-star hotel.
Rogge, an orthopedic surgeon, is trying to replace pomp with matter-of-fact problem solving.
Yet, not everyone was pleased with Rogge.
Samaranch, among other things, had once been an ambassador for Spain to the Soviet Union.
Although Russia was at the 1996 Atlanta Games, it did not make the 1984 Los Angeles Games, returning the favor for an American boycott of the 1980 Moscow Summer Games.
The Soviet Union used to dominate the Winter Olympics.
In 1964 the Soviets won 25 medals, including 11 golds.
The U.S. had six medals, with one gold.
The Russians have never finished behind the U.S. since joining the Winter Games in 1956, not even when the Games were held on U.S. soil in 1960 and 1980.
Now, they're trailing the U.S. by almost a 2-1 margin in medals.
The officiating in the Friday hockey semifinal game with the U.S. was their most recent complaint of Bear baiting.
Hockey coach Slava Fetisov said of the National Hockey League officials who worked the Games, ``They know the players.
They're Americans.
They're Canadians.''
Others were beginning to tire of the complaints.
The Russians, at least, didn't pack their bags and go home.
Before these Olympics, Romney wondered aloud whether the U.S. should ever again incur the costs and the headaches of hosting another Olympics.
Friday, he thought about it for a second and said, ``I think we have to.''
In the final judgment, the Games that had to go on for so many reasons did.
Salt Lake takes home the gold.
John Maher writes for the Austin American-Statesman; jmaher(at)statesman.com; 512-445-3956
